item.title: An Evening with Jean-Marc
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The die-hard Jura fanatic may remember the wines of Jean-Marc Brignot. The labels were simple, off-white and off-kilter, sometimes whimsically sketched, sometimes totally plain. There was a Melon-Queue-Rouge called “Les Mouches Ont Pies” (“flies have feet”) and a sulfur-less Poulsard called “Jouvenceau” (meaning unknown); both were delicious. Perhaps the Poulsard with its hints of initial reduction and abundant carbonic fruitiness was ever so slightly more memorable than the Melon-Queue; then again I’m drawing on the dusty recesses of my brain for taste impressions of these bottles, because as quickly as the wines appeared, they disappeared again. Where did they go? What happened to the wines of Jean-Marc Brignot? Rumors were afloat here in the U.S., as well as in France (as I later discovered) that Jean-Marc Brignot’s vineyards had fallen into disrepair, that he was a spacey guy and a flake, that he had lost all his vines and, consequently, had no wine to sell. It was with these rumors in mind that, after some hesitation, I sought out Jean-Marc’s email address and wrote him a poorly worded email in French soliciting an appointment for a degustation. Imagine my surprise when he promptly responded, in English, expressing the utmost desire to have his wines sold in the U.S. market again, and inviting me (and my travel companion, an importer, from here on referred to as “MTC”) to join him for dinner and a tasting. I eagerly replied “yes!” and proposed a Thursday afternoon for our visit. No response. A month later with my trip to the Jura looming, I emailed Brignot again: “Jean-Marc, I don’t believe I heard back from you confirming our tasting…” No response. Perhaps the rumors were true after all. On a Wednesday evening several weeks down the road, I found myself sipping Cremant in the dusky courtyard of Jurassian grower, Ludwig Bindernagel, recovering from an epic tasting in the cellar of yet another Jurassian grower, Fan-fan Ganevat, when my cellular technology announced the arrival of an email. The turgid refrain of “Crimson and clover, over and over” wafted from the upstairs balcony of Bindernagel’s mansion as he hand-labeled bottles, a cigarette dangling from his lips. My mouth was a landscape of little contusions the result of tasting too much acidic Savagnin, and I was half drunk. Looking at the recently arrived email snapped me sober: “Sophie, I don’t recall if I replied confirming our appointment. Looking forward to seeing you tomorrow. –Jean-Marc” Well, this incredibly late response would have been welcome had I not already booked three appointments for the following day. What to do? I had waited two months for Jean-Marc’s rely; he could wait twelve hours for mine. Over lunch the next day, I weighed the decision aloud to MTC. I was vaguely irritated by Jean-Marc’s late reply; I didn’t want to taste with four people in one day, but, ultimately, I was incredibly curious. I appealed to MTC to offer a decisive opinion; he un-obligingly left the decision to me. Screw it. Let’s go see Jean-Marc. MTC and I drove to Molamboz (population eighty people) that evening. As the sun set over the rolling hills, our GPS experienced repeated confusion, the sure indication that we were in the middle of nowhere. Eventually we found the tiny, deserted village of Molamboz, and pulled into the driveway of a dilapidated stone house, the address Jean-Marc had given us. We skirted its periphery looking for signs of life before following the only light that indicated someone was home. We ducked into the house and were greeted by a mangy and suspicious little cat followed by a kind-faced Japanese woman (Jean-Marc’s wife, Satomi), who led us through the kitchen to the dining room and went to fetch Jean-Marc. Now, regarding Jean-Marc’s house, suffice it to say that I’ve seen some hippie domiciles in my day; I grew up in one, but this house emphatically won the prize. The kitchen with its piles of plates, abandoned wax-capping projects, and all kinds of other items and objects. The large, common living and dining room was lined with stacks of books and papers. There were fairly abundant cobwebs and, as MTC and I waited for Jean-Marc to materialize, MTC spotted an enormous black spider, its bulbous body and black-legged outline vividly rendered by the evening light through the window pane that was its home. Terrified of spiders, MTC’s eyes were widely glued to this little being as I, in vain, tried to murmur a comforting word. (Me: “Look, I really think the spider’s dead. You have nothing to worry about.” MTC: “No way. I just saw it move.”) Enter Jean-Marc, a tall, jovial man perhaps in his early forties, sporting several days worth of beard and a polar fleece. He had the look of a cunningly intelligent animal, an animal that eluded me each time I tried to identify it, until I settled on a cross between a monkey (the ears that stick out) and a fox (the bright eyes and the pointed nose). He fumbled with an architect’s lamp and an extension cord while explaining that he and his wife don’t actually use light in that room of the house. Once the lamp (clearly a concession to his visitors from New York) was established and illuminated, he sat down next to MTC. He must have observed that MTC’s eyes made frequent visits to the spider in the window pane because his gaze also took in the spider. I was certain at this point that Jean-Marc would trap and remove the beast, but he seemed to view the spider more as a third roommate (after Satomi and the cat) than as an intruder. As Jean-Marc revealed his low intervention, chemical-free approach to winemaking, I began to understand how this rational, philosophically balanced man could happily cohabitate with such a large spider. The bottles came out. The first was a magenta Pet-Nat with about 10% alcohol and the barest hint of residual sugar. It was a perfect summer wine: red berries, bright acid, soft mousse, the perfect balance, and completely without sulfur. It was based on Gamay from the Beaujolais. Jean-Marc owns a few hectares of vines in the Jura. In the midst of a recent, difficult year, he lost all of his production and his vines fell into disrepair. According to other growers in the region, Jean-Marc stopped working in the vineyards and it’s a recognized truth that anyone who wants to make wine without chemicals must put in lots of time in the vines. His story of the loss of his vines gave me a desperately sad feeling; yet Jean-Marc spoke of this episode as a learning experience. “I am not a farmer. I am a winemaker.” Jean-Marc served the second wine out of a decanter. It was ruby red and quite light, peppery, earthy, and 11% alcohol. It was a pure, expressive, and vibrant wine that left me salivating, hungry, and thirsty for more. The wine’s name, “Sun of a Beach,” Jean-Marc explained, was a joke he and his wife had come up with on the beach in Cannes several years ago. The wine was 100% Pinot Noir from organic Saint-Romain grapes. Now, Jean-Marc is a “flying” (or in this case driving) winemaker. He sources grapes from farmers he knows in Beaujolais, Saint-Romain, Alsace, and Ardeche, sets up a winery on-site, and makes wine from the grapes he has purchased. Every cuvee he makes is labeled differently, each with a unique little pun, joke, or reference. He’ll never use the same name again the next vintage and all wines are labeled “Vin de France.” He has no inclination to seek appellation status for any of his wines. This complete irreverence for the system, for the opinions of others, even for the market, generally, coincided with everything I had learned about Jean-Marc over the past few months. This was a man who had forgotten whether he had responded to my emails; this was a man who had no qualms about sharing his odd hippie house with two strangers from an American metropolis; this was a man who spoke eloquently, fluidly and with controlled passion about his work. It all came together, especially when his wines, each one of which showed so much clarity and personality, were in my glass. A warm wave of alcohol washed over us, making us at ease with one another and filling us with general good will. MTC appeared to have made peace with the spider; Satomi brought us much needed and delicious sustenance in the form of a rich, tender potato pancake blanketed by melted Comte. We were enjoying hearing Jean-Marc’s story. He and his excellent English (learned during the six years he lived in Germany) commanded the conversation and, as is often the case with really good winemakers, the man’s mixture of humility and confidence found expression in the wines. Jean-Marc opened two more bottles with the same ’09 label and explained that one was a barrel sample of the 2010 version of this wine: a Gamay called “La Fille en Cage” (“girl in a cage”). Perhaps MTC’s memory is clearer than mine; I recall Jean-Marc telling us that the 2010 would be called something along the lines of “girl who flew the cage.” Again, both wines were stunning. As one would expect, the ’09 was powerful but still lithe and low in alcohol (12.5%?); the ’10 was truly elegant, offering the sweetly carbonic notes of natural Beaujolais. By this point, MTC and I were exchanging significant looks (“We have to have these wines.”) Impressed by their cleanliness, they were totally un-afflicted by what the French call “gout de souris” (mouse-y taste), a lingering flavor of dead yeast or lees on the finish that ruins otherwise delicious natural wine. A winemaker has more or less arrived when he or she has discovered how to make chemical-free wine without “mouse-y” flavors. Satomi, who we learned was in the early stages of pregnancy, left us after dinner with a bowl of little biscotti and the dregs of the bottles, which we were happy to polish off over Jean-Marc’s pontifications. He’d like to move to Japan. He’d like Satomi, who he also views as a business partner of sorts, to make her own wine. He’d like to convert his vineyards in the Jura into a self-sustaining garden, in which to grow vegetables as well as grapes. There were so many plans, both grand and inconsequential yet life-affirming, so many projects and so much vague optimism. And, when we departed quite late, these feelings of vague optimism persisted along with the lingering flavors of the wines, each so memorable. It was a difficult sensation to pinpoint, not the excitement of a new discovery, but rather the affirmation that something I had long suspected would be good, really was rather magnificent in all its utter strangeness. MTC and I chattered in the car (“I mean, what the hell was that?? Where were we? Holy fuck those wines were amazing.” “What about that spider?”), strangely intoxicated by the experience we had just had and needing at all costs to drink the wines again and again and again. -msb

item.title: Wild Strawberries
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: One has to go somewhere upon arriving at Charles de Gaulle first thing in the morning after an excruciating flight from New York featuring very little sleep and even less leg room. I’ve experimented with a variety of solutions to the red-eye flight hangover, most of them beginning with a commute on the RER, past the Parc des Expositions, through the myriad suburbs forming the northern outskirts of Paris, and ending at the crowded Chatelet-les-Halles station. I’ve subway-ed directly to the Gare Montparnasse or the Gare du Nord in order to fall asleep on a TGV speeding away to another French city; I’ve crossed Paris in record time only to wind up at Orly airport facing a flight south to Avignon (I don’t recommend this course of action). What I do recommend is hopping in a rental car, braving the Péripherique, jumping for joy at the signs for Chilly-Mazerin, and heading for Vézelay. Once out of Paris, one quickly finds oneself in the countryside, gazing out the window at green rolling hills, cows, and bales of hay. With no traffic on the A6 and a speed limit of 130 kilometers per hour, Vézelay is a few scenic hours away. Vézelay is in the Yonne départment, south and east of Paris, south and west of the Aube (hipster Champagne capital), and en route to Burgundy. At the center of Yonne is Auxerre, an important city in Charlemagne’s time when much of the départment was planted to vine, and perhaps not so important today. By far the most well-known Yonne wine is Chablis, chiseled Chardonnay with shell-y, kimmeridgean minerality that turns broad, mellow, and cheesy with age. Yonne also features the Sauvignon Blanc appellation of Saint-Bris and the Pinot Noir appellation of Irancy, the wines of which share the red Sancerre quality of being “like licking the dark crystal,” as a friend once remarked (I get giddy when I stumble across Irancy on a wine store shelf…). The Vézelay appellation lies in the very south of the départment and comprises the villages of Asquins and Saint-Père in addition to Vézelay proper. Interestingly, though today Vézelay Blanc must be based on Chardonnay, the original white variety of the region is Melon-de-Bourgogne. Some growers, including Patrick Bringer of Domaine les Faverelles (subject of this article), also plant small amounts of a native red grape called “Cesar,” which is fairly rustic on its own but works for blending. There are only twenty wine growers in Vézelay and a relatively large percentage of them farm organically. In fact, Asquins, where Patrick Bringer lives, is an organic village; pesticides are forbidden here. I arrived chez Bringer on a sleepy Saturday afternoon, the sun a welcome stranger after a long week of rain in New York. The air was dry and bright in spite of the lateness of the hour and full of the smell of warm earth and grass; the earth was lit up differently than at home; crickets chirped and the familiar satisfaction of being in France enveloped me. I was surprised at how arid it was in Asquins. In fact, it was a hard spring for many growers in France because of heat and drought at the beginning of the season. In many places, flowering was several weeks ahead of schedule. Patrick Bringer, a grizzly farmer with a swath of grey shag decorating his upper lip and exceptionally kind eyes, asked the customary question “on commence avec la dégustation… ou on va voire les vignes?” We made the obvious reply: “Let’s go see the vines.” We piled in an ancient hatchback, Patrick and the importer in front, me in the back, and headed for the vineyards. Once we were out of Asquins, Patrick fearlessly bumped up a grassy path to the top of a hill. The bouncing and jostling stirred me to wakefulness and I took in my surroundings, a green landscape at once farther north and less overcast than the Côte d’Or, patches of vines interspersed with patches of woods. This was not a terrain entirely dedicated to vine like some I’ve seen (Beaujolais, Barbaresco), although the vineyard we arrived at the top of was a perfect south facing bowl, the kind of parcel that screams out “plant grape vines on me.” I clambered out of the car and stood surveying the vineyard. Patrick explained the soil composition, limestone underneath with a familiar top layer: red clay! Just like my homeland of North Carolina. Not all the soil was red; some was grey and blue, but the red clay caught my eye. I began to inspect the plants growing in between the vine rows. It’s a well-known fact that good organic growers allow grass and other plant life to thrive in the vineyards and Patrick was no exception. There was a miniscule flash of red amidst the green… and another… and another. Fraises sauvages! The wild strawberries triggered a Proustian childhood memory of picking and savoring these berries one at a time in my parents’ backyard in early North Carolina spring. Fraises sauvages, tangy and sweet at the same time, offer the crunch and slight bitterness of the seeds. It’s a unique gustatory pleasure and one that has very little to do with the giant, mealy, dilute strawberries that are ubiquitous in grocery stores. I cupped my treasure of berries in my palm and refocused on Patrick’s story. Patrick farms six hectares of vines, half Chardonnay and half Pinot Noir (with a little bit of Cesar for blending), spread out across the Vézelay appellation. For twenty years before taking up viticulture, he was a bookseller in Paris. His family is from Asquins and his wife is the mayor of the village. I had heard a similar story in Basilieux-sous-Chatillon (Vallée de la Marne), where Champagne grower, Franck Pascal’s wife is the town mayor. Pascal is devoted to fighting the use of chemicals in the vineyards; perhaps it helps in this endeavor to have the village mayor be your wife. While I couldn’t exactly see Patrick as a radical, he clearly had a quiet but strong belief in organic viticulture and mentioned several times that he didn’t see why any grower working without chemicals wouldn’t become certified. The implication being that “practicing” organic means still spraying when it’s necessary to save the crop. This is approach is called “lutte raisonée and, while there’s nothing wrong with “the reasoned fight,” at the end of the day, it’s better to be organic. Back in Patrick’s tasting room, we were joined by Madame Bringer, who asked if we were hungry then magically produced a massive pie made of cheese embedded in savory pastry crust, which we munched on while tasting Patrick’s wines. We started with his 2010 Vézelay Blanc out of tank, a charmingly orchard-fruity Chardonnay that reminded me of popping cool green grapes in my mouth. There was a core of sweet, green fruit along with fresh, rocky minerality, clear as a bell. Next came the 2010 Vezelay Rouge “Le Nez du Muse” from a special parcel of limestone and red clay. This wine had a bright red character from its “robe” (French wine-speak for “color) to its abundant berry notes. Back in New York, I tasted 2009 “Le Nez du Muse” and found it to be pleasantly indicative of the vintage, with more structure and a darker, spicier, more savory essence than the ’10. This is the “vin de garde” in contrast to Patrick’s lighter and fresher “vin de soif,” the 2009 of which we tasted next. From the first high altitude, clay-heavy vineyard we had seen on our tour of Asquins and environs, this wine had lovely mineral depth and great energy. It showed the richness of the vintage, but had the vibrancy and the distinct flavor of the wild strawberries we had seen in the vineyards. There’s an expression for this: when a wine clearly bears the flavors of another plant cultivated in proximity to the vines, but I can’t remember it. Château Simone from the pine forests of Palette in Provence becomes piney in its old age; Ploussard from Pupillin takes its name from “Plouss,” a local plum that shares flavors with the wines of the village. My mind was full of foggy associations: the wild strawberries of my childhood, the red clay in Patrick’s vineyard, the crickets, the eerily vivid flavor of fraises sauvages in this little Pinot Noir from Vézelay. I was in France but I was in North Carolina; something vague and indescribable about the wine took me home. We nibbled our cheese pie and went to look at Patrick’s tiny cellar, to this day one of the smallest I’ve seen. Patrick opened a few older bottles. 2005 Vézelay Blanc showed rich, herbal qualities and broadened out on the palate like a good white Burgundy. 2006 Vézelay Rouge left a heart-melting impression of beauty with its notes of currants, cranberries, and earth. Supple yet structured, the wine was delicate and lithe with hints of fruit pit on the finish. Patrick told us that the wines are always around 12% alcohol. (!!!) 2005 Vézelay Rouge was quite unlike 2006, with a density and stern-ness that made it feel young and a trifle shut down. It was a good wine that suffered slightly from having been poured in the wake of the knee-weakening 2006. We concluded the tasting with Patrick’s “Ratafia,” a tea-like Vin de Liqueur of Marc mixed with unfermented grape juice. There are just a few recognized appellations (three, perhaps) for this kind of beverage and most is consumed locally either before or after a meal. In this case it was a satisfactorily rustic late afternoon glass to sip in Patrick’s cellar. Then we went to the cathedral. Winding up the main road of the town past tourist-y bistros, postcard stands, and shop windows, there wasn’t a Vézelay wine to be seen, only Chablis and the occasional Burgundy. It’s sad when a town doesn’t seem to realize what a treasure it has in its local wine. High atop a hill in the center of the village, the cathedral is an impressive structure dating back to the 12th Century, its imposing façade giving a sense of great historical significance to the place. It was still, cool, and dark inside the church, and made me think (as every cathedral does) about how brand spanking new everything American seems when I travel to France, how glitzy our renditions of Christianity, our strip mall churches. Outside the cathedral again, tranquility replaced exhaustion. Yes, all in all, I’d say heading to a vineyard, a cellar, and a cathedral in Vézelay is the best way to cure the hangover of an overnight flight from New York to Paris.

item.title: A Bavarian in the Jura: Ludwig Bindernagel
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I first became aware of Domaine Le Chais du Vieux Bourg when Mary Taylor brought the wines by Chambers Street for me to taste. (Mary works for a small importer called Langdon-Shiverick.) The first wine she showed me was a bone dry Pinot Noir-based Crémant from 2007 fruit called “Délire des Lyres.” This wine struck me as unusual for a number of reasons: its long period of maceration, its varietal composition (normally Crémant du Jura is made from Chardonnay), and its price ($30 retail… steep for Crémant and, ultimately why I didn’t buy the wine immediately because it was superb). The nose was nutty and mushroomy; the palate was dry to the point of austerity. It’s a wine for lovers of serious Champagne. Mary also showed me a Chardonnay and Savagnin blend called “BB1” that I liked, and a 2007 Poulsard that stole my heart instantly. The wine was supple and ripe with sweet cherry aromatics, an ethereally pale hue, and 11.9% alcohol. How could I refuse? Mary also told me that the winemaker: Ludwig Bindernagel (something told me he wasn’t Jurassian…) would be coming to visit.   By the time Ludwig came to town, I’d been informed that his wines were “all the rage” in Paris. Parisians have good taste. I sidled up to his table at a tasting to find a tall, handsome, soft-spoken German man pouring a lineup of attractively labeled Jura wines. He had a full head of gray hair and his small, pointed features gave him a vaguely elfin look. His smile was sensitive yet fun-loving. Little did I know I would see that smile many more times, as well as the smile of his French wife, Nathalie, an ambitious blond woman with full, pouty lips, and impeccable taste.   Ludwig and Nathalie have 2.5 hectares of vines in Arlay in the midsection of the Jura, but they live in Poligny, several kilometers away. Poligny, for those less than intimately familiar with the Jura, is the Capitol of Comte, the musky, nutty, semi-hard cheese that is the ultimate pairing with the sous voile Savagnins of the region. Their house, on one of the main drags of the town, is also a “hotel” in the sense that they have two honeymoon suite-like clusters of rooms for rent. It only seemed logical, after making an appointment to taste with Ludwig at the Domaine, that my importer friend and I should stay at their bed and breakfast during our five day long visit to the region. And an excellent choice it turned out to be. Nathalie greeted us on a Sunday evening and we embarked on a tour of the house, a stone mansion with different branches dating back to various centuries. A vast and arching wood front door opened upon a long, stone corridor, the walls of which were decorated with milky plaster cherubs, flowers, and ribbons. At the end of the corridor, she had hung sheer white curtains that parted to reveal a breathtaking courtyard, its periphery planted to roses in all colors. (Trust me, after Brooklyn, this was paradise.) We ate dinner with the Bindernagels: fresh poached river fish in Vin Jaune aspic with salad and Vin Jaune mayonnaise. As an aperitif, we drank “Délire des Lyres” as well as a Brut Rosé of Pinot Noir; with dinner, we drank Ludwig’s Vin Jaune, a light, young, accessible style of yellow wine. Unsurprisingly, all paired charmingly with a dusky evening in the Bindernagel courtyard. We finished the evening with Ludwig’s desert wine called “Papaille” (a play on words: “Pas Paille” or “not Vin de Paille”), a sweet wine aged under flor with 200 grams of residual sugar. Then we smoked cigarettes (Ludwig and Nathalie, as we came to discover, were chain smokers).   Ludwig came to the Jura in the early 2000s. His first vintage was, if I recall correctly, 2002. I asked “So, are you German.” “No… not German… Bavarian. It’s different.” His English was good but he was clearly shy and a bit uncomfortable in the language; we defaulted to French chitchat most of the time. Nathalie also spoke English, but decided that we needed to work on our French and determined to make us speak it whenever possible. I distinctly remember a conversation in which Nathalie and I exchanged expressions in our respective languages: Apparently the French version of “he has lots of baggage” is “il a une casserole en tren” (“he carries a casserole behind him”). During harvest each year, the Bindernagel courtyard is flooded with Bavarians who come each year to pick Ludwig’s grapes, camp in Ludwig’s yard, and party every night. They bring beer, which they exchange for local wine to bring back to Bavaria. Nathalie recently purchased a used restaurant grill with which to feed these visitors. In recent years, so many have wanted to come that they have had more pickers than they can possibly use at such a small Domaine. A good natured and entertaining couple, Nathalie and Ludwig stayed up late drinking, talking, and smoking with us on several occasions, sharing stories from their former lives: Ludwig used to be an architect, which might explain the beautiful interior and exterior of the house. Nathalie was formerly married and has an adopted daughter who works in fashion in Paris. Now she loves to do “bricolage” (a term that loosely means “crafts” or “housework”). I got the impression that everything chez Bindernagel was very carefully designed and executed, from the bottle labels to the impeccable domicile to the wines themselves to the vast array of breakfast foods Nathalie prepared for us each morning including jams she makes from wild strawberries, rose petals, Pinot Noir grapes, clementines… These are people to whom quality of life is very important. They had created an idyllic life for themselves, which I found both admirable and enviable. Yet as much as I enjoyed Ludwig’s wines, I didn’t exactly view him as a vigneron.   Why not? For one thing, he doesn’t come from a winemaking background and has only learned the trade recently. For another, his life didn’t exactly square with my mental image of a rugged country farmer. Still, his vineyard work is very good. He doesn’t use chemicals and has tall grass growing between the rows of vines; he works in the vines every day. And his wines are delicious. “BB1” (another play on words “baby one,” the very first wine Ludwig made), comprises 75-85% Chardonnay and the rest Savagnin, co-harvested and co-fermented. The wine is raised ouillé rather than sous voile and ferments for several years in a very cold cellar. The 2008 was fantastic, with gorgeous fresh acidity, white fleshy fruits, and the faintest hint of quince. His Poulsards are extremely transparent to vintage. We tasted a small vertical beginning with 2009, which was much fruitier and deeper in color than the Rosé-light ’08. The nose was all kirsch and sweet cherry. I asked if the wine underwent carbonic maceration and he replied that there is always some “carbo” but it’s unintentional. We skipped the ’07 and ’08 of the wine, which I already knew, and went to the 2006. At first this wine was extremely reduced, but once the reduction had blown off, it was vividly rose petal-y down to the velvety texture itself. 2005 was almost 14% alcohol and Ludwig confessed he thought he had harvested a bit too late. 2003 was very evolved and “faissant” (gamy) in a way that I associate with Burgundy. I liked the wine but found that, like most 2003s, it lacked the acidity I crave in Poulsard. Finally, we tasted the structured and raspberry-like 2005 Pinot Noir. Ludwig explained that this was a special strain of Pinot Noir known as “Savagnin Noir,” of which there are only two known parcels. This wine I adored (I remembered that I had some of Ludwig’s Pinot Noir coming to Chambers Street from Mary back in New York). We concluded the tasting with a red and a white Macvin, “In Finot Veritas” and “MicMacVin; both are extremely popular in Paris and were succulent and well-balanced. I began to think that Ludwig had a nice touch with sticky wines. We discussed Ludwig’s vineyard and cellar work. He puts two grams of sulfur in the white wines at bottling, one in the Pinot Noir, and none in the Poulsard. On the other hand, Ludwig uses 3-4 grams of sulfur at harvest, a decision that made me question everything except possibly the existence of God... or at least everything about Ludwig as a winemaker. It’s generally understood that sulfur before fermentation kills vineyard yeasts that the wine needs to ferment spontaneously. All of a sudden I began to recall the sweet fruit notes of Ludwig’s Poulsards… He told me he never yeasted the wine, but what if pre-fermentation sulfur made yeasting a necessity? Putain! By this point Nathalie had joined us with snacks, foie gras, cake soaked in orange syrup, gougères, and we were no longer spitting but savoring every sip of the delicious Macvin as we basked in early afternoon sunlight spilling onto to table in the Bindernagel’s courtyard. I pushed the pre-fermentation sulfuring to the back of my mind and relished everything that was lovely about Ludwig and Nathalie.

item.title: A Man Who Gets It: Fan-fan Ganevat
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In the grand scheme of Jurassian vignerons, Jean-François Ganevat is relatively well-known. He may not have attained the cult level fame (and correlative bottle prices) of Pierre Overnoy, but his wines are highly respected and praised in New York, in Paris, in the Jura (where the line “Demain on va chez Fan-fan “ is met with “Ahhh Fan-fan! Il est super. Il est formidable.” ), undoubtedly in the far east, another thriving market for French natural wine, just to name a few. By all accounts, Fan-fan has made it. I had conjured up a mental picture of this man before going to see him based on the press, his wines, and photos: brainy (he has an unusual head shape- ideal storage space for a slightly larger than average brain), maybe a touch insolent, brilliant. I was warned by several people to bring a loaf of bread to the tasting because Fan-fan makes *a lot* of different wines given that he farms only six hectares, which is about the maximum for a one man, chemical-free show in the Jura. An integral part of the myth of this man is that he is a specialist in the micro-terroirs of his region, as well as its ancient grape varieties on their way to extinction. An instance of this is “J’En Veux,” a wine that is made from 17 (if you buy it in France) or 7 (if you buy it in New York) “lost” old varieties cultivated on a tiny plot of land behind Fan-fan’s house. He takes the utmost care with this wine, de-stemming every grape individually with a pair of scissors. (Did I mention I also expected him to be fully insane?) Ganevat farms biodynamically and bottles most of his wines without any sulfur at all. The wines are incredibly clean and flawlessly executed. It’s very difficult to attain this level of purity working without sulfur. (The man has skills.) Fan-fan lives in a miniscule sub-hamlet called “La Combe,” of an already quite small hamlet: Rotalier, in the southern part of the Jura. Keep in mind that Arbois, Arlay, Poligy, Château-Chalon, Étoile , etc… are all within about an hour’s drive of one another, with Arbois in the north and Étoile in the south. Rotalier is yet another hour south of Étoile , on the highway nonetheless, meaning that this is quite different terroir than the terroir expressed by Puffeney’s fabulous Trousseau, for example. As Fan-fan pointed out, he’s as close to Burgundy as he is to Arbois. The climate is warmer; vines that were beginning to flower in Pupillin had finished flowering in La Combe. One views these wines through an ever so slightly different lens, a lens that takes into account that Fan-fan spent ten years working for Jean-Marc Morey in the Côtes-du-Beaune (incidentally one of my favorite Burgundy Domaines of all time). On some level, and despite that this man comes from a 14th century Jurassian family, Fan-fan’s wines are very Burgundian. At first glance, Fan-fan is a big, charming, boisterous country Frenchman. He smokes Marlboros inside his house, doesn’t know how to use a computer, has posters of race cars and bikes on the walls of his tasting room, won’t travel to New York because he’s afraid to fly, etc… Confident to a point that borders on cocky, one would expect this person to get it right, always; in other words, not ever to get it wrong. Based on his wines, he seems to have the perfect right to this confidence. At the same time, he has such a marked sense of humor and such a genuine joi de vivre, that he’s intensely likeable. Our tasting began with beer that Fan-fan makes: a crisp, yeasty beer, perfect for a hot day, which it was. We were in the cellar with several of Ganevat’s laborers, dreadlocked hippies who spend several months at a time working for one grower before moving on to the next. As they drank their post-work beer, they passed what looked like a children’s book back and forth between them. Upon closer inspection, this colorful, illustrated pamphlet turned out to be a handbook giving instruction in biodynamic farming. As nice as it was to be catching a buzz in the cool cellar with Fan-fan’s custom designed de-stemmer in the background, I was ready to get on with our tasting. Our first stop was the red wines out of barrel. These are wines that are immediate and easy to love. Fan-fan’s 2010 Poulsard “l’Enfant Terrible” was a gleaming ruby and rife with the kind of tangy red fruit flavors that make you feel as though you’re drinking fermented fruit rather than wine. Incidentally, I don’t find this kind of vivacity and sense of one-step-away-from-the-fruit in wines that are sulfured. This quality, though it is by no means present in all un-sulfured wines, is unique to them. Next came a Pinot Noir labeled “En Brillat Jus de Presse” (All Fan-fan’s barrels are marked with a masking tape and marker tag with the vintage and wine name). This wine, he told us, came from old vines. This was a pale, fresh Pinot Noir that made a nice contrast to the “Cuvée Jullien,” which comes from younger vines and is ever-so-slightly juicier in character. We also tasted Fan-fan’s Trousseau, “Plein Sud,” (a French expression meaning “full south” and normally indicating that the vines were grown at a full southern exposition), but my tasting note just reads “awesome.” It’s my impression that Fan-fan’s Trousseau is normally under-appreciated within the lineup of his red wines. Newcomers to the world of Jura fall for the seductive light-heartedness of the Poulsard; old school Jura and Burgundy heads love the Pinot, which has been known to taste very much like a Volnay, but the Trousseau gets left behind. My theory is that Trousseau may be an inferior grape variety to Pinot and Poulsard… With the exception of the exceptional Trousseau village of Montigny-les-Arsures, where Puffeney and Gahier make old vine, single vineyard Trousseau with amazing results, this grape seems to have neither the distinction of Poulsard nor the nobility of Pinot Noir. But I’d be happy to be wrong about this. Then we embarked on a veritable cellar-hop (Fan-fan’s wines spend their élevage in a maze of small cellars, some ancient and gnarly, some squeaky clean and modern) that left my mouth ravaged from tasting and my mind reeling from the notion that one man could make so many great wines. The first room yielded a fresh, minerally 2010 Savagnin from three different terroirs, raised in a massive 200-year-old barrel, as well as Fan-fan’s 2009 Chardonnay “Cuvée Florine,” from vines planted in 1986 on limestone soil. Just this incredibly pretty “basic” wine from Ganevat was a joy to drink with an appealing roundness off-setting its sturdy spine of acid and mineral. Next was the wine of the tasting for me: 2009 Melon-Queue-Rouge “Cuvée Margarite.” Only bottled in magnums, the wine comes from vines planted in 1900 and has mind-bending intensity. My impression that Fan-fan’s white wines, especially the old vine whites, are like pillars of concentrated, sappy, mineral-laden stuff, was confirmed in his cellar. The reds are classically ethereal, but the whites are impressive, rich, and seem as though they would age well. “Cuvée Margarite” was the apotheosis of this; the only fault I could find with this wine was that it would take days to drink a magnum because the sheer sappy character would make me exhausted after a single glass. (Fortunately these wines improve in the fridge for days and are seemingly immune to oxidation.) After the Melon, I truly began to see what a master of micro-terroir Fan-fan really is. 2010 Chardonnay “En Brillat,” from schist soil, had a totally different mineral core than 2010 Chardonnay “Les Vignes” from red clay and gravel. Both sets of vines were planted in 1965 giving a similar core of dense fruit off-set by laser-like acid; the distinguishing factor between these wines was their minerality. 2009 Chardonnay “Les Grandes Teppes,” from some of Fan-fan’s oldest vines, (planted in 1919) had an incredible mid-palate and very long finish. We dabbled in Fan-fan’s blue marl-y soiled Chardonnays, tasting several cuvées from vines of various ages. These wines, labeled “Les Chalasses Marne Bleu” spoke of their varietal character more loudly than some of Fan-fan’s other wines, wines that whispered their grape but screamed their place of origin: 2009 “Chalasses” from vines planted in 1930 was incredibly pretty, offering white flowers and apples supported by a spine of electric acidity. As is generally the case when meeting someone for the first time and having a language barrier to overcome, the tenseness of the first hour of tasting mellowed into general ease. Fan-fan was used to us and our ill-worded questions about vine age, barrel age, exposition, etc. and answered us tolerantly and more slowly than he had at first, having discovered that we didn’t actually speak French. The almost cartoon-ish quality to Fan-fan’s smile and manner was complemented by his sleek, grey sidekick, Schiste, a Weimaraner who accompanied him everywhere. We moved on to Savagnin, the thick skinned, high-acid berry that makes the most long-lived wines from the Jura. Fan-fan’s young vine Savagnin from un-grafted vines planted close to his house truly tasted of Savagnin: ripping acidity and a sense of “skinniness” for lack of a better word. Without actually being tannic, the wine had the flavor of grape skins. ’09 Savagnin “Sous la Roche” hailed from a vineyard called “Champs Bernard,” six kilometers from La Combe. This wine, Fan-fan informed us, was made from the Savagnin Vert strain of the variety. (Little did I know there were multiple strains…) The wine had a hint of woodiness that mingled nicely with its quince and citrus core. ’09 Savagnin “En Brillat,” from a high altitude parcel (400 meters) of clay and limestone soil was very different with a crisper, more chiseled character. Finally, ’09 Savagnin “Chalasses de la Marne Bleu” from vines of Savagnin Vert planted in 1930 was a regal wine that dazzled me with its preserved lemon and petrol notes. The wine was extremely complex, even tannic. We concluded the tasting with Fan-fan’s ’02 Vin Jaune, which was as great as one would expect. For this wine, he only uses Savagnin Vert, and the wine had the chicken stock, bouillon quality I have come to love in slightly evolved bottles of Overnoy. The flavors were well delineated with umami notes fading into rich fruit fading into an acidic and even tannic finish. Though Fan-fan seems to gravitate toward ouillé winemaking, his use of the voile was masterful. Then we were back where we started in the tasting room, Fan-fan leaning on the bar chatting merrily away, opening bottles of Crémant, inviting us to taste his “Selection des Grains Nobles,” a field blend featuring the same grapes as “J’En Veux.” Harvested in the first week of December, the wine contained 300 grams of sugar and was, quite honestly, painful to taste with my mouth, gums, and teeth reeling from acidity. We were joined by several Japanese visitors, a local Renault mechanic who works on Fan-fan’s car in exchange for wine, Fan-fan’s girlfriend, a neighbor and his son. It had reached the hour at which country French people stop working and sit down for une petite verre ( a little glass) of something. And frankly, what better place to stop for a little tipple at the end of the day than the cellar at Domaine Ganevat, where the conversation, which could turn to racing as quickly as it could to biodynamic farming , would always be amusing, and where the drink is positively guaranteed to be top notch?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great post. Loved reading it...can only imagine how amazing it would be to visit his cellar and be able to taste his wines with him. The wines I have from him are some of my most treasured. Thanks for introducing me to many Jura wines and always being a trusted source of advice!
Tom- Thank you so much. Truly seeing Ganevat was a treat. Stay tuned for more Ganevat this fall... there may even be some mags of Melon-Queue for us to enjoy!

item.title: Dinner with JBT: The Best is The Best
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: No matter how tired you are, no matter how late you know you’ll stay up, or how hung over you might be the next day, even if it means going above 14th Street, and returning home at 1am in a cab, there are some invitations to which the reply should always be “Yes. With bells on.” One is invited to a goodly number of dinners in the wine business. It’s gratifying, edifying, and can lead to experience of some of New York’s best restaurants… on someone else’s dime. (Needless to say, these functions are accompanied by very, very good wine.) Yet I frequently find myself declining these invitations because I have a hard time sacrificing my time and energy to eat out. I like to cook at home. Not to toot my own horn, but after six years of kitchen toil, I know how to chop things, and I make a mean salad dressing. Also, there’s something truly ostentatious about “fine dining;” the luxury of the experience rankles me, even when someone else is paying for it. Perhaps this is why I’m more inclined to accept invitations to dinners at someone’s home, for a meal they have prepared with wines that are meaningful to them. Perhaps this is why the invitation to dine chez John B. Truax (from here on referred to as “JBT”), old school wine luminary, bon vivant, and quirkily exceptional human, presented itself to me as an opportunity not to be missed. I confess I don’t know much about JBT’s history; I know far less than my good friend, Rosemary, who has had the pleasure of spending many more evenings with him than I have. I know that he has a long history with importer, Becky Wasserman and that he is closely acquainted with the entire Wasserman clan. In the ‘80s, he worked in the music business, which is how The Beastie Boys became regular clients of Chambers Street Wines. He visits Burgundy every year and knows the lay of the land there better than most. This past spring he spent three weeks in Beaune with author and part time wine writer, Jay McInerny, another wine loving fellow from a bygone decade. This is by no means an exhaustive mentioning of JBT’s notable friends. Having drunk more bottles of vintage Bordeaux than I’ll ever look at, I defer to him on old wine questions, but it’s more than that. The man has a unique perspective on and experience of both wine and life, ideal traits in a dining companion. Rosemary and I arrived chez JBT (a classic New York apartment in Murray Hill) on a hot Thursday evening to find him in white linen, cool-ly removing lobster morsels from their casings and tossing the bits in a salad bowl. “I was going to make lobster, but I thought with it being so hot out, we should have cold food. So, lobster salad with remoulade, lobster roe, and finely diced pickles. You have to have the pickles in there.”  Things were off to a good start. “What do you think about pickles, Sophie? I say “You’ve got to have pickles………””   JBT is a slight, somewhat delicate individual with big eyes round as saucers and a chestnut brown hair that I suspect makes him look younger than he is. He has a particular cadence that is irreplicate-able. We’ve all tried to reproduce his ever so slightly nasal, Midwestern tone of absolute assuredness when speaking about old wine, hatcheted bottles, classic pairings, old hip-hop recordings, Parisian restaurants, Burgundy vineyards, Bordeaux Chateaux, etc, etc… No one pulls it off. He sweeps you up in his monologue as you sit back and enjoy the ride. Those who have read Evelyn Waugh’s Brideshead Revisited will recognize characteristics of young Sebastian Flyte in this man. “Sophie. Rosemary. Check this out. This is really, really cool. How ‘bout this 1990 Chateau Simone Blanc half bottle?” JBT dried his hands post lobster processing and pulled a small bottle seemingly out of nowhere. Chateau Simone is one of the “classified growths” of Provence: a majestic castle four kilometers from Aix that is responsible for some of the most long-lived wines of the region. JBT extracted a wrinkled sheet of paper from his pocket with a list of grape varieties scribbled on it: Clairette, Grenache Blanc, Ugni Blanc, Bourboulenc, Muscat Blanc…. In northern France (home of almost all the French wine that interests me), it’s desirable to have south-facing vineyards in order to attain maximum ripeness. At Chateau Simone, in the arid and almost desert like climate of Provence, the north-facing, limestone heavy soil of Chateau Simone helps retain freshness and balance in the wines. ’90 Simone Blanc (out of half bottle) was vivid, lively, waxy, pine-y, perfectly alive and content with the olives, salty ham, marcona almonds, and buttered bread that began our meal. “My friend, X” (it’s inspiring how many of JBT’s sentences begin with “my friend;” I’d like to think this phrase- ubiquitous in his monologue- is linked to a genuinely positive view of human relationships, to a life well-lived, to friendships happily and dutifully maintained in an environment of callous, selfish beings) “got this bottle at a store in London. This wine came all the way from London and there’s no one I’d rather drink it with that you.” Flattery and half bottles of perfectly mature Chateau Simone will get you everywhere. We followed ’90 Chateau Simone with a midcourse of ’01 J.J. Prum Wehlener Sonnenuhr Auslese.  J.J. needs no introduction. Ancient and aristocratic, the Prums own vineyards in the famous towns of the middle Mosel: Wehlen, Graach, Bernkastel, etc… The wines are known for being incredibly sulfurous, almost undrinkably so as young wines, and, consequently, extremely age-worthy. I hadn’t drunk a bottle of Prum in quite some time and I’m no Riesling expert so this bottle was an interesting departure for me. JBT popped a couple of slices of brioche in the toaster, began unwrapping a log of foie gras, and asked us to choose between two grocery store peaches that I worried would be disappointing. Two minutes later, we had ripe, aromatic peach with salty, fatty foie gras on toast in front of us, and glasses of succulent Auslese. The Wehlenher Sonnenuhr vineyard is known for producing very peachy wines and, sure enough, there was incredible harmony between our second course and our second wine, peaches hauntingly echoing peaches, the incredible acid and almost cloying sweetness of the wine more than adequately cut by the foie, a faint petrol-y hint of mature Riesling presiding over the whole affair. I hadn’t been in ’01 Riesling heaven in some time, since the Terry Theise portfolio changed distributors in North Carolina and abundance of ’01 Donnhof materialized at ridiculously low prices. Donnhof Spatlese by the pool, anyone? Close on the heels of my favorite recent German vintage came a bottle from my favorite recent Burgundy vintage as JBT uncorked a bottle of ’02 Louis Carillon Puligny 1er Cru “Le Champ Canet.” This was the bottle that was to accompany our lobster salad. “It’s like white wine fest!” JBT interjected. “My wife doesn’t like white wine… so I don’t have anyone to drink these bottles with.” Lobster salad came to the table along with chunks of avocado and I tried to find room in my already full stomach for a third round of rich food and great wine. Though white Burgundy will always be appreciated by lovers of classic, regal French wine, it’s not a popular category with the geeks right now, who clamor for more cut, a lighter frame, more filigree, and less oak influence. (There are some exceptions: Chenin Blanc, “orange” wine, and Chablis, a steelier rendition of Chardonnay in Burgundy.) My primary education in Cote-de-Beaune Chardonnay took place a few years ago with a boyfriend who was a true Burgundy lover, and I’ve enjoyed the wines ever since. This bottle of Carillon had all that I love about white Burg: a whiff of Burgundian earth on the nose, a lactic richness on the palate buoyed up by waves of acid and more earth, and a long finish of green herbs, lemons, and minerals. As our attack on the lobster salad slowed down to a nibbling pace, JBT pulled out one classic French food and wine book after another… and then opened a bottle of ’90 Coulee de Serrant. I mulled over pictures of how to butcher a fish such that its head could be stuffed through its body, thus enabling the chef to fit four or five fish in a pan at once. Rosemary began to read aloud from “Notes on a Cellar-Book” by George Saintsbury (published in 1939). “One of my father’s sisters was a very old lady, who lived by herself in a remote part of the country on no large income and in a quiet way. Having some trouble with her eyes, she came up to town to consult an oculist and naturally stayed with me. The oculist, finding nothing organically wrong, but only a certain weakness of age and constitution, recommended her to drink Burgundy. I gave her some Richebourg, telling her frankly that it was a very expensive wine, and some of a sound Pommard, which could be had for between half and a third of the price, that she might chose to order from the merchant who supplied both. I had imagined that the first figure would either frighten or shock her; but she said with perfect simplicity: ‘I think, my dear boy, that the best is the best,’ and ordered a small supply of the Richebourg forthwith.” This passage from Saintsbury made quite an impression on our little group. Our evening was like a testament to its culminating line, its “moral,” so to speak. Though JBT has been convinced for some time that “the best is the best,” for Rosemary and me, who live in an ever changing world of wine and food fads, it’s helpful to recall the sheer glory of great wines and their classic accompaniments. JBT was giving us this opportunity. I wish I could remember more about the ’90 Coulée de Serrant. It was very good with its honey and hay bale old Chenin character. JBT reminded us that Coulée de Serrant was a great vineyard long before Nicolas Joly was even “a glint in the milkman’s eye.” Rosemary and I consulted some books to see if we could find the right food pairing for this bottle while JBT called his friend, “Y,” a notable wine luminary who might know the answer. “Y” was in accordance with JBT’s books that river fish in a butter sauce is the right pairing for old Savennieres.  Like all Coulée de Serrant, the wine changed a lot in our glasses, but we were already moving on to something else by the time it began to sing. I had been eyeing the clavelin of ’83 Chateau d’Arlay Vin Jaune on the corner of the table for the duration of the evening. JBT announced that either we’d open and drink it, or I’d take it home with me. Curiosity inspired us to select the former option. JBT cut chunks of Comte and Tomme and meticulously removed the wax from the top of the bottle. Chateau d’Arlay is an ancient castle in the town of Arlay in the Jura. The Laguiche family has presided over the Chateau and its wines since, if I remember correctly, the 10th century. While I don’t consider the wines of Chateau d’Arlay to be amongst the region’s most exciting, they are certainly amongst its most traditional. Aggressively musky and redolent of the thick layer of yeast called “voile” that forms on top of the wine in barrel allowing a slow transference of oxygen to the wine, Vin Jaune is a bit strange when young. But, with decades of bottle age, the wine becomes caramel-y and soft with aromas of bouillon and mirepoix: carrots, celery, and onion. The nose on this bottle of ’83 was all savory umami and the palate was all silky, voluptuous texture. At the end of the evening, this was the bottle we kept returning to, taking little sips and marveling at each one. It was a super evening that left me with a feeling of satisfaction with and respect for the past, for what, in a constantly changing world of food and wine, has been proven to be great time and time again…

item.title: Eating and Drinking in Montreal Part 1: An Inferior Waiter Serves Superior Poulsard from Domaine L’Octavin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I had been wanting to visit Montréal for at least five years, but there were several serendipitous events clustered together that prompted me to book a flight. A good friend- not from high school but from that era- lives in Montréal: Curtis, who is Canadian of origin but grew up in Mebane, NC, a veritable hell hole of fast food, nasal southern accents, and vinyl-sided suburbs. Post college, Curtis relocated to Montréal and made his dream life as an industrial engineer. I should mention that Curtis was the first person to visit me in Brooklyn after I moved to the metropolis from my own home of Chapel Hill, NC. A visit to him was long overdue. I had no plans to make the journey north when Martin Labelle wandered into Chambers Street wines on a Sunday afternoon to pick up a couple of bottles to take home to Canada. This tall, enthusiastic Francophone guy who began many statements with “theez guy” amassed such an interesting collection of bottles on the bar that I had to strike up a conversation. We knew many of the same natural winemakers: “theez guys” Olivier Lemasson, Frank Cornelissen, Philippe Bornard, to name but a few. A long chat ensued touching on a range of topics from visiting Bornard in Pupillin to drinking at Ten Bells on the lower east side to the bizarre Québécois alcohol laws. This was a kindred spirit; I began to tell myself that it was high time I stopped talking about going and actually went to Montréal. A few weeks later, after a whirlwind tour of the Jura, I found myself in a Paris wine bar called “Spring” talking to the effortlessly beautiful and genuinely friendly Laura Vidal. Laura is the sommelier at a popular Parisian restaurant, Frenchie, and must be incredibly talented because Kermit Lynch has attempted to co-opt her as a scout. After a few minutes spent bonding over mutual ambivalence about Natural Wine in spite of a deep a love for many natural wines, Laura revealed that she’s from Montréal. “Oh! I’m about to go there for the first time!” As soon as the statement was out of my mouth, I knew I had to make this pipe dream a reality. “I’ll recommend some restaurants.” I ripped a page of out my moleskin notebook and handed it to Laura, who made a tidy list of all the joints in Montréal at which I simply had to dine. My first impression of Montréal was that it was very hard to get into. I waited in an endless customs line only to be interrogated about my visit, its nature and length, the friend I’d be staying with, his neighborhood, the duration of our acquaintance, etc... All this for three days! Once I was safely out of the airport and drinking beer with Curtis in the Mile End section of Montréal (equivalent to our Williamsburg), I was quite content. Our hip waiter spoke interchangeably in French and English, serving us a sandwich called “Péché Mortal” (mortal sin). It was Friday night and there were lots of people of various ages hanging out, lingering over food and drink on outdoor patios. We went to a nearby wine bar, Buvette Chez Simone, where we ordered a bottle of refreshing 2010 Guy Breton Beaujolais and some snacks including “smoked meat,” salty, smoky cured meat like thick-sliced pastrami. On the terrace, waiters recently released from work and enclaves of very cool Québécois sat smoking and drinking “canons.”  This city, after just a few hours, struck me as both decidedly European and unmistakably North American. Like Québécois French, as Curtis pointed out, which sounds like you’d imagine French to sound transposed to North American, the same language spoken in a more rustic, blunter, and less mellifluous key. Saturday was a big day. From Curtis’ neighborhood, Côtes des Neiges (awkwardly translated as “Snowden”) a Hasidic Jewish community of families and quiet streets, we walked through Mile End and toward the Vieux Port, the river, and the scenic old city. I learned that wine can only be sold through state run institutions called “SAQs,” akin to the ABC stores in North Carolina that hold a monopoly on hard liquor sales. We checked out an SAQ and I became very sad for the population of Montréal.  The shelves were lined with bad Rose, mass produced, Merlot-based Tuscan wine, and négociant Burgundy.  I made my way to the Loire Valley section of the shop and things began to look up: Chinon from Bernard Baudry and Mardon Quincy. A dusty bottle on the shelf nearest to the ground caught my eye: Bossard Expression Orthogneiss, an oasis in a desert of bottles! We passed the Quartier des Spectacles, where several events were taking place including “Just for Laughs,” a well-known comedy festival. We stopped to watch a bizarre sporting event consisting of a relay race followed by hardcore weight lifting. The vicarious exercise made us thirsty and we sought beer at a pub close to our destination: Le Vieux Port.  Sweaty and tipsy, we wandered along cobblestone streets, crowded with tourists; we took note of several limos waiting to whisk sets of brides and grooms off to their honeymoon flights. This was the Montréal of my imagination, the Montréal my parents had described from their visit decades ago. We had barely reached the river when we realized that we needed to find our way back to Côtes des Neiges in order to make our cocktail appointment and dinner reservation. Rather than take the subway, Curtis suggested that we rent Bixi bikes, three speed rental bikes that could be returned at a station in his neighborhood. I hadn’t ridden a bike in over four years and have only ever had a tenuous grasp of the skill. Mildly buzzed, I bumped down hills against oncoming traffic on my Bixi, no helmet, my heart racing, then up again, pedaling hard, trying to keep up with Curtis, and employing leg muscles that hadn’t been used eons. It was great. By the time Charity, a musicologist and consummate foodie, arrived to meet us at The Sparrow for a cocktail before dinner, Curtis and I had polished off a poutine between the two of us. It may sound odd to pave the way for a meal in a super restaurant with a large plate of fries topped with gravy and cheese curds, but we were starving after our day of site seeing. Besides, it was essential that I try this Canadian specialty. I confess I was afraid, but when the poutine arrived at our table, my fears were allayed. My error was in imagining that the gravy would be thick, southern, gelatinous gravy based on corn starch or flour when, in fact, it was deep brown reduced meat sauce that was rich but in no way heavy or cloying. The cheese curds were deliciously salty, the fries, perfect, and the whole affair dusted with black pepper. Also alarming in theory but less so in practice was the cocktail Curtis ordered, a Bloody Cesar, a Bloody Mary-like drink with Clamato juice, a kind of clam flavored V8 juice, instead of the standard tomato. As it turns out, clam adds a further savory element to the drink without giving it perceptible fishy notes.   Martin, though he could not attend, had made us a reservation for the terrace at Le Filet, an (almost) all seafood restaurant in the Plateau district of Montréal, over-looking the base of the mountain itself. The 80s throwback décor was a bit odd and I was alarmed to see the table of three well-dressed Canadians next to us happily sipping mojitos with their oysters, but a quick look at the wine list put my mind at rest. I tasked Curtis and Charity to order the food, eight small plates to be shared between the three of us, while I set about placing a wine order. The first bottle that caught by eye was from Olivier Jullien in the Coteaux du Languedoc, a white version of “l’Etats d’Ame” (“states of the soul”). I had drunk many a bottle of the red but had never seen the white. I didn’t doubt that the wine would be good, but I suspected it would be heavy and perhaps not an ideal match for oysters. “Vous avez des questions?” Our waiter, an aggressive and slightly cocky young guy asked. “Yes I wonder if I could taste two wines that you serve by the glass.” Québécois seem to have no problem using French and English interchangeably. Our waiter slipped into perfect English. “Why do you want to taste them?” “Well to see if we want to order a bottle.” “What are you looking for? What kind of wine do you like?” “I want to taste the Mas Jullien and the Chablis that you serve by the glass before we order a bottle.” “For me, I’d get the Mas Jullien. It’s really light and crisp.” Really? “Hm. It’s generally been my experience that white wines from the Coteaux du Languedoc are on the richer side” (not to mention the fact that there is nothing delicate about Jullien’s wines, generally, which are powerful statements of the wild, almost scorched, arid Languedoc). “Fine. I’ll bring them both for you to taste.” This was a bizarre style of customer service. To cut a long story short, we ordered the Mas Jullien, which was a fantastic bottle of wine made entirely from Carignan Blanc or Grenache Blanc depending on which waiter I asked. The wine was not, however, light or in any way crisp, but rich, floral, clearly oaked, unctuous, and 14% alcohol. Our first few plates were delightful: oysters in a Japanese preparation, oysters baked on the half shell with one sautéed mushroom, cream, and truffle oil, raw scallop salad with beets, fluke Carpaccio. Then there was a lull and we finished our bottle of Mas Jullien and began to contemplate a second bottle. I asked our friend, the rude waiter, to return the wine list to me. We discussed a Bourgeuil and a Cru Beaujolais from Guy Breton, whose village wine we had drunk the night before at Buvette Chez Simone. The waiter brought glasses for us to taste. Both wines were good but neither was what I wanted. “Do you want to try something different? I have this wine from the Jura…” I had noticed Poulsard “Dora Bella” from Domaine l’Octavin on the list but had skipped over it in favor of wines I don’t see in New York. “Yes I know the wine. Sure. Let’s do it.” I turned to Curtis and Charity “I have pictures of the winemaker’s kids on my phone. I visited them in May; they are really sweet people.” This marked the turning point in my relationship with our waiter, who listened, amazed, before continuing his monologue. “It’s a little different, this wine. I hope you like it. “It’s bottled without sulfur,” I told Charity and Curtis. “I think you’re right,” chimed the waiter. “I know I am. Alice and Charles bottle all their wines without sulfur.” Smile. I will save the story of my meeting with passionate Alice and sweet-natured Charles of Domaine L’Octavin, their gregarious three year old, Anatole, who offered cherries and marshmallows to each member of our party, the perfectly shaded deck on which our tasting was staged, and their lineup of super, sulfur-less wines for another time. Poulsard “Dora Bella” had travelled very well from Arbois to Montreal, not always a given with wines lacking in preservative. It had the unmistakable fruitiness of carbonic maceration, the tell-tale blood orange, citrus-y red character of Poulsard and showed barely a hint of reduction, a symptom of many Poulsards. I asked my new friend, the waiter, to bring us an ice bucket so that we could appreciate the wine at the proper temperature. It unfolded in our glasses to reveal the ripeness of 2009, and the sheer, soft, natural-feeling drinkability of un-sulfured wine. Our banter continued, and a second wave of food arrived: grilled octopus with bone marrow (who says the lily shouldn’t be gilded every once in awhile?), homemade pasta with slow braised meat sauce, and more delicacies that run together in my mind.  Nighttime enveloped the patio of Le Filet as we contentedly polished off our fantastic bottle of Poulsard.

item.title: On Wines and Scenarios
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Not too long ago, my friend Brooklynguy published a piece about wine and situation pairings. Roughly, the article was about tough situations that arise in parenting and the wines that complement them.  I really enjoyed this post and it got me thinking about the interplay between wines and situations. The tenor of this piece seemed to comfortably acknowledge that we drink wine away from the table, in un-food-related scenarios, and sometimes just because we bloody well want a drink. Drinking wine for its alcohol is essentially base, yet pretending alcohol isn’t part of the appeal seems like bad faith.  The truth is that the vast majority of us don’t always drink in an analytic way or for a particular symbiosis with a much-loved dish. Wine enthusiasts – myself included - seem to drink with an almost pious respect for the interaction between terroir and flavor.  Also, we pretend we only to drink wine with food. Not true. There are too many situational wine harmonies just to drink wine at the table. After all, situation and company play such a profound role in our enjoyment (or lack thereof) of wine. A mediocre liter of Grüner Veltliner with someone you love is one thing… a bottle of perfectly aged Burgundy with an insufferable wine industry blowhard sitting next to you at the table is another…

When we are drinking wine away from the table, we are drinking for the relaxing properties of alcohol, but we are also drinking for flavor. I love the idea that flavors can complement scenarios.  For me, dry Rosé pairs well with getting ready to go out: the invigorating color, the zingy red berry and, if you’re lucky, mineral flavors, enlivened by acid, and just the right amount of alcohol to increase the drinker’s confidence before entering a bustling milieu. In a similar vein, some wines are just plain comfort wines, the wine equivalent of macaroni and cheese: Mosel Riesling… a Piesporter Goldtröpfchen from Reuscher-Haart, for example.  This is a wine to take solace in, the peach and pineapple flavors imparted by the “droplets of gold” vineyard, the sweetness and acid like a lullaby. I like Champagne in movie theatres, most recently 2005 Larmandier-Bernier Cramant during “True Grit.” A soft and mushroom-y vintage for the wine, it was a nice pairing with this earthy Cohen Brothers film.

Over the past few weeks, I was in a good - if incredibly sad - position to appreciate wine and situation pairings. My father passed away; I was devastated and at once manic and totally dulled. I didn’t have the energy or the time to think much about wine, but I did drink a few memorable bottles. Here are some wines that affected me, and the scenarios in which I drank them:

Tuesday, August 23rd I arrived in North Carolina after a sleepless night in New Jersey followed by an almost laughable three hours in the Newark airport during which my fellow passengers and I were told that our delay was caused by a flight crew having failed to report for duty at the airport in Buffalo. At my grandmother’s house in Chapel Hill, faces were sullen and grief-stricken. Everyone behaves differently when a loved one dies, but tears and zombie-like meandering during the first few days after the event is a common mode of behavior. Enter 2010 Ameztoi Txakoli, selected by my best friend, Susannah, and left in my grandmother’s fridge to chill as I napped. Upon waking and finding the bottle, I poured myself a sizable glass and inhaled the salty,  lime-y, and floral aromas of Txakoli. The freshness of the wine woke me up; its sheer liveliness and vivacity burst through my dulled and somber mood like a vivid ray of light. There will be joy again; here, in my glass, is proof of this fact. Now, I don’t know that Ameztoi’s is the best Txakoli in 2010 though I do have a personal penchant for the bubbly styles that come from San Sebastian; these days there are many contenders. But I know that as I drank that glass of Txakoli, I began to see a very distant glimmer at the end of a very long corridor. It was an excellent pairing.

Then there was a bottle of Clos Roche Blanche Rosé consumed at Susannah’s house deep in the woods—North Carolina woods that fade into the recesses of my mind in New York. This is countryside I know well enough that no amount of time spent in the booming metropolis will destroy our intimacy. Susannah lives so far in these woods that there is no traffic noise, practically no noise at all, and you can see lots of stars from the deck. Susannah’s house is a lot like the house I grew up in: strangely shaped and pieced together from old wood, cool because of ample shade rather than air-conditioning, and possessed of a very distinct, comforting, homey smell. This wasn’t the first time I had retreated to this house with its wonderful inhabitants—Susannah and Francesca, a tricolor tabby—in a time of need.

Just a few days had passed since my dad’s death, about enough time to begin to fathom that he wouldn’t be ringing my cell phone, wouldn’t be picking me up from the Raleigh airport in his beat up old truck, wouldn’t be calling me “sugar” or “sweetie” ever again. It was in the midst of this paralyzing sadness that I brought Clos Roche Blanche Rosé to Susannah’s.

Catherine Roussel and Didier Barrouillet’s wines have come to symbolize everything that is great about Loire Valley natural wine; the praise these wines have garnered is much deserved. Amongst their wines, Pineau D’Aunis and Rosé of Pineau D’Aunis have always been my favorites. “L’Arpent Rouge,”  red Pineau D’Aunis, is only made in some vintages and is one of the most unforgettable wines of my life, a wine that grabs your brain and won’t let go. It is a jubilant wine you can pour for just about anyone you want to make smile. CRB’s Rosé of Pineau D’Aunis is less a “comfort” wine than a stunning curiosity… in successful vintages. In 2009 there were problems. Initially the wine was ever so slightly sweet and quite lovely; after a couple of months stateside, the wine was totally dry and ever so slightly bubbly. Refermentation. Interestingly some people enjoyed the refermenting bottles; I was not one of them. 2010, a cooler and more mineral-driven vintage in the Loire (and France generally) gave thirsty CRB lovers as delicious a vintage as I have ever had of Pineau D’Aunis Rosé: redolent of flower petals and pepper and the faintest hint of floral soap, texturally lush from lack of filtration but taught with acidity, pretty but by no means facile and, above all, unique. No wine tastes like this wine.

By the time Susannah got home from work, I had cried all I could cry and opened the bottle of Clos Roche. I poured us two glasses. Miraculously, through my clogged nose, I smelled this beautiful thing and here (!) here (!!) was a reason to keep going, not just to be able to drink this wine but to know it and talk about it and sell it and share it. Words fail sometimes. It was a super bottle consumed in a peaceful, affirming place.

A week later, I did a totally self-indulgent thing: I went to the beach for a few days. I hadn’t visited North Carolina’s shores in years, and was looking forward to long walks losing myself in thought, healing in salt water, eating fish, and listening to waves. On the last evening of my visit, I had an hour all to myself. The others were napping or getting ready for dinner and I took my book to the upper deck of the beach house, which commanded a perfect view of the early evening waves. I opened a bottle of 2010 Sigalas Santorini Assyrtiko and poured myself a glass. A very old friend called to tell me that an even older friend had become a father. The news ushered in a fresh round of unstoppable tears. I might have kids one day; they will never know their grandparents, my parents. Full of self pity, I put my nose in the glass: honey and smoke, salinity and sweetness that has nothing to do with fruit, exotic tropicality of the type found in Jurançon Sec. There is a rich, sea-like quality to this Greek island, volcanic soil cultivated wine that is all its own. The weight and texture is reminiscent of Chenin Blanc or Jurançon, the palate hefty, succulent, and mouth-watering. The air was sticky and briny; the wine was briny. Even the color of the wine in my glass somehow harmonized with the golden light of the sun and sand. I have enjoyed this wine before, but here it was perfect. I sipped and thought about my dad and cried and sipped and thought and became tipsy and slowly felt a little bit better.
