item.title: Burgundy: Vintages, Vineyards, Past loves, and Present
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Moving files from an old laptop to a new one last week, I came across notes from several years ago. I wrote them up after a tasting put together by my former boss at Astor, one I’ve recalled several times as my love and understanding of Burgundy have deepened. As smitten as I am with the Jura, Champagne, Beaujolais, the Loire Valley, I find that good red Burgundy tugs at my heartstrings like no other wine. There’s an ineffable je ne sais quoi, a mingling of soil, fruit, and mineral in red Burgundy that is absolutely divine. (Obviously not all the time, but when it’s good it’s phenomenal.) I’m also fond of white Burgundy, but it produces a different sensation. Red Burgundy is romantic, waves of incredibly pretty often petal-y textured, aromatic, seductive Pinot fruit interplaying with the most compelling scents of earth and mineral, then the incredible resonance in the cheeks from acidity, then endless finish. Red Burgundy makes me feel the way Chopin Nocturnes used to make me feel when I was playing them on the piano as a teenager. White Burgundy feels more baroque or classical, earthy but subtle, often more powerful than pretty. I find white Burgundy (though not Chablis, which I find androgenous) to be more masculine and red Burgundy to be more feminine, echoing Jura in this way (or maybe Jura is echoing Burgundy…). Perhaps white Burgundy is more like playing Bach or Mozart, but I don’t wish to overextend this dubious musical analogy. The weather has turned autumnal, to my chagrin, and I have been drinking more red Burgundy than I did during the summer months. It’s the season of roast game birds, root vegetables, and sprinkling thyme on everything. Red Burg, anyone? In the spirit of crisp days and chilly nights, I’m offering my notes from a 2008 Astor staff training followed by my notes on a few more recently tasted Burgs. Astor, 2008: I’d been working in the business for a few months when I had my first (and to this day my most) transcendent Burgundy experience. I was at Susannah’s house in rural North Carolina surrounded by acres and acres of barren winter trees. The sun had set; I’d been there for hours soaking up the company, chatting about boys and old indie rock bands and, most importantly, wine. We’d drunk a sparkling Bonarda and a Lopez de Heredia Rosé and were rifling through her wine fridge fondling bottles, looking for the next victim when her face suddenly lit up. “I know what we can drink.” Buried beneath several Chilean samples was a spotty labeled Burgundy bearing the elegant cursive Pommard “Les Pezerolles.” The wine was made by Hubert de Montille, the adorable French octogenarian who so quaintly epitomizes Burgundy in the movie Mondo Vino. A 2000 vintage, not stellar in Burgundy but then great producers make great wine in off vintages; the bottle looked like a promising choice to me. Susannah explained that the wine was un-sellable because the wine-speckled label indicated leakage, therefore possible heat damage. She uncorked the bottle and poured two glasses. A panoply of aromas: red currants and cherries and blood and earth filled my nostrils. The wine was soft and delicately voluptuous in my mouth continuing on and on seemingly endlessly. I had read that great Burgundy could have a peacock’s tail-like effect, starting small but growing into something massive and colorful. What an apt analogy for this wine, the memory of which has stayed with me since. In staff training we tasted through an array of Burgundies, all from Côtes de Nuits villages, points north of my darling Pommard Pezerolles, which has lingered in my memory like a first love. I have to say it was a kick ass tasting in part because my boss picked traditional producers to feature and in part because we tasted a bunch of ’05s, which was a vintage in which (wine pundits will say) you had to be a moron to make a bad wine in Burgundy. What the tasting left me pondering, though, was not how great ‘05 was, but rather how compelling the two older bottles we tasted (’95 and ’99) were. We kicked off with two wines from Domaine Collotte both ’06s, a rainy year in Burgundy that left growers with lots of undesirable botrytis and the need for multiple “tries” to select for decent grapes. Happily, I found none of the weedy herbaceousness that typified my experience with ’04s, the last “green” vintage in Burgundy. (Incidentally, critics enjoy characterizing these vintages as “true winemaker’s vintages,” code for vintages that are challenging for the vigneron.) I liked the Collotte wines, one from Marsannay, the other from Fixin. The Marsannay was a bit more oomphy, rustic, and well-knit, its raspberry fruit, sumac, and acidity making me salivate and want food. It’s a good thing we discovered last weekend that the tang of Bûcheron pairs nicely with light, village level Burgs. The Fixin was insipidly pretty; it reminded me that my favorite thing about this appellation is its name, which is almost as fun to say in a southern accent as “Corn-ass.” Before I get to the ‘05s, I should mention the fairly forgettable Bertagna Chambolle ’06, which was oaky from up to 45% new wood. Bertagna is owned by the same family as Von Kesselstat, a famous Mosel estate. I’ve never really liked the Bertagna wines; this one reminded me of popcorn and violets initially. The finish was woody and, in spite of female solidarity, I wanted to tell the chick that makes the wine at Bertagna to go back to Germany where new wood is less of a temptation. The three stunning ‘05s were as follows: Lambrays Morey “Les Loups,” Chézeax Clos de Vougeot (Grand Cru factoid: only 1% of all Burgundy produced is Grand Cru!) and Hubert Lignier Nuits Saint Georges “Les Didiers.” I wish I could say I had a favorite but the truth is I liked them all in the way I like good-natured toddlers whom I can tell will mature into much cooler adults. Each had lots of aromatic complexity, the Chézeaux being my favorite in that it abounded with brambly, feminine Pinot notes. The Lambrays and the Lignier both had slightly more funk, which, in general, I’m a fan of but in these cases didn’t steal my heart. When the Lignier reached my glass, what I found most intriguing was the story of Hubert and his son, Romaine, who died suddenly before completion of the ‘05s leaving Hubert with wine to make as well as a huge legal battle to fight over vineyards against Romaine’s ditsy, blond American widow, who has since become the scourge of the village. What these wines had in common was a certain pulpy sleekness, which I attributed to their youth and the glory of the vintage. Toward the end of the line-up was a 2005 Dugat-Py “Coeur de Roy,” which, in spite of the vineyard’s status as a “lieu-dit” rather than a Premier Cru, showed the most dark hued depth and extraction. A “lieu-dit” is a super vineyard site that hasn’t been elevated to the status of Premier Cru. Dugat-Py’s parcel is blessed with vines well over 60 years old, which explains the intense blackberry color of the wine. I had a quasi-Proustian experience with this Dugat. Its sauvage, earthy notes, its barely wood-kissed aromas of forest reminded me of wandering the Adirondack paths by the old girl-scout camp where my family spent its summers. On the palate, there was such a quality of black raspberry and seed tannin, that I was genuinely recalled to my childhood Adirondack berry picking. Back to the present: Unfortunately at this point my Astor notes end, before reaching the crux of the tasting, the ’95 and ’99 we tasted. I recall the impression the older wines left, though, after tasting ‘06s and ‘05s: that of mature, beautiful women. Less facile, more subtle, less “pretty” than the young wines, the older wines were more complex and layered, lines around the corners of the eyes and mouth deepening the beauty of the woman. Consciously or sub, I’ve sought out opportunities to drink Burgundy over the past few weeks, beginning with 2000 Bitouzet-Prieur Volnay “Les Aussy.” 2000 is a bit before my time, but my understanding of the vintage is that it was overshadowed by the vintages that bracketed it: ’99 and ’01. 2000 yielded early maturing wines, quaffable wines, wines my co-worker, JBT, calls “gouleyant” (rough translation: “slurpable”). While I didn’t exactly want to slurp this wine, it was perfectly ready to go, the tannins receded, the nose offering dusty-fine dark and red fruits, the palate savory and broad. The style of winemaking at Bitouzet is very traditional; the family has many parcels, most of them in Volnay and I’ve also had delicious bottles of ’98, ’99, ’01, and ’02 from this Domaine. The wines leave the impression of rusticity rather than polish, which I like. My good friend, Zach, made duck for a small group. The wine, though not the most profound Burgundy to cross my lips, was dreamily ready to drink, a feature that can eclipse vineyard, producer, and vintage, all. Next came 2004 Gaunoux Pommard “les Rugiens.” This is an old man’s Burgundy, from a village known for muscular Pinot Noir, the vineyard marked by its iron rich red soil. I happened to acquire two bottles of this wine from a kind Rosenthal rep, who knows my fondness for the 2004 vintage in Burgundy, one that is not praised. I cut my Burgundy teeth on the 2004 vintage, however, and I’ve come to appreciate the vegetal edge that marks many of the wines, the result of ladybug infestations in the vineyards. In general, the Cotes-de-Beaune suffered more in this regard than the Cotes-de-Nuits, but there are always exceptions, such as this wine, which shows barely a hint of “’04-itis.” The first bottle of ’04 Rugiens I drank showed more of the irony side of this vineyard, an intensely feral note to the nose carrying through to the palate, making the wine seem more about blood than about fruit. This was fine, but the second bottle was better and totally differently with layers of sweet, floral, red Pinot fruit: raspberry, ripe tangy cherry. As compelling as the aromas were, it was the texture of the wine that slayed me: absolutely silken, as velvety as rose petals, the finish broad and mouth-wateringly acidic. My only complaint about this bottle, and it’s a niggling complaint because we drank the shit out of the wine, was that it was ever so slightly hot at 13.5% alcohol. Which brings me to 2004 Comte-Lafon Monthelie-les-Duresses, consumed on the same night as the second Rugiens. Dominique Lafon is primarily known for his white wines, but the reds are highly thought of and this was my first. By Burgundian standards, Comte-Lafon’s history is not long, dating back to the early 20th Century when Jules Lafon was mayor of Meursault. Lafon is renowned for having started the famed dinner (if one could even call it “dinner” when “bacchanalian feast of epic proportions” is more accurate): “La Paulée de Meursault.” The current vigneron and grandson of Jules, Dominique Lafon, is viewed as one of the demi-gods - if not one of the gods - of Burgundy winemaking. ’04 Monthelie-les-Duresses, though darker in character with licorice and blackberry, was lither on the palate with less alcohol and a more delicate structure. Its tones were somehow cooler, sleeker, yet with as much mouth-watering resonance as the Pommard. Astonishingly, neither wine emerged a winner. Both were fantastic and the one in my glass was my favorite... until the other was… I kept revisiting one and then the other, trying to decide if one was “showing” better… to no avail. Drinking delicious Burgundy invariably brings a few questions to the forefront of my mind: why do critics equate Great Vintages with long-lived wine? ’02, ’05, and ’09, Great Vintages of the past decade yielded wines of such impressive structure that they are/will be shut down and undrinkable for years to come, while “lesser” vintages like ’00 and ’04 yielded earlier maturing wines that are a blessing when you have a duck breast in front of you and your ‘05s are still babies… Shouldn’t we be equally thankful for age-worthy vintages and for earlier-maturing vintages? Isn’t it part of the beauty of this region that there is vintage variation, which is reflected with such transparency in a good producer’s wines? After all, as much as I try to force myself to want Burgundies that can age for forty years, what I really want is a wine that is “gouleyant.” Is that so wrong?? -msb

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi,
You make some interesting points in your last paragraph. There is a real distinction between the so-called "great" vintages and the lesser years, but the line is more blurry today than it was even a decade ago. The way I view it, the two types of wines are for different uses. Burgundy that can last 10, 20, 30, even 40 years can develop remarkable secondary flavours and (especially) aromas that are unique in the wine world. But I wouldn't try to drink the wine with any food (or any food I would like to eat). For me, they are much too delicate and fragile. In contrast, the "lesser" vintages produce average bottles that are often brilliant at the table: light, fragrant, fruity, and as you write, "gouleyant". It brings a different dimension to the pleasure of Burgundy. I also find that these wines are becoming a little bit harder to find over the years, especially with in lower price range. In some very light years, I drink a few suspiciously full-bodied bottles. This seems to occur more often now than before, though over the years, I have had one or two very strange tasting merchant-bottled Burgundies from England from the 1950's, drunk when they were 30-40 years old. Adulteration was rife then, maybe it continues today. Perhaps the word "gouleyant" offers an explanation. This is one of those hard to translate words. It means flowing, easy to drink, gulpable, lively, and it is most often applied to Beaujolais. In the French wine press, whenever I see the word applied to Burgundy or Bordeaux, it is almost always has a derogatory meaning: a "gouleyant" Burgundy is a defective Burgundy. Perhaps winemakers are reading between the lines and using a few laboratory tricks in off-vintages to give their wines a boost. The problem with this is, of course, that if they do it in weaker years, they will have to do it in the "great" vintages also (Andrew Barr points this out in his book "Wine Snobbery"). Some winemakers are walking down a dangerous path. For the rest, good, "gouleyant" wines from weaker vintages are something to treasure.

Hi Henry - I am sorry it has taken me so long to reply to your comment. I had issues with my spam filter, which made wading through the spam comments a daunting task that I wasn't doing very often. I was thrilled to find your very real and insightful comment amongst the adds for boots, hiking equipment, rolex watches, and website design help. Your point that truly mature Burgundy from superior vineyards - only possible in great vintages - offers a unique expression of terroir is a really good one. Unfortunately I only very rarely get to drink wines of this caliber. I probably should have done more investigation into the use of "gouleyant" in the French wine press before using it in this post. I think what I was trying to get at was not that the 2000 Bitouzet-Prieur was a facile, fruity wine (which it was not), but rather that there's a very real use for early maturing Burgundies with a softer structure. I really like lighter Burgundies from '06, '07, and '08, wines that have good acid and a firm mineral core, especially in the case of 2008s... It's precisely this sort of vintage transparency that draws a lot of people to Burgundy, I think. Good producer's wines will taste different every year because the growers don't use winery tricks. As an aside, I was really depressed to hear my co-worker, JBT, tell me that Jean-Marie Fourrier's wines taste like Oregon Pinots in 2009. I don't believe it; that would just be too sad. Anyway - thank you again for the comment.

item.title: Champagne Love in Several Parts: Part 1: Icy Chalk.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Why do we love Champagne? Or, I should say, “why do I love Champagne?” Not all wine folks get the intense Champagne jones, the lusty need for chalky bubbles and borderline painful acidity that I do. The topic of Champagne Love arises with relative frequency at my workplace, where there’s a faction that believes Champagne is overpriced, over-sulfured, over-dosaged, and generally spoofulated; these co-workers aren’t wrong! There is enough heavily manipulated Champagne in the world to intoxicate the population of a small nation, I reckon. In response to allegations of heavy manipulation, I say: “it’s our job to find the wines that speak of the land louder than they speak of the hand of man.” But what about The Art of Blending, often sited as essential to Champagne (usually by reps from big Champagne houses)? Admittedly blending is important, but at the end of the day, good wine comes from good grapes farmed on healthy soil. Period. In response to complaints about lofty prices, I say “agreed; it’s hard to justify the price of Selosse ($160-ish/bottle), when one could purchase roughly eight (!!) bottles of François Pinon Vouvray Brut for the same amount of money.” I distinctly remember engaging in this very conversation with a good friend who works in the wine trade. My point - namely that if you want Champagne, no other sparkling wine will do - fell on deaf ears. I felt the way I feel when I argue with my older cousin, who believes (for example) that women wear jogging clothes to show off their bodies. Having never jogged a day in his life, it doesn’t occur to him that women wear these clothes because they are comfortable to jog in. This digression is merely meant to illustrate that if you’re not a Champagne lover, you may not understand choosing to spend money on Champagne; if you’re not a jogger, you may not get a jogger’s outfit choices. We spend the extra bucks on Champagne because we want Champagne. It’s not rational, then again on some level neither is jogging… In January, I had the good fortune to travel to France courtesy of the lovely people at LDM. We stayed a night in Paris then made our way north to Chablis, where we tasted with Alice and Olivier de Moor, some of the finest growers in Chablis. After touring the vines, we headed for their tasting room, where we met Olivier Horiot of Ricey in the Côtes de Bars. I had never heard of Ricey, an appellation for kimmeridgean born, pink sparkling wine. Horiot’s wines didn’t resemble the Rosé Champagnes with which I was familiar. Accustomed to chiseled, sometimes fruity, sometimes austere, elegant bubbles, occasionally deep and vinous, but often light and pretty in color and character, this rustic, smoky, broad, practically tannic stuff in my glass was a different beast entirely. I liked it. Where I was used to encountering some degree of polish and artifice, here was honestly. The next morning we drove the short distance from Chablis to the Côtes de Blancs; our first stop was at Domaine Ulysses Collin. My outstanding memories of this Domaine are as follows: 1) it was incredibly cold; 2) the wines were arresting. Long underwear, fur-lined boots, knee-length down jacket, sweater, scarf, and gloves were not enough to keep me warm. I could have worn my grandma-knit hat too, but I had leant it to a Floridian wine distributor with a shaved head; his need was greater than mine. The courtyard was cold, but the cellar was colder; chill traveled up through my boots into my very core. We stood, blowing warm breath into our balled up hands while Olivier Collin, grandson (??) of Ulysses, showed us a special square press he prefers to the commonly used pneumatic press. I began to wonder if everyone we met would be named Olivier. By the time we moved to Collin’s tasting room, cold had become the only sensation of which I was aware. Consistent with my memory, the wines were bracing, austere, and vinous, their high acidity and lack of residual sugar like a bold and true proclamation to my palate. Collin uses barrels, old for the first pressed juice, new for the second. Both alcoholic and malolactic fermentations take place in barrel, but malo doesn’t happen every year. I shuddered to think what the wines are like in a non-malo vintage. Collin farms three parcels: “Pérrières,” “Roises,” and “Maillons”; we tasted wines from all three in Collin’s broad, low ceilinged (marginally warmer than the cellar) tasting room. “Pérrières” is an especially chalky site. He uses a pneumatic press for this wine and in both the 2005 and the 2007, the fruit was cheesy like an old Chablis. Collin added 1.7 grams of dosage to the 2005. I asked Olivier about the vintage, a well-regarded one in many parts of France. He replied that the incredible concentration of ’04 had left the vines sapped in ’05, a somewhat lackluster, rot-afflicted vintage in Champagne. 2007 “Pérrières” had not yet been disgorged and was lemon zesty with graphite minerality. The wines showed their oak and were - in many ways – consistent with the single varietal, vineyard site specific, bone dry Champagnes we know from Vouette et Sorbé, Marie-Courtin, or Cédric Bouchard… Actually Bouchard doesn’t use oak, so perhaps he’s a poor analogue for Collin. This is the new, anti-assemblage, anti-dosage, face of Champagne. Yet Collin’s wine continued to strike me as more extreme – crazier - than many in this style. Where Bouchard’s wines show lacy, prettiness, Collin’s show angularity and power. Maybe it’s a wood thing… but I digress. “Les Roises” is a parcel of 60-year-old Chardonnay vines in Congy. The berries are very small; the word for this in French is “millerandage.” All chalky mineral, the wine had no fruit; I mean none. Acidity encompassed my palate; the wine had no dosage at all, though Collin admitted that he might add some. He varies his dosing from year to year, wine to wine. Next came “Maillons” from 40-year-old, east facing Pinot Noir vines. Here things began to look up for my poor palate, the whole morning crying out for a café au lait and a good croissant. “Maillons” had the same chalky underpinning as “Roises” but with layers of red fruit, crabapple, salty, cheesy funk, even pink grapefruit. The color was ever so slightly pink and the wine was, like “Roises,” marked by uncompromising, almost sadistic acidity. I should say something about the man. Young, not much older than me, he struck me as slightly insane; he had those bulging, gleaming eyes that denote winemaker insanity. At this point, in spite of the fact that I recognized the superiority of the wines, I started to despair that I’d never understand them and that I couldn’t love them regardless of my intellectual appreciation. Most of the examples of Collin I’d had in the US were flawed: oxidized or not bubbly or otherwise strange and unappealing. This saddened me. The material was clearly there; the guy works very hard in the vineyard and champions expression of terroir. He ferments using all indigenous yeast – uncommon in Champagne – and his fermentations can take an incredibly long time – months on end! Why were his wines so impenetrable, so reluctant to offer the drinker anything but austerity, icy white chalk and sadistic acid? Then, a faint glimmer of comprehension, before the germination of an actual idea: what I was tasting was the terroir of this cold, hard, windy place with its frigid cellars and barren landscape. Did this mean that what I thus far knew of Champagne was dosage, blending, and obfuscation? Perhaps… Things became clearer when we went to lunch with Olivier. Wines that had seemed mean in his tasting room had become still, rich, nuanced, and extremely satisfying. We sat at a long table and consumed a classically French salad decorated with eggs and lardons, out of season tomatoes and bitter greens. Bubbles stripped away, the wines were partners for our meal as well as for conversation over lunch as we formed little enclaves at the table. Next came a course of river fish drenched in cream sauce on a bed of forgettable rice. The vaguely oxidative character of the wines matched the rice, while acidity sliced through cream sauce. The meal was mediocre, but the wines were not. Our large party filled the room with warm and jovial laughter, chill forgotten until we’d collected our coats to move on to the next appointment.

item.title: Part 2: Vinosity
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I can’t speak for the landscape of Champagne during the summer months, but driving around during the winter is depressing. There are few healthy vineyards; most we saw were desolate and brown with no green at all between the vines to indicate biodiversity. It’s hard to be organic in Champagne due to the humidity of the region, which makes most grape growers turn to anti-fungal agents. The view from the car window en route to Cauroy-lès-Hermonville, in the very north of Champagne, alternated between frigid, lifeless vineyards, and sad, highway-side trees, giant cotton balls of mistletoe impaled on them, mistletoe slowly sapping the tree’s life. We arrived chez Francis Boulard as the pale gray daytime sky became the darker gray evening sky; it was about 4:30 pm. I have a longstanding fondness for the wines of Domaine Raymond Boulard, named after Francis’ father (Francis began making the wines at his father’s estate in the '70s) Recently Domaine Raymond Boulard was divided and Francis set out on his own with the help of his daughter. Francis has only a few hectares spread between the Vallée de la Marne, Mailly, and the Massif de Saint Thierry. The vineyards closest to the winery - including the fabulous “Rachais” vineyard – are in the Massif de Saint Thierry. Raymond has been farming his Saint Thierry vineyards organically since 2007 and plans to convert his Marne and Mailly vineyards. He toys with biodynamism, always picking on a fruit day, perhaps more out of superstition than actual belief.  He makes a pied de cuve, which he keeps in case fermentations do not begin spontaneously. These are very British Champagnes, raised entirely in wood, the “Petraea,” a multi-vintage Champagne comprising vintages going back to ’97. In contrast to Collin’s wines, which only go through malolactic fermentation when it happens naturally, Boulard’s wines always go through malo, even if it means he has to warm the cellar to spark the process. The wines have a rich, staid, mellow feel to them. Boulard is older than Collin, more of a traditionalist, less of a trailblazer, salt of the earth. Reserved, rotund and a bit gnome-like, it took him an hour to warm to our large, boisterous group. First we tasted wines from “Les Murgiers,” Boulard’s vineyard in Vallée de la Marne. This wine is 70% Meunier and 30% Noir, a Blanc de Noirs, from 25-year-old, selection massale vines grown on clay and chalk soil. Boulard showed us two versions of this wine: one dosed with 5 grams, the other un-dosed. The dosed wine was rich, vinous, and nutty, offering some of the savory, mushroom-y notes I associate with Pinot Meunier. It was a generous wine that felt both luxurious and complex. The non-dose wine was steelier aromatically, the honey and nut tones of the dosed wine having been replaced by something greener, more earth-driven. Even the non-dosé “Murgiers” was less austere than Collin’s wines had been, with a fine, appealing mousse. My notes indicate that I preferred the dosed wine. Who knows if that would be true now? I find that my taste in Champagne has grown drier and drier. On the other hand, different wines find balance with different amounts of dosage… on none at all. Next came Boulard’s Grand Cru Mailly from clay and limestone soil, and, again, we tasted a dosed version and an un-dosed version. From the limestone heavy eastern part of the Marne, both iterations of this wine were extremely minerally, light and laser-like in spite of their high percentage of Pinot Noir (90%), and Boulard’s heavy wood regime. In the case of Mailly, I preferred the un-dosed wine, which was ripe, toasty, focused, and well-balanced. There’s an expletive in my notes, which means either that I loved the wine, or that I had stopped spitting… or both. Here I began to speculate that there’s a connection between superior terroir and the ability to make good bone dry Champagne. Mailly is a Grand Cru; maybe the grapes are riper, more flavorful than the ones from “Murgiers,” and better able to produce a balanced wine in an extra dry style. One day I’ll ask Peter Liem about this… At last the moment I’d been waiting for: “Petraea” and “Rachais.” “Petraea” is named for the kind of oak tree that yields the barrels, Francis told us. He uses 205 liter barrels, which are the traditional size in Champagne, slightly smaller than the typical Burgundy barrel. The wine is 60% Pinot Noir with 20% Chardonnay and 20% Meunier. The oldest vintage in this particular version of the wine is ’97 and the wine is bottled at five atmospheres, rendering a more delicate mousse. This choice to bottle with less pressure is yet another topic I’ll need to pester Peter with if I have the chance. I believe the idea is that Champagne bottled with less pressure is more wine-like; with less bubble comes more vinosity.  “Petraea” was super, if oddly marked by wood, extra dry but balanced as such. “Rachais,” a name derived from “Rachet,” the word for a new shoot that grows in after an old one has been cut, is a lieu-dit close to Boulard’s winery. The vineyard is planted to old vine Chardonnay and makes a wonderfully expressive, complex, long wine. At this point I should tip my hat to Brooklynguy, who told me about the wine years ago and convinced me to buy it for the shelf at Astor. I think the wine can age, with its old vines and time in barrel. I’d like to taste an older one some day… Unfortunately we didn’t get much of a chance to see how Raymond’s wines complemented a meal, but we did drink a horrible bottle of Rosé de Ricey at a nearby restaurant, which confirmed for us that Olivier Horiot’s wines are exceptional examples of this appellation.

item.title: Puffen-Yay!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: One of the perks of the wine business is being invited to dinner to taste an array of fun wines. These events have many forms, but essentially all are variations on a theme: mild intoxication over delicious food enjoyed with other people in or connected to the business. There are two things that distinguish a “wine dinner” from a dinner at which wine is served because it’s a better beverage with food than, say, Dr. Pepper, tequila, or Earl Grey tea. The first is the number of different bottles tasted over the course of the meal. While many of my friends have a somewhat perverse affection for Big Bottles (“I swear, Sophie, wines taste different out of magnum”), in actuality, half bottles make more sense for wine people because they allow us to taste more kinds of different wines. (I’m mostly joking, here, half bottles don’t show up at wine functions save for the odd sweet or fortified bottle.) The second variable is, of course, the number of “wine people” at the table, which heavily influences the conversation. A group comprised of only “wine people” means you’ll talk about wine: winemakers, schnooks, vintages, obscure grape varieties, old bottles, other wine dinners, pairings, etc. almost the entire time, perhaps with a departure or two into the realm of music, relationships, or other trivialities of life. If there are a few non-wine people at the table, attempts will be made to find topics of general interest, but the conversation will inevitably veer back to the fascinating topic of wine. If you’re a non-wine person who ends up at a full-on Wine Dinner, I’m sorry for you! You must be bored! I promise to try harder next time to stick to topics of general interest! As I said in my write-up of dinner with JBT, I’m more likely to accept an invitation to dinner if it’s at someone’s home. I enjoy cooking and being cooked for. There’s a level of intimacy possible at a home that isn’t possible at restaurants, where there’s the constant interruption of the sycophant waiter, the unhappy baby at a neighboring table, the couple drinking Cabernet with their oysters (to be fair, in New York, the Cabernet-oyster pairing is rare), the couple having Champagne and chocolate cake (whence the notion that a dry, high-acidity beverage goes well with desert?).  Also – in a private setting, you can open as many bottles as you please without having to worry about a corkage fee, or ordering off the wine list as a concession to the restaurant because you’ve imported so many of your own bottles. Complicated, eh? I was delighted to accept a recent invitation to Astoria to dine at the apartment of our Polaner sales person, Mike. Mike belongs to the upper-most echelon of schnooks; he’s constantly on top of his game, he never comes to the wine store without an appointment and, perhaps most importantly, he’s not a soldier for his company. He drinks outside the portfolio he represents and is a consummate professional regardless of the specifics of his job.  On the night in question, Mike had invited me, a buyer at an important store in Brooklyn, and a portfolio manager for another company, to a dinner featuring Coq au Vin Jaune aux morilles and Jura wine. With the weather cooling down and the holidays stampeding toward us, it was bound to be a good time. In contrast to when I began this wine charade six years ago, there are now many Jura wines on the market. In 2005, there were three: Overnoy, Montbourgeau, and Puffeney, the so-called “Pope of the Arbois.” Now options are numerous. Conscientious buyers dot their shelves and wine lists with cool bottles from this obscure, eastern French wine region. Importers scramble to find their own Jura Domaine to represent so as not to have an incomplete portfolio or be bested by a competitor for a placement. Just a few years ago, only Joe Dressner and Neal Rosenthal risked importing these difficult to sell and not inexpensive wines. With their rise in popularity and availability, the classics - Montbourgeau and Puffeney  (I don’t include Overnoy/Houillon because the wines have become so expensive and rare)– are up against some competition. And this gives rise to the following train of thought “well, we loved them when they were the only ones, but are they the best or only the originals?” Had you asked me in April, I would have said “originals but not best.” Two bad experiences with The Pope’s wines, one with a disjointed, almost candied bottle of Puffeney Trousseau “les Berangères” and one with a mousey bottle of Puffeney Savagnin had tarnished my image of this man’s wines. Let me back up and say that I have a deep fondness for Jacques Puffeney. To this day, Puffeney made the best bottle of 2003 white wine I have ever tasted: Melon-Queue-Rouge. His old vine Trousseau from Montigny-lès-Arsures, adjacent to Arbois and home of the Trousseau variety, has been swoon-worthy in many vintages. I went to visit Puffeney several summers ago. My companion and I weaved the few kilometers from Pupillin to Montigny and climbed to the top of a hill and the end of the tiny village. With no little door plaque to be found indicating Puffeney’s Domaine , I rolled down the window of the car and appealed to a ninety year old woman leaning out of an upstairs window “on cherche la maison du Jacques Puffeney,” which lead to a further ascent and finally The Pope’s residence, a very old stone house. We had a magical tasting with Jacques, a round and petite little man with bright eyes who practically had to stand on tiptoe to kiss my cheek, a cheek I didn’t wash for days as though to preserve the memory of my visit. Without rehashing our tasting, from which I don’t have notes only memories, I’ll conjecture that what makes the man’s wines stand out is their austerity and their unmistakable Jurassian tang. This is hard to put in words; it’s the high-toned earthiness, minerality, and ripping acidity of the region. I can’t speak for all, but when I seek out Jura wine, this is what I want to taste and smell, not carbonic maceration (no offense to the natural Jura producers whose wines I also like very much), not new Burgundy barrels or Chardonnay raised in stainless steel. The region yields wines in a range of acceptable styles, but it’s the wines that take the drinker immediately to the cool, green hills and musty cellars of the place, itself, that are – not necessarily the most delicious – but the most vivid. It transpired rather coincidentally that dinner at Mike’s was a marvelous opportunity to drink lots of Puffeney’s wines and to remember what it is we are drawn to about them. There were two non-Puffeney bottles at dinner, both brought by me. The first was Crémant from Domaine le Chais de Vieux Bourg, a Pinot Noir based, bone-dry, Champagne-mimicking Crémant from Bavarian winemaker Ludwig Bindernagel. It was delicious with Comté, walnuts, and conversation (mostly about wine). Once we’d polished off the bubbles and all members of the party had arrived, we moved to red wine. Justin, the most excellent wine buyer at Uva in Williamsburg, had brought a bottle of 2005 Puffeney Vieilles Vignes. This is a wine that The Pope doesn’t make any longer because he had to uproot and replant the vineyard; the yields were too low to do otherwise. The wine is a field blend of Poulsard, Trousseau, and Pinot Noir, all co-planted, harvested, and fermented. If you ask Jean-Francois Bourdy of Arlay, he will tell you that this is the traditional style of red wine of the region and, surprisingly, the bottle we drank reminded me more of Bourdy’s Côtes du Jura Rouge than of other Puffeney reds. It was initially somewhat closed, but opened up quickly to reveal earthy tones and brambly fruits. What surprised us was the structure. The wine was down-right tannic, a quality we attributed to the vintage though there could have been many explanations. Mike had fixed a tasty first course of sausages with potatoes and sautéed bitter greens. There's no need to wax poetically about the virtues of this pairing: sausage and bitter greens with structured, slightly rustic yet very expressive Jura red wine. They were great together, especially as the wine began to soften and become more aromatically pretty. Next came a double header of ’05 Puffeney Savagnin and ’07 Puffeney Cuvée Sacha. Sacha, a wine I was introduced to by Elizabeth Harcourt - former sommelière at Corton - as an ideal cheese partner, is a favorite of mine. The wine is a blend of Savagnin and Chardonnay that has some voile-y, nutty character but is, for the most part, pure and clean with rich, yellow fruit character, and mouth-watering acid. This wine is a a very good starting point from which to delve further into the sous-voile white wines for which the region is known. The wine is nice with cheese but was even nicer with the Coq au Vin Jaune Mike had made, an adapted recipe that allowed him to prepare the dish in a relatively short period of time and without using an entire bottle of Vin Jaune at around $70 a pop. By this point, we also had Savagnin in our glasses, a wine that truly complements Coq au Vin Jaune aux Morilles.  I like Puffeney’s Savagnin with its intense aroma of walnut skin and mustard seed and its long, sherry-ish finish, but I preferred the ease of the Sacha, perhaps a less complex wine, also a more subtle one. We swirled, sipped, and ate, occasionally veering from the subject of wine… but infrequently. We finished with a duo of sweet wines. I had brought 2007 "L'Ivresse de Noë" from Philippe Bornard, Savagnin harvested in November and fermented with some residual sugar remaining. The wine is lightly sweet, robust in alcohol, and highly acidulous. Dear to my heart, I first tasted this wine several years ago, the day before my visit to Puffeney. Bornard, a flirtatiously impish little man, characterized "L'Ivresse" as a wine 'to drink in bed...' I assume the implication was 'not alone...' I fell in love with the wine, begged the importer to bring some to the U.S. for me, and about a year later cases of adorable fox labeled 500ml bottles of late harvest Savagnin arrived. After a bit of bottle age, the wine had turned a pale burnished golden and was honeyed and almost Chenin-like in character. Justin's comment, 'this wine tastes expensive,' was at once mystifying (what - besides spoof - makes a wine taste 'expensive'?) and spot on. Though the wine isn't particularly pricy, it carries with it a sense of hedonism that Bornard apparently found sexy and Justin found 'expensive.' It's a fun bottle and well worth a try... out of bed, even! We closed the evening with Puffeney Vin de Paille. Call me a glutton, but I have no problem both beginning and ending a meal with cheese - and once the Comté and walnuts were in front of me again, this time with thickly sweet, straw-matt-dried desert wine in my glass, I was more than content. Drinking Vin de Paille is a treat. Unlike Bornard's late harvest Savagnin, Vin de Paille is actually prohibitively expensive, but at the end of a meal, a small glass of this magic potion-like elixir can be absolutely perfect. It was a fun evening, on a wine level, on a wine conversation level, and on a food level. It was also a super opportunity to contemplate The Pope's wines and to say... not Puffeney, but Puffen-Yay!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I know what you mean about neophytes at a wine geek dinner! It can be such an effort to make standard small talk when surrounded by the oenophile species. I do feel bad, like you, that small talk escapes me when in the presence of 'the tribe'.

item.title: Dix-Huit Huitres! (R: PG-13)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: There was a time when I did not like raw oysters. There was a time when I did not like any oysters, but fried ones grew on me at a younger age than raw ones. I remember my dad eating oysters on the half shell when I was a kid; he would put the same horseradish, ketchup, lemon juice, and Tabasco concoction on them that he put on shrimp. The fact that I found this gross meant more oysters for him! The textures and flavors of raw oysters are extremely “adult,” in the same category as radicchio, dandelion greens, Chinon, and Vin Jaune. Now I love all of the aforementioned, but I especially love oysters. Oysters have an inherent sexiness that I comprehended well before I grew to like the food. One only has to watch the famous dining scene in ‘Tom Jones’ to appreciate the aphrodisiac properties of the oyster. Along with sexiness, there’s an appealing simplicity: the food is presented au naturel; the only preparation is the cracking open of the shell. There’s complexity to a good oyster, a balance of creaminess and brininess to consider. With the oyster, we have a chance to ponder the complexity – the profundity - of an incredibly simple thing; if it makes us feel sexy at the same time, all the better! Wine folks enjoy oysters because of their overt minerality, which is especially complementary to two types of wine: Muscadet and Champagne. I still fondly recall the opening party for Astor Center at which a group of us loitered by the oyster table sucking down one after another, pausing every few minutes to refill our glasses of Vilmart. Even more likely to bring a smile to my face is the memory of being at Marc Ollivier’s house tasting young vintages of Muscadet aside a vast array of freshly shucked oysters. While in the past few years I have eaten oysters with great abandon, I know essentially nothing about them. Recently an opportunity to learn presented itself: a generous customer invited me join him, his wife, and their good friend, for an oyster tasting, the objective of which was to find not only wine harmonies but food harmonies as well. This was not your average Tuesday evening invitation. I accepted without hesitation. It was an added bonus that this lovely, friendly couple inhabit a realm that is far different from my own rough and tumble existence as an east Williamsburg dwelling, natural wine swilling, wine store manager. He’s a French literature professor; she’s a fashion designer; they live in a beautiful TriBeCa loft filled with classical music, unique paintings, sweet daughters, and un-translated copies of Diderot that they can both read! What a calm, civilized, and sophisticated place. We began the evening with a bottle of Marie-Courtin Résonance. Briefly: the winemaker at Marie-Courtin is a woman named Dominique Moreau. Her vineyards are mostly planted to Pinot Noir and are in the Côtes des Bars in southern Champagne. The Côtes des Bars is known for its kimmeridgean soil, which gives the wines a different minerality than the chalky minerality of Côtes des Blancs Champagnes, for example. This is a warm(er) part of the region that historically supplied the more northerly, more famous Champagne villages with Pinot Noir grapes. The Côtes des Bars is very popular right now for a category we refer to as “hipster” Champagne: single vintage, single cépage, single vineyard Champagne made with a focus on meticulous vineyard work rather than elaborate cellar work or blending. There are no Grand Crus in the Côtes des Bars. If Ambonnay is the Upper East Side and Vertus the West Village, the Côtes des Bars is Bushwick. (This is not really a geographic analogy, more of a whimsical, prestige and reputation-based analogy. Though the Côtes des Bars is becoming increasingly prestigious due to the new wave of Champagne growers there, it doesn’t have the cache of the northern sub regions of Champagne.) Moreau’s wines – true to the hipster Champagne style – are given no dosage. Raised in stainless steel, the wines are very… very… very dry.  Angular in the best possible way, I think it’s safe to say this wine woke us (and our palates) up and prepared us for what was to come. All in all we tasted 18 types of oyster (this is more fun to say in French: dix huit huitres!), but I’ll only describe the ones that stood out for what they taught us about food and wine harmony. The first round of oysters was from Lobster Place in Chelsea Market, widely considered the best source of seafood in the city. With the very briny Wiley Points from Maine, we learned that good balsamic vinegar is not enough to mediate the salt of such an oyster. Bring on the lemon! We moved on from the palate cleansing Marie-Courtin to a bottle of Selosse “Substance.” Now, the wine world is full of people dying to brag about the Selosse they drank. I am not one of those people. However, this wine was remarkable both in its flavors and in its complete dissimilarity to any other Champagne. Anselme Selosse, long-time champion of organic viticulture and high fruit quality as the basis for great Champagne, is masterful at incorporating oxygen into his winemaking. His Domaine is located in the Côtes des Blancs; thus he is working with Chardonnay. He uses mostly old barrels in the winery and “Substance” is aged in Solera as well as in bottle before release. Brief scrutiny of the label revealed that the wine was disgorged in 2008. I’m sure a little research could turn up the various vintages in the wine, but I am more inclined to its poetry than its prose. Amber colored - the most amber colored Champagne one could imagine - it was quite fabulous, really, with nutty tones and dried fruits, a deep sense of ripeness in spite of its very low dosage. Rich and minerally with tiny bubbles that seemed perfectly integrated into the weighty texture of the wine, I felt very lucky to be consuming such a wine.  Which oyster was perfectly at home with Selosse? The king of all west coast oysters: the Canadian Beau Soleil.  I believe at one point these perfectly plump, flavorful, buttery guys were treated with melted truffle butter, which I liked. But honestly, “Substance” was the best dressing the Beau Soleil could have received. We moved on to east coast oysters. My host explained that he likes them best with Muscadet and, sure enough, the sweet, grassy, cucumber-y fresh Barron Point from Washington state was very good with 2010 Clos des Briords from Marc Ollivier (out of magnum).  From an acid and mineral driven vintage in Muscadet, 2010 Briords, though a young wine, resonates with the kind of fennel and herb-tinged salinity one wants in a Muscadet. There was a lightness to this experience that proved a nice contrast to the explosion of flavor that had been Selosse and Beau Soleil. We tasted through a lineup of good but not super memorable west coasters from Lobster Place: the “totally blah” Quilcene, the simple Sister Point, and the ultra-melon-y Calm Cove, before we arrived at the king of all west coast oysters: the Kumamoto. I have read that Kumamotos are their own species. They certainly are distinct, possessed of an unbelievable creaminess that I honestly found revolting at first. There was much discussion at the table as to whether the excessive creaminess of this oyster was related to its mating cycle. (Apparently as they approach the time to mate they get creamier…?) Whatever the cause, this lactic quality was overwhelming. The suggestion was made to apply caviar, to try to balance creaminess with salt. (When in doubt, just go ahead and gild that lily.) This turned out to be a super idea, especially when Laherte Brut Tradition found its way into my glass. Laherte Frères, not a well-known Domaine, is rapidly becoming a favorite of mine. Comprising about 70 tiny parcels of vines amounting to ten hectares, the vineyards are worked by various family members who, in turn, “sell” the grapes to one another. Laherte Frères are forced to call themselves a “négociant” when they are clearly “grower” in spirit. There is nothing basic about their basic wine, which is predominantly Pinot Meunier. It turned out that the vinous and loose-bubbled quality of this Meunier based wine matched very well with the caviar topped Kumamoto. Teetering on the brink of both fineness and rusticity, the Laherte was powerful enough to stand up to the caviar, whilst adding a crunchy textural element that the oyster definitely needed. It was an earthy, earthy combo. The second round of oysters was mailed to New York by a San Francisco purveyor called “I Love Blue Sea.” We tasted the complex Marin Miyagi from California, the Washington State Hood Canal Bay, which was praised for its easy shuck-ability, the Kusshi, which was shrunken and shriveled but otherwise tasty, the Skookum, which was intolerably salty, and my personal favorite of the night, the Humboldt Kumamoto. What made this Kumamoto so different from the Lobster Place Kumamoto, who knows? Perhaps these Kumas were further from the mating season… Whatever the reason, this was the perfect oyster for me: medium creamy, sweet and briny with texture. I squeezed just a bit of lemon on mine with great results. The price to pay for this perfect Kumamoto, however, was that the bloody things were incredibly hard to shuck and, at the end of the day, this does make a difference; it’s a labor- intensive food, the oyster. With our San Francisco batch, we drank ’09 Cédric Bouchard “Inflorescence.” Back in the Côtes des Bars, this bottle comes from the hipster Champagne poster child. Making only single vintage, single cèpage, single terroir, bone-dry Champagne, Bouchard’s are some of the best, if not the best made in this style. That said, 2009, a warm year, is not my favorite vintage for this wine, which was such a stunning, if reticent, beauty in 2008. Technically this is not a vintage wine because it does not go through the élèvage required to be labeled as such. The wine sees no wood and is, in many ways, the opposite of the oxidative Selosse we drank earlier in the evening, though the two growers maintain similar commitments to organic viticulture.  What typifies “Inflorescence” for me is its purity, its soft bubbles (bottle under less pressure than most Champagne) and its aromatic quality of flowers, leaves, blue fruits. All Pinot Noir in its best incarnations, it’s a hauntingly delicious Champagne and 2009 is very good… just not as good as 2008. I should mention the types of food pairings we tried: oyster and salmon crudo (very good), oyster and pear (not my favorite; then again I often take issue with fruit and seafood combinations, a food trend I think should have fallen along the wayside at the end of the 1980s), oyster and foie gras (good but a bit overwhelming for the oyster), oyster and lime fruit, a kumquat sized, ovoid sack filled with crunchy, citrusy little balls (texturally at odds with oysters), oyster and ponzu (nice), and - finally – the most contentious pairings of the night: oyster with Brillat Savarin then oyster with chocolate. Following the lead of our hostess, I gladly opted out of the last two, which I’m told were challenging, though our host maintains hope for future harmony between oysters and chocolate. This was a fantastic experience and one that taught me to love these strange, slimy little mollusks all the more. Thank you, hostess, for having me. Thank you host, for shucking all those oysters, and thank you, friend, for bringing Selosse (as well as sharing your notes). -Sophie

item.title: How to add more uncomplicated fun to your life: wine at the movies.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: At the risk of discrediting myself as a Serious Wine Professional, I like to seek out frivolous occasions to enjoy wine, from chugging cold Tissot Trousseau from the bottle in front of a grill fire, to sipping Barral Faugères out of a cut open Badoit bottle in front of the Sacre Coeur. I believe that we wine pros often take ourselves too seriously; we take the conditions surrounding our wine experiences too seriously. Was the bottle treated properly, aged properly, decanted properly? Was the glassware the correct shape? Was the food pairing perfect? This is not to underrate the majesty of those transcendental moments, few and far between, when the wine has been open just the right amount of time, its flavors humming synergistic-ally with the dish in front of you. I recently enjoyed a ’74 F. Rinaldi Barolo under such ideal conditions, a mushroom risotto in front of me, the wine having been open for about five hours. This is a particular type of memorable wine encounter. Then there’s the lighthearted wine encounter, in which the conditions, the temperature, the glassware, the food pairing aren’t perfect, but you have uncomplicated fun drinking the wine.   I can’t quite recall the first time I brought wine into a movie theater. It’s definitely a young tradition, one that only dates back to my move to New York. The tradition began when I was working at Astor Wines and Spirits on 4th and Lafayette, just a few short blocks from two big theaters: Union Square and East Village Cinemas on 2nd Avenue and 12th Street. It didn’t occur to me to sneak wine into North Carolina theaters, perhaps because they are generally smaller, more intimate, less anonymous, and less crowded. Maybe I was less of a drunk then, more able to withstand a three hour long film without a glass of wine in my hand. Regardless of the catalyst for the onset of this tradition, I quickly realized that wine introduces an additional element of relaxation and enjoyment to the experience of a movie. Here are some tips for drinking wine at the movies.   1) Bubbly. If you’re like me (which 0bservation tells me few people actually are in this particular regard), you’ll have brought your own snacks to the theater: sandwiches, cheese, chips, but you won’t be enjoying a full-on meal, which means you’ll need something that’s good on its own. Leave the Bordeaux, the Grand Cru Burgundy (as if anyone would actually lug their Musigny to the movie theater), the Barolo, basically any complex, structured wine at home and opt for something bubbly (white wine and rosé are also fine choices, but bubbly is best). By the same token, that bone-dry, stainless steel raised Champagne you’ve been curious about is not the best choice. You’ll want something that’s relatively easy and, should you have forgotten to bring snacks, generous bubbly wines can prove remarkably well-suited to popcorn.   2) Open your bottle in advance. I first brought wine into the movies in 2008. The movie, ironically, was “Bottle Shock,” a fairly lowbrow flick about Bo Barrett, the history of Chateau Montelena, and the famous mid ‘70s tasting at which California wines beat French wines at a blind tasting featuring French judges. Without dwelling on the movie, which most people hated but I enjoyed for the sake of the banal entertainment it offered, I learned a valuable lesson: open your bottle ahead of time, especially if it’s sealed with a crown cap. My good friend, Curtis, from Montreal was in town for the weekend and we decided to celebrate his visit to New York as well as our epic morning run from Bushwick to the west village with a movie and a bottle of Rosé Cava from a forgettable producer in the Jorge Ordoñez portfolio. The lights dimmed and the previews began. How were we going to open the bottle without the celebratory pop of News Years Eve ringing out through the theater, disturbing our neighbors, and possibly arousing the attention of the theater attendants? I proposed to take the wine to the bathroom to open it. Curtis scoffed: “It’s a movie about wine! No one is going to care if we’re drinking wine; it’s appropriate. Besides other people probably are too.” After some additional dithering, I let Curtis open the wine; no one seemed to mind (at least no one turned around to give us the hairy eyeball and we didn't get thrown out), and we had a lovely time.   3) If you’re not averse to drinking something simple, which you shouldn’t be, really, because the movie is the focus, bring a screw cap wine or a tetra pack wine. Shortly after my experience with Curtis, I brought two bottles of Astor-exclusive cheap Prosecco to “James Bond: Quantum of Solace.” Screw caps made the bottles easy to open. The wine was, of course, forgettable; the movie, however, was fun and its faint, action-packed trashiness seemed a good match for the metallic, lightly sweet, heavily yeasted and sulfured Prosecco. I learned that if the movie is long, you’ll need more than one bottle of wine for two people. In the same era, I brought Yellow and Blue Malbec to “Milk” with Sean Penn. (Before you criticize my choice, please understand that this is an inoffensive wine that is environmentally friendly, that I was poorer at that time, that the wine was a sample from a supplier, and that the tetra pack meant my load was significantly lighter than it would have been if I’d brought a bottle. The same principle that makes tetras better than bottles for the environment makes them better for movie theaters as well.) It would seem to contradict point 1) to advocate Malbec at the movies given that Malbec is generally ponderous, heavy, and tannic, and I won’t repeat this experience, but theoretically if good wine came in tetras, a tetra would be a great option for the theater.   4) Avoid collapsible plastic cups. They do not work and you’ll wind up with wine on your clothes. I gave my set of Heidsick-Monopole camping cups numerous tries and was disappointed every time. Now I use jelly jars or mustard jars, which add weight to my bag, but are more fun to drink out of than flimsy plastic cups, which, I believe, impart some of their plastic-iness to the wine. Also, you’ll lessen overall dribbling if you can screw the lid on when you’re through drinking.   5) Extreme wines can be very good with extreme movies. On one of the sweltering days this past summer (before I had an air conditioner), I went to see “X-Men.” Without time to visit one of the little wine boutiques in my neighborhood, I was limited to the contents of my fridge. I took ’09 Texier Rosé “L'Anecdot'hic,” a wine that is unusual both in story and taste. Comprising 26 grape varieties planted close to Eric’s house in Charnay, the vineyard is farmed using the Fukuaka method of non-intervention farming. The wine is deep, rich, and fruity for rosé, with a sense of cherry sweetness and a great finish. Even as James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender were pitting their super powers against one another’s at the end of the film, a CGI extravaganza of epic proportions, the wine sang through with a presence all its own. 6) Special occasions call for special movies… and special wines. I have essentially one partner in crime when it comes to drinking wine in movie theaters; we’ve been doing it together for years. He picks the movie and buys the tickets; I bring the wine. The year before last, we began a meta-tradition of going to the movies on New Years Day. Aside from the fact that many people see movies on January 1st, therefore the theaters are crowded, NYD is a perfect day for this activity. Always off work, a bit groggy from the previous night’s festivities, in search of something relaxing to do in the afternoon or evening, New Years resolutions at bay until January 2nd , these are the conditions under which we enter the theater. NYD 2011 we saw “True Grit,” the excellent Cohen Brothers remake of an old western. To drink we had 2005 Larmandier-Bernier Grand Cru Cramant, not Pierre Larmandier’s best effort in my opinion, but an ideal wine for the theatre: soft from the vintage, slightly nutty and mushroom-y, hinting at evolution but without being a wine I’d actually want to age. The wine was good enough not to do a disservice to the movie by any means, but not so fantastic that it distracted from quirkily funny Cohen Brothers dialogue, the well-wrought Jeff Bridges character and the superb performance of Hailee Steinfield. NYD 2012, just a few weeks ago, we saw the long-awaited remake of “Girl with the Dragon Tattoo.” We drank Chidaine sparkling Montlouis, followed by a glass each of ’10 Luiz Rodriguez Ribeiro Blanco. The Chidaine, delightfully aromatic and soft enough to be a good match for popcorn, was delicious. Though I don’t put this sparkling Chenin in the same category as the excellent Vourvray Brut Non-Dosé from Francois Pinon, I am fond of the wine and seek it out from time to time. A field blend of Treixadura, Godello, Albariño, and Caiño Blanco from Galicia in northwestern Spain, the Rodriguez was excellent, a wine that I would advocate any white wine lover to try. Fresh and rocky on the nose, floral, honeyed, layered, this wine hints at Loire Valley Chenin as well as white Burgundy. The finish boasts the kind of minerality that is so mouth-coating, it almost feels tannic. I had the pleasure of tasting with Rodriguez last year; his higher end Blanco “Escolma,” in the price range of a Puligny-Montrachet, is the best Spanish white wine I’ve had to date. As for the movie, you should see it yourself while it’s still in the theaters: thrilling, thought and conversation provoking, beautiful, and possessed of a gripping story line, the movie was great. I haven’t seen the original, nor have I read the books, which meant that the villain remained a mystery until the very end; I was on the edge of my seat, a jelly jar of Ribeiro Blanco in my hand, bits of popcorn on my pants. (A vaguely ironic aside: the wines, in fact all the beverages in “Girl with the Dragon Tattoo” are extremely well chosen. After the film, I recommend a warm apartment, a Grand Cru Burgundy, and a roast chicken.) Salut!
