item.title: Two Nights, Two Dinners, Not Much French Wine, and a Few Revelations… Part 1.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In the process of trying to finish a piece on Benoit Lahaye, I found myself yearning to write about something a bit more frivolous. I’ll finish with Benoit; I love his wines too much not to, but in the meantime, I have the urge to write about two delightful evenings in my recent wine life. Thank God this is blogging and not school, wherein we are forced to write what the teacher tells us. Friday night four people came to dinner. At my family home in rural North Carolina, in a dining room with a table that seats twenty, this would have been nothing, but in my East Williamsburg apartment, four exceeds maximum capacity. Strategic furniture rearrangement was required, so was cold food. There is no ventilation in my kitchen; thus it’s impossible to serve hot food during the summer months.  I settled on the following menu: chilled beet soup followed by cauliflower and red pepper crustless quiche, grated carrot salad, potato salad with dill and bacon, roasted fennel, cheese (provided by the lovely AR and her hook ups at Stinky Brooklyn).  The basically non-existent theme was “COLD.” In wine terms this means: if it’s red, it should be chilled. In guest terms, suffice it to say these are folks of whom I’m very fond, and with two non-wine pros (yet great tasters) in the mix, we managed to balance the geekery. We drank a number of delicious wines, but I’m going to be parsimonious with my commentary on most in order to focus on the “revelations.” With beet soup, we drank a Vinho Verde from a producer in the Savio Soares portfolio called “Casa de Mouraz.” The wine is labeled “Biotite;” we know it as “Bio-Tittie.” Mouraz is a certified organic winery in the Dao; this wine comes from the north of Portugal. Let’s say that if Galicia is the Spanish face of a coin, the Costa Verde is its Portuguese face: same rivers, same grapes (in this case Loureiro, Azal, Trajadura, and Arinto), different wines. I like Vinho Verde and this one seems transcendent of the category. For one thing, its balance is reminiscent of a trocken Riesling with low alcohol, high acidity, and a touch of residual sugar; there’s even a hint of petrol. Like most, this is a lightly effervescent Vinho Verde; its charm comes from its juicy, succulence and ebullient fruit. It’s a wine you feel on the sides of your cheeks as it makes you salivate. We drank an Austrian wine from Jutta Ambrositch, a new producer for me. Apparently Jutta makes about 500 cases of wine a year, farms bio-dynamically, and is a little known gem of a winemaker in Vienna. This selection “Wien Ein Liter” is a blend of Grüner Veltliner, Gemischter Satz, and Riesling. Jutta raises her wines in stainless steel and stirs the lees, two practices that, I would imagine, contribute to this wine’s rich-textured purity. In spite of the green, vegetal, and peppery associations we normally have with Grüner, this wine is mellow and floral with anise, pears, a subtle resonance, and an intriguing dark, sleek depth. Both wines were appropriate - if not earth-shattering - partners for the soup. For the “main course” of our meal, we drank two American wines (!!!): a stainless steel tank Chardonnay from Red Tail Ridge winery in the Finger Lakes and Malvasia Bianco from Birichino, a California “project” (read négociant). Red Tail is 34 acres in the town of Penn Yan, New York, on Seneca Lake. It’s a relatively new winery, dating back to the early 2000s. It seems that the couple who run Red Tail have quite a bit of oenology experience. AR has been hounding me to give these wines a chance for a year now. I’m glad I did. Honestly, I love the Finger Lakes and, as a child, I spent a fair amount of time in Ithaca, Trumansburg, and Watkins Glenn, but I do not expect good wine to come from the Finger Lakes. Too often the reds are thin and over-oaked, and the whites stringent, under-ripe, and lacking minerality. I was mildly delighted by Red Tail’s Chardonnay. It was apple-y crisp, balanced, with layers of fruit on the mid-palate, and expressive of… well… Chardonnay. And it tasted great with cauliflower quiche and roast fennel with lots of lemon juice and zest. The flavors of Chardonnay suit eggs (a challenging food with which to pair wine), and fennel, and cauliflower. The real surprise, however, was Birichino Malvasia Bianco.  The two gentleman (“dudes,” perhaps? It is Cali, after all…) behind Birichino used to work for Randall Graham, and one might sense the Bonny Doon spirit here. The Malvasia that goes into this wine was brought to Monterey from Calabria in the early 19th century, where it thrives on a high elevation vineyard, benefiting from warm days and cool nights. Widely planted, Greek of origin, Malvasia is aromatic and foxy, Muscat-like, but with less of a Rose water note and spicier lychee aromas. I only wanted a glass of this wine but, to its credit, it proved to be the most remarkable partner to grated carrot salad with shallots, celery, and parsley (one of my culinary staples.) Lightly tannic, a bit bronze in the glass, more flower than fruit-driven, the wine played friskily with my salad. This may sound farfetched so bear with me: carrots have a very particular earthy, aromatic character and mouth-feel that is mimicked by this wine. (Try it and tell me I’m wrong; email me and I’ll send you the wine as well as my recipe for carottes rapées.) At some point we realized that we were in an unfortunate bind: we had nothing but cheese left to eat and nothing but red wine left to drink. (If the expression “First World Problems” springs to mind, I don’t blame you.) Wine and cheese are like the bride and groom in an arranged marriage: sometimes they grow to love each other; often they despise each other yet are forced to coexist nonetheless. It’s an oft alluded to notion that white wine and cheese stand a greater chance at marital bliss than red wine and cheese; Champagne and cheese spells disaster, and the best scenario for a happy cheese union is a bottle of sweet wine at the end of a meal. Yes we really do believe that all those Brits and Frenchies sipping First Growth Bordeaux with Roquefort, and Grand Cru Burgundy with Epoisse are wrong! There’s something about tannins that makes all the funk and ammonia and foot-iness of cheese flourish in one’s nostrils and mouth. But what could we do? We opened a 2009 Produttori del Barbaresco Nebbiolo and a 2010 Pacalet Bourgogne Rouge and hoped for the best… The cheeses were as follows: Toma della Rocca (mild, luscious, and like a savory cheese cake - made from cow, sheep, and goat’s milk on the border of Piedmont and Lombardy), Abbaye du Bellocq (mild, semi-soft, sheep-y cheese from the Pyrenees), Appenzeller (classic, nutty, Swiss Alpine cheese made from cow’s milk), Le Peral (Asturias, blue -- need I say more?) We began nibbling cheese and splashing wines in our glasses, including the dregs of the whites we had tasted earlier, testing combinations and discussing them. The results were astonishing. The best pairing of the night (aside from carrots and Birichino), also my penultimate “revelation” was Toma della Rocca with young Produttori Nebbiolo, which seemed totally counter- intuitive, as Nebbiolo is very tannic and generally at ease only with meat and mushrooms. This young, warm vintage Nebbiolo, a traditionally made yet accessible wine from the skilled Aldo Vaca, was deeply ripe, not lacking the high-toned earthiness and rose-y character one desires from Piemontese Nebbiolo, but showing sweet-toned, red berry fruit. The wine with the Toma was like cherries spooned over cheesecake… but better. I mean no disrespect to the Produttori in likening the wine to cherry cheesecake topping. One of the most exceptional and long-standing co-ops in the winemaking world, Vaca takes pride in the staunch traditionalism of the winemaking, the lack of new barrels and the absence of winery tricks at Produttori. The co-op’s vineyard specific wines are structured and long-lived, but it happens that this Nebbiolo is joyous, forward, and downright “gouleyant” (gulp-able). Before I disclose the evening’s ultimate “revelation,” I’ll say that on the following night (part 2 of this duo of dinners), my co-worker, the inimitable CB, did tell me that young Nebbiolo possesses a hidden, cheese pairing super power. You’ll have to wait for next week’s installment to hear more… Isn’t it wonderful to be wrong? I remember once in early high school, I swore up and down that I hated Phish (the band). My sneaky friend, FVH, put on a catchy Phish song one evening and, without disclosing the artist’s identity, asked me how I liked the music. “I love this; this is awesome!” issued forth from my lips. The episode was followed by at least a year’s worth of glorious Phish listening. There are things about which I prefer to be right, but food and wine pairings is not one of them. I love “wrong;” each “wrong” is a lesson. When we learn to pair, we stick to theory or an intuitive sense of what works, but we don’t ever really know until we’ve tried, and pairings that are based on theory or intuition rather than empiricism are often not good pairings. We tested a number of white wines with two of the three remaining cheeses. Combinations that seemed as though they would work didn’t really (Appenzeller and Ambrositch). Combinations we knew would work were fine but unexciting (Red Tail and Abbaye du Bellocq). We had no earthly idea what to do with the Roaring 40s blue until the intrepid NG (not a wine pro, therefore not subject to abject wine prejudices, also more open minded) poured himself some Pacalet and took a bite of Roaring 40s. “NOOOOO! STOP! THEY AREN’T RIGHT FOR EACH OTHER!” practically peeled from my lips. Of course you can guess what came next. “Actually the Burgundy is pretty good with the blue.” Silence. In the background a Cuban pianist lightly tinkled an old fashioned rift. We all agreed; let’s give it a little test, this dubious combination of tangy, high acidity, cranberry and Sumac laden, natural young Pacalet and salty, creamy blue cheese… and it worked. Far from a perfect pairing, the wine and the cheese shared a harmonious tang. There was complementary sweet and salt and something mysteriously and perplexingly good about the combination. Oh well. Back to the drawing board or the cutting board, even better…

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Sophie. Thanks so much for your posting. I'm glad our Malvasia proved to be a revelation with your carrots (though of course I can't fathom how you could have just one wee glass :) I can imagine the sweetness of the carrots and celery combined with the edge of shallots and verdant (but also a touch floral, sweet) bite of parsley would be quite good with it.Please do send your carrottes recette- most keen to try. I'm not exactly sure we qualify as "dudes" - I have been surfing--twice--but am a New Englander by birth, and John is a Michigan boy FWIW, but both climes were just way too brutal for us so we relocated as soon as we came to our senses to The Peoples Republic of Santa Cruz just after the '89 quake. I also have just a small comment to make on your description of us that comes to us courtesy of the Frenchies whose language lends itself so well to such subtle shades of meaning. We are négociants, yes, but more specifically négociant-éleveurs in that, indeed, we own nothing but 2 Macbookss, a few old Taransaud barrels, and yet are fortunate to work with 3rd generation growers from families we've known and had the pleasure of working with for 20+ years. We buy their fruit, and make every single picking and winemaking decision in our wines. But as yet, we don't have a fortune from i-banking that we can then pour into a hole in the ground in the form of a vineyard we can call our own (though our long-term contracts give us many of the bennies, without the mortgage payments). Though who knows, i do have exactly 9 vines planted in the backyard (some Rayas grenache, a little mourvedre and roussanne from Beaucastel planted with a little biochar and perhaps I can coax those buggers into producing 1 ton per vine.. I hope you will get the chance to try some of our other wines one of these days. Cheers! Alex

item.title: The Ballad of Benoit
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: As a general rule, I try to pick different topics for Sophie’s Glass than I pick for my articles for Chambers Street Wines. There are several reasons for this, the primary one being that I don’t want to bore you, dear reader. If you are out there and reading, chances are you also read what I write for the wine shop, and therefore don’t need to find those stories reiterated on my blog. Furthermore, the goals of the two are different. When I write for Chambers Street, I write to sell what I believe is great wine; when I write for Sophie’s Glass, I write for myself, also to share information about great wine. (Please note that I’m talking about “great” as opposed to “Great” wine; in other words I’m not talking about DRC or Clos Saint Hune or Monfortino or even Overnoy Poulsard, but singularly delicious wine that is attainable to normal humans such as myself.) If I become a VIB (Very Important Blogger) one day, perhaps my pieces will influence sales (perhaps I’ll begin drinking “Great” wine, which would be neat!). In the meantime, these pieces are designed to give me an outlet to write and to share my experiences with wines, their terroir, and their makers. No matter how hard I try, there will always be a few overlaps between Sophie’s Glass and my CSW articles and this is one. The points of overlap occur, of course, when a set of wines is so compelling that I feel obliged both to buy them for the store and to offer more detail on Sophie’s Glass. After all, we’re talking about really tasty wine here, which has a tendency to permeate many aspects of life, professional and personal. For those of you who read about Benoït Lahaye on the CSW site (or who have read about Benoït on Peter Liem’s site, in which case you have no earthly need of my blog), I apologize, in advance, for repetition and please feel free to skip anything that feels repetitive. One of the stars of my (now not so) recent trip to Champagne was Benoït Lahaye, a grower in the Grand Cru of Bouzy, a village in the Montagne de Reims known for its powerful Pinot Noir-based Champagnes. I already knew that I liked Lahaye’s wines very much; I had been working to procure them for Chambers Street since Peter had told me he views Lahaye’s wines as the best from Bouzy. I could not have anticipated how much I would come to respect the man during our visit. Benoït farms just shy of five hectares, planted about 90% to Pinot Noir. He stopped using systemic herbicides (widely used in Champagne, loathed by Benoït Lahaye) in the mid-90s. By the early 2000s, the Domaine was entirely converted to organic viticulture. By 2007, Benoït was certified; by 2009 Benoït was certified in biodynamics. As discussed in an earlier post, it is an immense challenge it is to do this kind of vineyard work in Champagne. In addition to the struggle to fight mildew and odium without chemical treatments, there’s the issue of one’s neighbors. The Champenoises refer to the vineyards in the northern part of Champagne as being “morcelées,” meaning “parceled out.” The region is a patchwork of tiny plots of land, worked by many people, the vast majority of whom use chemicals. An organic grower’s vineyards are always threatened by runoff from his or her neighbor’s vines. In short, organic (not to mention biodynamic) farming is a real labor of love in Champagne, practiced by those few dedicated growers, amongst them, Benoit, who genuinely want to make the best wine possible and believe this process begins with the soil. I met Peter at Benoït’s Domaine on a beautiful, sunny morning. We went straight to Benoit’s tasting room, overlooking his garden in Bouzy, where we applied fresh palates to Benoit’s wines. Before I address our tasting, can I say that I am continually amazed at the way winemaker’s personalities are reflected in their wines? Of course this could be an occult belief, merely the power of suggestion; once a particular hint of flamboyance or subtly has been noted in a wine, it becomes easy to find a comparable trace in the winemaker. Nonetheless I find that – even if it’s no more than the choice of arch traditionalism versus innovative winemaking – winemakers are reflected in their wares. I recently had dinner with a biodynamic farmer in Trumansburg, New York, who believes that stewardship of the land is an essential “element,” if you will, of biodynamics, meaning it’s not merely the earth and its bounty; it’s the man or woman who tends the earth in this very particular way, aligning the other factors so all may come together. On a surface level, this is totally obvious. Biodynamics is a choice, a human choice, but I think this farmer meant to add that the grower is part of the biodynamic equation along with the cycles of the moon and the tisanes for treating the soil. I like this idea; it jives with my intuition of the way these things work. Then again, we humans are nothing if not masterful at finding spirituality in the mundane. But back to Benoït. My gut reaction to Benoït was not unlike my gut reaction to Michel Gahier when I met him a year ago. Benoït is shyly passionate. He is a subtle man, not prone to exaggeration, not verbose, yet willing to explain what goes on at the Domaine, why he chose to begin farming organically and why he eventually converted to biodynamics. He was clearly preoccupied by the health of the soil when we visited the vines after our tasting. In an attempt to promote airy soil, not compacted by a tractor, Benoït began plowing the majority of his Domaine with his horse, a sweet-natured, 900 pound creature. And Benoït truly loves his horse, who we visited. As frisky as such a massive animal can be, he trotted over to us, perhaps eager for a carrot or an apple. While Peter and I ogled the horse, Benoït explained that one of the major drawbacks of horse plowing is that the horse has a mind of his own. It can be a challenge keeping him on task in the vines. In the cellar, Benoït is a minimalist and his wines are delicate for Bouzy Champagnes; minerality speaks loudest of all. A portion of Benoit’s wines are raised in barrel and he hopes, eventually, to accommodate 50% of his production in barrel. The wines undergo malolactic fermentation sometimes, but not always. In general, he blends malo and non-malo wines together for a balanced, finished wine. Dosages are steadily decreasing each year as he harvests riper grapes with no sacrifice of acidity. He attributes this increase in ripeness to organic farming. As a finishing touch, in cooler years, Lahaye puts his vintage wine under cork rather than capsule for the second fermentation (a practice called tirer a liège), which gives the wines a broader and more generous character from slightly more exposure to oxygen. We began our tasting with Benoït's Extra Brut, a blend of 85% Pinot and 15% Chardonnay, the Chardonnay grown on chalk. This wine combines '09, '08, and '07 vintages with some reserve wine coming from a Solera that Benoït keeps. The wine is raised in roughly 80% wood, which perhaps mellows the sharp edges that Extra Brut Champagnes can sometimes have. With no shortage of ripeness, tangy, apple-y fruit, and fine bubbles, I liked Benoït's Extra Brut, but it was the first wine of the day and I am not yet the professional who can truly assess a wine with the taste of toothpaste and coffee in my mouth. Brut Essentiel followed close on the heels of Extra Brut. It's essentially (no put intended) the same wine, but dosed with six grams of sugar. Tasting wines that differ only in their level of dosage is a wonderful experience because the addition of sugar changes everything about the wine from the aroma to the mouth-feel to the finish. I suppose the minerality remains unchanged, but its presentation is certainly effected by an alteration of dosage. Brut Essentiel showed more baked apple, while Extra Brut showed more raw apple flesh on the nose. Both had notes of fresh cut grass and green leaves, but this fresh green quality came alive slightly more in the Brut Essentiel. Again, the addition of sugar brings out aromas, even if it can distract from a Champagne's steely mineral finish. In the end it's all about balance, and though there is an element of personal preference and fashion in the choice to dose or not to dose (and if so, how much?), there remains an sense of objective reality to the notion of a balanced Champagne. Both of these wines had only been disgorged for two months and the expert, Peter, tells me the ideal time to taste is six months after disgorgement, so these two were destined to evolve and I hoped to encounter them again down the road. We moved on to Blanc de Noirs, a personal favorite of mine. Dosed at five grams and comprising the 2007 and 2008 vintages, this wine has intriguing notes of ginger, mirabelle plum, and crushed raspberries on the nose and lovely, soft, delicate bubbles. Disgorged in December, it had had more time that the first two wines we tasted to settle down after disgorgement. I think part of the reason I love this Blanc de Noirs is that it is a good representation of Benoït's style: subtle and unassuming for Grand Cru Bouzy, which is often brawny, almost clunky wine. There is a real elegance and delicacy to the frame, complemented by fine minerality. For me the next wine, vintage 2006, absolutely stole the show. Benoït told us the Chardonnay that goes into this wine (30%) comes from a very old parcel of chalk in Bouzy called "Argentières" that was planted in the '60s. (There's a question mark next to my note on the planting date; please take it with a grain of salt, as well as the spelling of the vineyard name.) Dosed at four grams, this wine felt perfectly balanced with a powerful mid-palate, the chalk and acid gripping hold of the tongue and the cheeks and clinging on until the very end. I have tasted this wine since then, twice in the states, and each time it has been just incredible. I have to confess that I was not paying the utmost attention when we tasted Naturessence, a blend of 2006 and 2007 fruit, equal parts Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. I was enjoying listening Benoït speak about his horse. I regained focus when Violaine made its way to the table. This is a cuvée that Benoït makes without sulfur. Like Naturessence, the wine is equal parts Chardonnay and Pinot, in this case all from the 2008 vintage (a very, very good vintage in Champagne). Violaine takes its name from the town where both Benoït and his wife's parents grew up. Sans Soufre Champagne is basically uncharted territory. We know that Dominique Moreau from Marie-Courtin makes one... and there is this one from Benoït Lahaye, but Champagne growers are generally not shy with sulfur, though the very good ones are not excessive either (Laval, Lassaigne, Collin, etc...). I didn't know what to contrast this wine to. It had expressive and natural-feeling aromas that were perhaps marked by the faintest oxidation; it was a very vinous wine, and it was the finish that stuck in my mind. There was nothing interrupting this wine's minerality, which was mouth-coating, softer than the 2006, and equally long. I was intrigued and would have liked to sit down and gotten to know this bottle better. There are some scenarios in which a quick taste at the Domaine is not enough. We finished with Benoït's Rosé Champagne, from the 2008 and 2009 vintage. I am sucker for this wine. It's unique in my experience of the category. I enjoyed what Benoït had to say in the subject: "there are two things that really piss me off: herbicides and Rosés made by assemblage" (the process of adding a portion of still red wine to a white Champagne to give it color). I knew exactly what he meant. Rosé Champagne is a thing the market demands and many growers I spoke to make it for the market. As a buyer, it's hard to put Rosé Champagne on the shelf in the wine store because I am often disappointed by the wines, even from top growers. And they are expensive! Typically the finer examples of pink Champagne are made using a process called "saignée," in which first press red juice is "bled" into the wine giving it color. Benoït's is neither saignée nor assemblage, but rather "Rosé de Macération" as he calls it. The grapes macerate on the skins for 18 hours, giving the wine its color, which is deep magenta. This is a serious wine. Dosed at three grams of sugar, it has intense strawberry and cranberry aromas, and finishes with light tannins. The fruit has a real presence, but is in no way cloying. This wine is probably not for everyone as it is atypical for Rosé Champagne, but, if you're an intrepid drinker, I highly recommend seeking a bottle out. We stepped out into Benoït's sunny backyard, piled into his truck, and headed for the vines...

item.title: Rosé Over-Haul: what to Drink, Skip, and Seek out Immediately.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Even though Rosé is clearly popular among the masses in New York, it’s not so popular in the geek crowd, I’ve discovered. Why? Rosé seems generally to be viewed as more frivolous and less *complex* than very good white or red wine. Of course there are the oft-cited exceptions: Lopez de Heredia, Cotat, Chateau Simone, for some Clos Cibonne. These are wines that are released later and can age longer than the standard pale Provençal Rosés that begin to crop up in wine stores and on restaurant lists in March and April, which are fruity but dry and particularly sought after if they come in a curvy bottle like Domaine Ott. (Ott Rosé is a terrible product. I tasted it once when I was buying wine at Astor. The wine is fake-y, low quality, and expensive - the Rosé equivalent of Santa Margherita Pinot Grigio.) It’s these low quality Rosés that give the entire category a bad rap and make it a challenge for people like me who love Rosé to tout its merits. The truth is that, between Ott and Clos Cibonne, there is a lot of Rosé to drink and, beginning in April, I set out to drink as much as I can. In my memory, there were more Rosé lovers among the North Carolina wine geeks than there are among the New York ones, and who of my hometown friends can forget "Rosé Croquet": an annual spring time event of pink wine, white clothes, cucumber sandwiches, and this civilized outdoor game? In New York, the geeks are dismissive of the category, thus I’ve become the go-to Rosé person at my shop because I make a point to drink basically everything we stock from our $11 Bergerac DI Rosé to Pradeaux and Pibarnon. My take on the situation is that, for sure, Rosé is sometimes not as complex as very good white or red wine, but what it can lack in complexity, it makes up for in deliciousness. If you require a high level of complexity to enjoy an experience with wine, then maybe the majority of Rosé wines aren’t for you, but if you like the flavors of a good Rosé, nothing else will do, and I’ve got lots of recommendations. My parameters for Rosé are that I don’t like residual sugar and I typically prefer French (and to an extent Austrian) Rosé to Italian, German, Spanish, or New World. Below you’ll find a list of Rosés from the Loire and Provence that I have been either impressed or disappointed by this summer, beginning in the Loire. First I should mention that perhaps because I work for the yeast police (anyone who wants further explanation of this statement can email me personally), it has become very hard to taste or have a conversation about Rosé without discussing yeast. As I understand it, most Rosé is fermented using cultured yeast rather than naturally occurring yeast that flourishes in the vineyards of cellars of the best organic wine growers. The advantages of inoculation if you’re a winemaker are that 1) you get a standardized product and 2) the fermentation happens more quickly, thus the wine is bottled and sold more quickly, and you make more money. It’s also worth noting that many growers must add yeast because they don’t have an adequate naturally occurring yeast population. The disadvantage of inoculating is that the wine often isn’t as good. This is a topic that deserves much more time and many more words than I’m going to give it at the moment. Yeasted Rosé is not necessarily bad and can, in fact, be quite enjoyable. Many excellent growers use cultured yeast, but wild yeast Rosé is better: the fruit more vivid and less candied, the aromas earthier and more authentic, the finishes longer, more layered and complex. If there’s one bottle to seek out posthaste this summer, it’s the 2009 vintage (though not vintage dated) François Pinon Brut Rosé. I have been drinking this wine for four years now and this is the most distinct rendition to date. Made from a blend of Grolleau and Malbec, the wine can sometimes be very lightly sweet, but seems dry in 2009 (of course – otherwise I wouldn’t like it). Fruit mingling with earth and a hint of Loire Valley funk on the nose, the wine has surprising complexity for its price ($20) and is – dare I say – arrestingly delicious. All the strawberry, sour cherry, and earth carry through to the palate with surprising clarity. The finish is tangy, dry, and clean. I’ve consumed several bottles of this wine in the past two months and it has paired with every scenario: roof tops to afternoon Downton Abbey watching to that bloomy New Jersey cheese called Kunik. I routinely advise clients against Laherte Frères Brut Rosé ($45) in favor of this wine. It’s nothing against Aurélian Laherte, who makes wonderful wine; the Pinon is just that good. Second on my list of 2011 “must-drink” Rosés is Clos Roche Blanche’s Pineau D’Aunis Rosé (no surprises here; if you’ve read some of my previous posts, you know I love their wines, especially this one). In 2010, this wine had some problems: it began the summer lightly sweet and finished the summer dry and lightly sparkling: refermentation. I don’t foresee a similar fate befalling 2011, which is totally dry and possessed of the delicious capsicum edge of Pineau D’Aunis: green peppers and black pepper and sour, wild strawberries and cherries. This is not a fruity wine by any stretch of imagination, but one doesn’t want for fruit when it’s in the glass. A constant challenge to try to find words for Clos Roche Blanche’s wines, my descriptors fail time and again. The wines are so vibrant and seem to have a voice all their own; they linger in my mind as the evidence of result of what great vineyard work does for great wine. My boss, DL, tells me that Didier Barouillet of Clos Roche Blanche is so intimately close to the soil and the vines that he can predict what the wines will be like in a given vintage without having to taste them! Olga Raffaut Chinon Rosé, which was a joy in 2010, was not quite such a joy in 2011. My co-worker, JR, drank a bottle before I did, and he reported that it was “fruity.” He and I do not always see eye to eye. His palate is more – shall we say – acid driven than mine? I honestly believed that I would probably like the wine and I didn’t. It was fruity and, while not lacking acidity, not possessed of as much as I have come to expect and want from Rosé of Cabernet Franc. Though not heavy-handed by any means, the wine lacked clarity and gave more of a sense of homogenous pink wine than of the limestone of Chinon or the spice of Cabernet Franc. And the varietal character was mute, buried under a layer of fruit. The faintest hint of green pepper emerged on day three as the fruit receded, but I remained unsatisfied. From the south of France, the big surprise was Côtes de Provence Rosé from Chateau Pradeaux, the famous Bandol Domaine. Either this wine has not been made before, or it has not been imported before. Whatever the case, I received missives from my friends at Rosenthal Wine Merchant while they were on their spring tasting jaunt raving about this wine. I found it to live up to the praise. From a blend of Cinsault, Mourvèdre, and Barbaroux (has anyone heard of this grape?) the wine has the voluptuous and silken texture of good Bandol Rosé with the snappy, brightness of Cotes de Provence Rosé. Too often, Côtes de Provence Rosé smells of peaches and peach fuzz, the peach aromas coming from fake yeast and the peach fuzz coming from an excess of sulfur. It’s a delicious relief when these wines have saline, iodine, and orange rind aromas and flavors like their more “serious” cousins in Bandol. I found Pradeaux’s Côtes de Provence Rosé to incorporate aspects of both appellations into a thoroughly enjoyable whole. The Commanderie de Peyrassol’s “Commanderie” bottling did not fare as well under my scrutiny. I’ve been drinking this wine since 2005, and I still recall my first sip; it was a revelation. Notably, the best bottles of Peyrassol have a delicate, floral quality in addition to pale, berry notes, and stone fruits. It can be absolutely delicious. That being said, the wine has been getting less delicious and I can only attribute this sad fact to an increase in production. The Rosenthal website now tells us that the company’s annual allotment of the wine is 40-50,000 bottles. It’s very hard to maintain good quality with an increase in production. With global warming, there have been several very hot vintages in the south of France, problematic for the Rosés of the area which can easily become alcoholic, fruity, and less crisp than we'd like. Peyrassol’s Commanderie bottling has been getting fruitier, with more berries and standard Rosé aromas and less of the blossom-like prettiness of my first few vintages of the wine. I don’t wish to cast aspersions nor have I the right to claim that I can always discern when Rosés are fermented naturally, but I don’t think this wine is fermented with native yeast. It has the sweet, fake-y fruit nose of inoculated Rosé. I’m not sure which is sadder, that the wine is yeasted or that I have become unable to enjoy it because of this. Not to be a hopeless shill for my company, but the wines we import from Les Fouques in the Côtes de Provence are better and more natural feeling that Peyrassol’s Rosés have become. It surprises me when I drink Clos Cibonne that I prefer the young vine to the old vine bottling: Cuvée Spéciale des Vignettes. For those unfamiliar with this Domaine, it dates back to the late 18th century and makes wines based on an uncommon local grape variety called Tibouren. In addition to this unique grape that provides the base for these wines, the aging process is unusual. The wines are aged in hundred year old barrel, 5,000 liter barrels under a thin layer of surface yeast: voile. They are released later; the current release is 2010 rather than 2011. These wines have only been on the New York market since last year when my friend, Andre Tamers, of De Maison Selections began to import them. I recall notable (and hilarious) wine luminary Levi Dalton raving about Cuvée des Vignettes, from the Domaine’s oldest vines (60 years old). The profile of these wines is intriguing; they have the deeply saline aspect of Bandol Rosé and notes of orange rind, but they are more oxidative and, I’m told, this is the flavor of Tibouren. The texture is silken, velvety, and the wines are quite full-bodied, also balanced. There’s none of the facile berry and peach/apricot of a typical Provençal Rosé and - to me - the wines are not fruity, though they broaden out with ripe, mouth-filling flavors on the mid-palate. I find the young vines Clos Cibonne to be more drinkable than the Vignettes, which needs lots of time to open up. Typically these wines like to breathe and will show best when the bottle is half drunk. I suppose you could decant, but it’s Rosé… save the decanter for your next ’82 La Mission Haut-Brion. These aren’t the only excellent Rosés I’ve drunk in 2012… but I’ll stop for today. Please find yourself some Pinon and some Clos Roche Blanche. And remember that nothing suits the produce and seafood that are in abundance at the various NYC green markets better than Rosé. Tomatoes are here and they are great. In whatever preparation, your raw, in-season tomato is calling out for a glass of Rosé to stand beside it. Come find me at Chambers Street; I'll help you pick something out. Salud!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yeast police--hilarious! Damned if they aren't right. DL and JW have taught me a lot. Keep up the terrific posts. Best, John

item.title: Pondering Pinot Meunier...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: (This is a two part story and I’m struggling and probably failing to make the parts cohere, but here goes... Part one is about my visit to Aurélian Laherte in Chavot, Coteaux du Sud d’Epernay; part two is about a Pinot Meunier tasting I hosted at Chambers Street a few days ago.) Pinot Meunier strikes me as the red headed stepchild of Champagne grape varieties, possessing neither the ability to impart as much power and complexity as Pinot Noir, nor as much chiseled, expressive minerality as Chardonnay. It is primarily a blending grape, grown all over the region but most commonly found in the western lobe of Champagne: the Marne Valley. What Meunier may lack in finesse, it makes up for in dependable productivity and high acidity. My collector friend, NV, often complains that Meunier-based Champagnes have unpleasantly fat bubbles. I distinctly recall an acquaintance working for Champagne Salon saying something to the effect of “people who grow Meunier have no terroir.” (Easy to say when you’re perched in Mesnil, arguably the best Grand Cru of the Côte des Blancs.) Regardless of its usefulness, Meunier is less prized than Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. What started my pondering of Meunier was the arrival of some wines from Vincent Laval, including a Meunier called “Meunier de la Butte” that retails for $240/bottle. When this grower’s top single vineyard Chardonnay and Pinot Noir range from $150-$160, how could this fat-bubbled, terroir-less Meunier possibly cost almost $100 more?!? In the interest of trying to discover if there’s a commonality to Pinot Meunier based Champagnes, also to answer the question: “Why is Laval’s Meunier so expensive and is it worth it?”, we opened some bottles at Chambers Street. Leading up to the tasting, I recalled that Aurélian Laherte is a young man who has a solid grasp of how to squeeze terroir from the humble Meunier grape. I began to remember my visit to his Domaine. The Lahertes have been in and around Chavot since the late 19th century and Aurélian is the seventh generation winemaker at the estate. Laherte Frères is registered as a négoce because several different family members own the vines that go into Laherte’s wines; thus they “buy” grapes from one another. But Laherte Frères is an RM - a grower - in every relevant sense of the word. Best, always, to consult Peter Liem for a more thorough explanation at www.champagneguide.net. It’s an interesting place, Chavot. Just south of Epernay on the western side, its terroir comprises the chalk of the Côte des Blancs and the clay of the Vallée de la Marne. From the hillside below Aurélian’s winery, one can see white, chalky slopes to the east and darker, clay-heavy slopes to the west. This hillside was our first stop on my visit. Aurélian showed it to me as though to say “look at this diversity of terroir we have!” In fact, the Lahertes work with many tiny plots and they are all treated individually in the cellar. Aurélian farms the plots close to Chavot biodynamically and he plans eventually to convert the rest to biodynamics. And Aurélian is an interesting guy: angular, lean, intense, and focused for his age (late 20s). He told me that he had done a stage at Kendall-Jackson in California. This must have given him an antipathy toward malo-lactic fermentation for Chardonnay because his wines often do not undergo it and are marked by their riveting acidity. In fact, malo is blocked by opening the winery doors, letting freezing cold air into the cellar to stop the growth of the bacteria that causes “le malo.” This being said, his Meunier, with its excessively high acidity, generally undergoes malo to soften its edges.  Aurélian has a speaker system set up in his winery and the barrels (all small and old) are serenaded by classical recordings. I believe Bach was playing when I was there… There’s a chamber-like quality to the cellar at Laherte; it’s a big, open space lined with barrels, airy and very cold. The only stainless steel to be found is used for the “basic” Brut Tradition and Rosé, which are fermented using cultured yeast. The rest of Laherte’s wines are raised in barrel with native yeast for the first fermentations. Aurélian and I adjourned to his tasting room, where we began with his Brut Tradition, a Meunier based wine that is a terrific value and delicious (even though it is not fermented with native yeast – shh – don’t tell). This isn’t a terroir wine for Aurélian; it’s a bread and butter wine: fairly rich, toasty, and nutty, apple-y with great cut and character for well-priced Champagne. We moved on to his Blanc de Blancs, which I had not previously tasted because the importer doesn’t normally bring it in. I loved it. Bottled Brut Nature and with malo-lactic fermentation blocked, it’s a zesty, austere wine with notes of key lime and chalk on the nose. With its total lack of warmth, this wine will not cradle or caress your palate, but it is remarkably alive. I ordered ten cases. Next we tasted “Les Clos,” a wine made from the mélange of original Champagne grapes: Pinot Meunier, Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, Arbanne, Petit Meslier, Pinot Blanc, and Pinot Gris. All grapes are co-harvested and fermented, from a vineyard that is farmed biodynamically. Raised in a solera, the current release of Les Clos comprises each vintage from 2005 to 2009. It has a beautiful stone fruity richness on the nose and laser-like acidity and minerality on the palate. I have only tasted this wine twice, and each time I wished for an opportunity to sit with a bottle.I didn’t enjoy 2007 Vignes d’Autrefois quite as much. When it followed Les Clos, it seemed simple. From 40+ year old Meunier vines grown on chalk, the wine is dosed at 2 grams of sugar and feels comfortably dry, lightly toasty, and with the sturdy workhorse feel of Meunier. I prefer, and have for some time, Aurélian’s Rosé “les Beaudiers” from a parcel of limestone and clay, some of which Aurélian keeps a jar of in his tasting room for demonstration purposes. Les Beaudiers is not a fruity wine, but earthy, gamy, broad, and defiant of standard Rosé Champagne. The first Beaudiers I tried, which was based on either the 2005 or the 2006 vintage, smelled like sausage and parmesan cheese and was wonderfully dry and savory. This rendition, based on 2007, is more delicate and less feral, but equally delicious and complex.I tasted a couple of other wines with Aurélian: “Empreintes” and vintage 2005, but I’ll skip them as their base wines are not made from Meunier. My overall impressions of Aurélian were that he’s ascetic and pragmatic; while his style is hard-edged, marked by high acidity, élèvage in old barrels, very low dosages, and the natural rusticity of Meunier, he wants to sell wine and works well with what he’s been given and in the style he’s chosen.Full disclosure: the Meunier exploration at Chambers was merely a transparent excuse to taste the Laval Meunier de la Butte. In researching the wine, I learned the probable reason for its high price. It’s a wine that was only made one time, in 2006. From a vineyard planted to vines in 1930 and 1965, after the 2006 vintage, Vincent Laval replanted the vineyard. I believe that he would normally use the Meunier from this vineyard in his “basic” (though there is nothing basic about it) Cumières. It sounded to me, from reading Peter Liem’s review, as though Vincent Laval made this wine as a sort of celebration of the life of this vineyard before uprooting and replanting it. He made 800 bottles only. Scarcity has an uncanny way of raising the price of a bottle. As is typical of Laval, the base wine was fermented in barrel using native yeast, and the wine shows an incredible ripeness and depth, imparted by long-time organic farming. The wine was absolutely beautiful with a creaminess of texture and rich, lactic weight that played so well with the wine’s high acidity and resonant minerality. The fruit character was apple-y with a citric streak to the midpalate. There was a whiff of dusty, smoky stuff – leaves lingering between fresh and dried. It was a wine that defied description, and it was certainly the most elegant example of Meunier that I have ever come across. We tasted several delicious examples of Pinot Meunier at this tasting. 2006 Laherte Frères Autrefois showed an interesting herbal and vegetal note, a pleasing dryness, and a chalky finish. To my nose and palate, it was more interesting at this point in time than the 2007 I had tasted with Aurélian. “Sagesse” from Franck Pascal comprises 60% Meunier, 25% Pinot, and 15% Chardonnay. I believe, though I can’t swear to it, that this wine is based on fruit from 2007. We agreed that this is a happily masculine wine. The nose is earthy with a fennel seed edge that I found appealing and, without any dosage, the wine is satisfyingly tangy and mineral-laden on the finish. It felt pleasantly rustic after Laherte’s delicacy, but without much charm. After Laherte and then Pascal, Bedel’s “Dis, Vin Secret” seemed positively sweet-toned. Based on the 2003 vintage and dosed at 7 grams of sugar, this wine has a maturity that the others do not. The nose shows the yeasty, biscuit-y quality that the Brits love in Champagne, and the palate is broad, still, and mouth-filling. In some ways, this wine was a relief after the nervosity of Laherte and the Pascal.On to redder examples of Meunier. We tasted Laherte’s 2007 “les Beaudiers,” (previously described) before moving on to the real wild card of the afternoon: Coteau Champenois Rouge from Franck Pascal. The year before last, I visited Pascal with the LDM team and his red Champagne made from 80% Meunier and 20% Pinot Noir stole the show. We begged to buy some for the New York market. This is a wine for acidic red wine lovers. Aromas of raspberry, red currant, and sumac mark the nose. It tastes of fruit seeds and a marginal climate, but is nonetheless ripe and texturally silky. Based on the 2008 vintage with a bit of 2007 in the blend, the majority of the wine is vinified without sulfur and it has the vivid purity of very good natural wines. At the end of the day, I learned that Pinot Meunier-based Champagnes are not charming (even Laval at $240/bottle was not a charming wine, though it was extremely complex and delicious); they are rustic, but they have a moving authenticity and quirkiness, and they more than merit consumption.

item.title: In Situ? The Duchy of Uzès Gains Appellation Status.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: From Yapp.uk: “Few visitors to the region know of the local ‘Duché d’Uzès’ Vin de Pays appellation, which is made by a handful of producers and tends to be consumed in situ rather than exported further afield.” It’s a well-known fact that In Situ wines are just that: wines enjoyed in their place of origin. Roughly five years ago I drove from Provence to Piedmont with my mother. We traced the Mediterranean coast before making our way north at Ventimiglia, the Ligurian town that mirrors Monaco on the French side of the border. Up through the Maritime Alps we drove, scrag and brush becoming verdant hills marred by industrial thoroughfares. When we reached Cuneo, the end of the drive was in sight as we saw signs for Dogliani, Alba, and Asti. From Alba it was just a few kilometers to our ultimate destination: Barbaresco, where we’d rented rooms at an Azienda Agricola called Ca’ du Rabaja. This was 2007 and it was a hot 90 degrees in Barbaresco, nonetheless breathtaking under the baking sun. Vines covered everything, parceled out into plots, hills undulating picturesquely under the blue sky as though there had never been a notion to do anything but cultivate grapes here. We were met at the entrance of Ca’ du Rabaja by the tireless Lorenzo Alutto, a maniac with a business degree from Torino who was trying to remake his father’s home into a winery overlooking the famed Rabaja vineyard. We were to learn much more about Lorenzo as the days wore on, but for the moment we saw a frenetic, wire-y man rushing about the house and grounds barking orders at Sicilian construction workers in hoarse yet melodious Italian. Lorenzo seated us on a large balcony with a view of sun drenched Rabaja, opened a bottle of intense, ripe, floral Nebbiolo, and poured us two enormous glasses. Then he flitted off to continue supervising construction. It was four in the afternoon and we’d been driving since just after dawn; it was also incredibly hot. Nebbiolo is never a refreshing wine. Even Rosato made from Nebbiolo isn’t refreshing. Still, here we were with glasses of (pushing 15% alcohol) young, vaguely spoofy juice… and nary a cracker or a piece of salami in sight. Somehow the wine mysteriously made sense and tasted delicious. I maintain that Lorenzo’s wine was perfect in this moment because we were gazing out at the Langhe hills and basking in the sun that gave birth to it. This is not actually a post about Lorenzo Alutto’s wines, though they are very good, nor it is a post about my adventures in Barbaresco. My apologies for leading you on. I mention the experience only because it’s my most vivid memory of an In Situ wine. Less striking examples of In Situ wines are the wines I drink when I go to the south of France. My oldest childhood friend’s mother owns a house in Argilliers, west of Avignon and north of Nïmes. Argilliers is microscopic, what the French call a “village,” as opposed to a “ville,” which connotes upwards of 5,000 inhabitants. The closest “ville” to Argilliers is Uzès. A pretty and historically interesting town, Uzès was built by the Romans, at the font of a major aqueduct constructed in the 1st century BC to convey water to the inhabitants of Nïmes. Argilliers lies just three kilometers from the Pont du Gard, a spectacular chunk of preserved aqueduct that stretches across the Gardon river. For years I viewed this as a lost or not yet found place for wine, though it produces quite a bit of the stuff. Just to the east are the outer reaches of the Côtes du Rhône. The Estézargues co-op, from which we get quite a bit of good, everyday Rhône wine here in New York, is close to Argilliers on the road to Avignon. To the south is the Costières de Nïmes and to the west, the Languedoc. In essence, Uzès (and by extension my beloved Argilliers) is at the intersection of three major regions: Provence, the Rhône, and the Languedoc, and the local wines bear characteristics of all three: the sweet ripeness of Grenache from the Rhône, the garrigue-y wildness of Provençal wine, and the feral funk of Carignan from the Languedoc.  The closest wines in profile are those from the Costières de Nïmes, but even those seem to have slightly more alcoholic weight and prune-y dried fruit character than the wines of the Gard. Until very recently the Gard département did not have a single appellation controlée. The wines were labeled Vins de Pays and Vins de France. What does this mean? Many things… probably foremost that no one had considered the wines to be potentially profitable enough to bother wading through the bureaucracy of the appellation system. The basic white and red wines of the region, which come in bag-in-box format, are often based on non-native grapes: Chardonnay and Merlot.  To my knowledge the only Gard wines one sees in New York are from the Estézargues co-op and they are Chardonnay and Merlot featuring a pretty little line drawing of the Pont du Gard on the label.  The lack of appellations controlées in the Gard means that the wines have remained quite inexpensive, the priciest offerings at a any given winery being the “spoof” cuvées in which the lucky Grenache, Syrah, and Merlot blend is treated to fifty percent new wood. I have been drinking the local wines of the Gard for years while visiting Argilliers. The rosés make a lovely poolside beverage; the dry Muscats are a perfect accompaniment to outdoor ping-pong (low alcohol=better ping-pong game); the white wines, usually based on Viognier, Chardonnay, or Marsanne/Roussane/Grenache Blanc, are a good fit for the brébis cheeses from the market in Uzès, and dry, earthy Merlot does wonders for ratatouille of garden vegetables (not to mention “tyain,” a casserole of round slices of zucchini, eggplant, tomato, and goat cheese atop aromatic rice, liberally sprinkled with herbs de Provence). These are very much In Situ wines. When I was a novice I would lug home bottles of $4 rosé in an attempt to relive my Provençal vacation in North Carolina, but alas, just as Pastis tastes best in a dusty town square over a cutthroat game of pétanque, so do the wines of the Gard show infinitely better In Situ.Then a couple of things happened. M, my hostess in Argilliers and possessor of quite a good palate, began to buy wine at Domaine de Malaïgue in Blauzac. Certified organic since 1998, Malaïgue is different. The wines have lots of personality and seem to vary from the standard of cheap plonk for which the area is known. I took notice of the Domaine in 2007 and brought a bottle of barrique aged Syrah home with me. We drank it a year or so ago in North Carolina and it was loved around the table in spite of a slightly heavy oak presence. (Amusingly, a friend called several days later from a wine shop in North Carolina to ask what he was likely to find on the shelf that tasted like the Syrah from Malaïgue.)When I arrived in Argilliers a couple of weeks ago, our first stop was at Malaïgue to load up on bag-in-boxes for the house. We rumbled up an arid, dusty white gravel driveway on the ancient Roman road between Uzès and Nïmes, and alighted by an old wooden basket press now used as decoration. Malaïgue’s tasting room is a cavernous sub-chamber of their winery – located in a 12th century building – from which one sees the cement lined bétons they use to age the majority of their wines. At Malaïgue I learned that the villages around Uzès are on the verge of attaining appellation controlée status. Or, rather, France had approved the “Duché d’Uzès” appellation controlée, but the EU has not yet given its approval. From Wikipedia we learn that “the Duke of Uzès is the premier title in the peerage of France.” The Dukes of Uzès played a significant role in French history; I suppose you could say the name of the appellation is a tip of the hat to the Dukes of Uzès, all 21 who have been wounded or killed over the centuries as hereditary champions of France. As I tasted the wines at Malaïgue, picking out good white, pink, and red bag-in-boxes for the house, the germ of an idea graced my jet-lagged brain. Perhaps these wines don’t have to be In Situ wines after all.  The wine business in New York is a perennial quest for the as-yet-undiscovered. Perhaps it was time to “discover” something that had been right under my nose for years… The quest began to discover the regional typicity of wines from the Duchy of Uzès. I learned, for example, that under the new appellation controlée, Merlot would not be allowed, nor would Chardonnay. For red wines, Grenache, Syrah, and percentages of Cinsault, Carignan, and Mourvèdre are permitted. For white wines, Viognier, Marsanne, Roussane, Ugni Blanc, and Grenache Blanc. The following day we went to see Luc Reynaud in Saint Siffret, another village soon to be part of the Duchy of Uzès appellation. My hostess, M, is on a mission to convince local wine makers to convert to organics. She has spent years looking at the compacted, barren, unhealthy soil of her neighbor across Chemin des Barons in Argilliers, and she worries about what his weed killers and pesticides are doing to her own vegetable garden just a few yards away. At each Domaine she visits, good-natured banter that borders on interrogation ensues over the choice to be “bio” and, sure enough, M was ready with questions for Monsieur Reynaud, who is not organic but claims to practice “lutte raisonée” viticulture. I had tasted Reynaud’s wines before and liked them, but after Malaïgue’s wines, they seemed hollow, the reds too tannic and hot, often too oaky, the whites and rosés boring. I liked the man; he reminded me of the actor who plays Mozart in “Amadeus.” After blind tasting one of his pet projects, which I somehow divined as the Swiss grape, Petit Arvine, he began to take us seriously and he met our questions about his decision not to work organically with candor. The short answer is that his Domaine is 60 hectares and it’s hard to work that much land organically. My hunch is that no one is making money off the wines of the Duchy of Uzès and that organics is viewed as a venture that puts large portions of the production (thus the livelihood of the vigneron and his or her family) at risk if something goes wrong. I hate to be dogmatic about organics, but Malaïgue’s wines are better, and I’m sure chemical free farming contributes to their quality. Several days went by and I contemplated importing Malaïgue’s wines to New York. The more I thought about it, the more I liked it. So, on my last morning in France, on the way to the airport, I requested a ride to Blauzac. I needed to ask all the relevant questions (native yeast fermentation? how much sulfur? ex-cellars prices?) I also needed to find out whether the winery was interested to begin with.I met with the delightful Emmanuelle, who assured me that there was interest and offered me a brief tasting of all wines in bottle, as well as a list of tariffs, and a bag of lentils grown at the Domaine. At 12.5% alcohol, the first wine we tasted, “Le Fruit” stole my heart. This is a blend of Grenache, Cabernet, and Merlot that manages to be ripe and fruit forward but with the cool, sleekness of concrete élèvage.  The wine will not be recognized as “Duché d’Uzès” because of its portions of Merlot and Cabernet, but will remain a lowly Vin de France. The next wine, “Le Rond,” a blend of Grenache and Syrah was equally satisfying and possessed of more regional typicity in the form of spicy garrigue notes on the nose and a warm tone to the palate. We moved on to “Le Corpulent,” the Domaine’s sans soufre wine, a blend of Merlot and Cabernet. Sadly it had some of pickle and mousey-ness of natural wine and it wasn’t for me. Malaïgue’s delicious rosé “Petronille” is made from Grenache and Syrah and I have a suspicion it will travel well when the season for rosé approaches again. Of the Domaine’s group of whites, I am the most smitten by “La Blanche Fleur,” made from Viognier and Roussanne. This is a truly Mediterranean wine, with its notes of apricot from the Viogner and pine nut from the Roussane. With good acidity and reasonable alcohol, it's a wine that melts the ubiquitous antipathy toward southern French white wine.In answer to the relevant questions: Native yeast fermentation? Toujours. Save perhaps for the rosé; Emmanuelle did not know. Sulfur? 20 milligrams for the reds and slightly more for the whites. I was not bombarded by the egg-y, clenching, stifling present of sulfur; then again I’m not as sensitive as many. Prices? Let’s just say these wines are an absolute steal. Soon, I hope, we’ll have the opportunity to see if these wines transcend their “Situ:” the various villages surrounding the town of Uzès. Complex? Well…. not exactly, but delicious, real, and well put together with the help of over a decade of organic viticulture. I like to think they’ll strike a chord that carries further than the Pont du Gard and echoes beyond Nïmes to the south and Avignon to the east.

item.title: Le Marcel.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My life largely consists of insisting that I don’t like things only to discover that I actually do… like them… This is a trend I first noticed when my clever friend, FH, tricked me into liking Phish (the band); we were fourteen and I was a confirmed Phish hater. At this point I have only a vague recollection of Phish and their oeuvres, but I believe she put on “A Picture of Nectare” or “Rift” in the background of a lengthy gossip session. After ten or fifteen minutes, she asked me if I liked the music… and low and behold I did! What does this mean in terms of wine? For me it means learning that I sometimes like wines from hot, southern climates. Friends -- even trivial acquaintances -- know I’m a confirmed white, pink, and bubbly wine drinker, and the reds I drink are red wines for people who drink white wines: Poulsard, Burgundy, Beaujolais, etc… I waxed on about this at length in my post “14%,” so I’ll attempt brevity here. Tannins, Big Fruit, and high alcohol scare me and overwhelm the food I am generally eating. “Jamming,” senseless lyrics, and shapeless melodies offend my musical sensibilities, my need for tunefulness and order. I’m not closing in on a comparison between Marcel Richaud and Trey Anastasio, which would be ludicrous. I’ll leave it at this: there’s a time and a place for Phish, and there’s a time and a place for Cairanne. These days AR is the person most commonly responsible for opening my mind to big wines, and it was her Mourvèdre mission that brought us to Marcel Richaud’s Domaine in Cairanne on a blistering August afternoon. AR knew (I did not) that Richaud, known around the wine-obsessed world as “Le Marcel” adds more Mourvèdre to his blends than other southern Rhone vignerons. We desperately needed to find out why. And I hate to be suspenseful, but I'm going to leave the major Mourvèdre revelations to her. There’s an interview -- conveniently translated into English -- on the Louis/Dressner website.  Here one can read about Richaud’s history, motivations, vineyard work, cellar work, etc… The synopsis is that he decided to become a vigneron as a late teenager and began farming some hectares of his aunt’s vines. He then inherited and took over his father’s Domaine when his father retired. Richaud’s father sold to the cooperative, but the driven young Marcel wanted to make his own wine, according to his own principles, with his name on the label. He began working organically almost forty years ago, understanding that the very best wine is born from land to which the utmost respect has been paid. Interestingly, Richaud does not use fruit from his original parcels to make the wines labeled under his name. He prefers to seek out other parcels that have no attachment to his family, believing that his siblings have just as much of a connection to the family’s vines as he does. Instead he seeks out old vines and great terroirs within Cairanne on which to leave his mark as a vigneron. We began our visit with Richaud’s wife, Marie, a bright and good-natured woman who has clearly shown more than a few visitors around the Domaine in the absence of her husband. Denyse Louis had told me that we might catch a glimpse of Le Marcel but that it was unlikely. With 55 hectares of organic vines to farm and an impeccable reputation within the region and internationally to maintain, he’s a busy man. And did I mention that Marcel Richaud is somewhat of a spokesperson for natural wine? I’ll come to that later… First we went to the cellar, clean and cool, the walls built from stones from the Carrière de Vers by the Pont du Gard. Richaud has experimented with every type of vinification and winery technique under the sun, concluding that the things that matter most in the making of a great wine are yields, vine age, and terroir. Thus the wine-making is what I’d call “classical.” The lighter wines are aged in concrete while the more structured wines spend time in barrels. Sulfur additions are kept quite low and are sometimes non-existent. Overall the approach is one of low-intervention with the majority of the energy poured into vineyard work and attainment of the best possible fruit. What to say about this? It’s what I’ve been taught to think produces the best possible wine and tasting confirms the belief time and again. Back upstairs in the winery, Madame Richaud showed us a detailed map of the terroirs within Cairanne, explaining where “Terre de Gallets,” Cairanne Village, and “L'Ebrescade” come from. We chatted about the upcoming harvest and looked at some pictures on the computer from past harvests. She stepped away periodically to attend to other visitors, but always returned to us with renewed attention. We installed ourselves at a table overlooking the road to Vaison-la-Romaine and Vinsobres and I inwardly marveled that an airy stone house without air-conditioning could be so cool on a sweltering day. We began our tasting with 2011 Richaud Cairanne Blanc, a wine I did not know existed. The quantities are miniscule, which may account for its failure to show up in New York. This wine is made from Bouboulenc, Roussanne, Clairette, Marsanne, and Grenache Blanc grown on fine, sandy soil. The vines are 20 years old on average. Malheureusement, my notes do not contain the varietal breakdown. 10% of the juice is vinified in wood and the rest concrete, and there’s an open-topped maceration. I was blown away by this wine. The aromatics were extremely expressive: waxy, yellow fruits, apricots, orange peels, and a hint of nuttiness mingling gloriously. The palate showed a bit of alcoholic heat at 14%, but this was totally excusable given the wine’s respectable acidity and overall (for lack of a better word) Rhône-ish character. I hope I’ll have the chance to drink this wine again. Round about the time the first bottle of red was set in front of us, Madame Richaud was called away by another group of guests. We poured ourselves some wine: 2011 Côtes-du-Rhône “Cuvee Terres d’Aigues.” As we were sipping, scribbling notes, and chatting, we noticed a small, deeply tanned, white haired man enter the tasting room. After exchanging a few words with Madame Richaud, he came to our table. “Vous êtes Monsieur Richaud?” “Oui. Enchante” “On est vraiment très heureuse de faire votre connaissance.” The man behind the magic! We began to taste wine with Le Marcel and, as he grew increasingly comfortable with us, he opened up, and a discussion of many things dear to all of our hearts ensued. As always, it wasn’t just the wines that left their mark, it was the intelligence, vigor, and passion of the vigneron. “Terres d’Aigues” is a great majority of Grenache grown on alluvial soil. The wine is made using carbonic maceration; “like a Beaujolais,” Marcel told us. The wine was full of Grenache fruitiness and was surprisingly light on its feet given its 15% alcohol. The average vine age is 60 years here and, had I not tasted the wines to come, this bottle would have left a lasting impression on me. We moved on to 2011 Côtes-du-Rhône “Terres de Gallets,” a wine that takes its name from small pebbles in red clay soil called “gallets.” Comprising 40% Grenache, 30% Carignan, 25% Syrah, and 5% Mourvedre, this wine was more to my liking than the previous. The profile was darker and spicier, with more cassis and garrigue on the nose, perhaps more of a sense of place, more tannin to mask the wine’s robust alcohol percentage. Historically I’ve very much enjoyed “Terres des Gallets,” a wine that has integrity and a sense of place, but also a certain lightness and drinkability, challenging qualities to produce in a hot and arid terroir. At this point, AR began to interrogate Le Marcel about Mourvèdre. Let me say that it was a beautiful moment of bonding for both parties. Again, revelations to come... On to 2011 Cairanne. As though it existed to force me to challenge my palate and pre-conceived notions, this wine was excellent at 15.5% alcohol. With Grenache at 45%, 27% Mourvèdre, and the rest Carignan, Syrah, and Counoise, the wine was balanced! The vine age here is 40-70 years with yields at 30-40 hectoliters per hectare. The wine is 80% fermented in concrete and 20% fermented in barrel. Despite my fondness for “Terres des Gallets,” this Cairanne proved to be a minor revelation. Truly, the wine did not taste as though it was 15.5%! The alcohol was so well integrated, so finely knit into the soul of the wine, so exquisitely balanced by high-toned fruit and soil-y aromatics, that I barely noticed. (Then again, I was spitting. It might have rocked my world at the table.) Rarely in my tenure as a taster and buyer do I encounter an entire lineup of wines from a Domaine that impresses me, yet ultimately this is what we look for, because it is evidence of a truly superior winemaker. In Champagne, we hope that the grower’s basic, blended, non-vintage wine to be good, a harbinger of what is to come with the higher end wines. In Burgundy, we look for transparent and character-ful Bourgogne Rouge to come from prestigious producers of Gevrey and Chambolle. I was struck across the board at Domaine Richaud, not just by each wine in isolation but by the way each led to the next. “L’Ebrescade” is Le Marcel’s top wine and it’s raised in futs and demi-muids. The soil that gives this wine consists of very old sedimentary deposits. It’s a superior terroir on which Grenache, Mourvèdre, and Syrah are planted, listed in their order of prominence in the cuvée. The vines are between 20 and 50 years old and yields can be as low as 20 hectoliters per hectare. This is dark, black wine that is powerful but not giving, not easy, perhaps even obscure… until the finish, which is so lingeringly chalk full of blackberries that all of a sudden one comprehends the magic and the potential. By far the most coiled and complex wine in the lineup, Le Marcel recommended cellaring “L’Ebrescade” for ten years. And so our tasting came to a close, but our banter continued with gossip about other winemakers in the region and the inevitable question: “Avez-vous visité New York?” As it turned out Le Marcel and Madame had been to Chambers Street many years ago. I am convinced that the warmth of their reception had to do with their long-term relationship with Joe Dressner and Denyse Louis. As a final note, I’ll say that I was intrigued by Marcel Richaud’s thoughts on the subject of natural wine. He’s clearly in the movement; he’s a member of the AVN (Association des Vins Naturels). Yet he’s neither radical nor extremist. If anything his approach seems well-reasoned and calm. He pits natural wine against industrial wine and speaks of the natural wine “cause” as a worthy one. He also advocates putting an ingredient list on wine bottle labels, which would be truly incredible. This would allow us to steer clear of sulfur the way we steer clear of hydrogenated oils and high fructose corn syrup. And why not? If you’re really interested and a geek like I am, read this post on WineTerroirs in which Le Marcel defends natural wine against Michel Bettane, a well-known French wine critic. It'll make you think about the various ways big business endeavors to keep people drinking crap, and it'll make you grateful for people like Le Marcel who fight against industrial swill.
