item.title: An Original: Cédric Bouchard
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I’ve been meaning to write about Cédric Bouchard for over a year now, since my boss, JW, had me, our notable friend, Brooklynguy, our former Polaner sales rep, and a one co-worker over to drink all of the current releases of Cédric Bouchard’s wines. This took place last summer. 2008 Bouchard “Inflorescence” Blanc de Noirs was in stock even though 2009 had come in. We wanted to taste the two vintages next to each other; what a perfect excuse to open all the rest of the wines.JW made an amazing meal of poached swordfish with corn and peppers. This followed a summer vegetable risotto, which followed a chilled pea soup. It was a feast, and a feast done in a light, vegetable-rich style (my favorite kind of feast). What I remember best about the wines was that 2008 Inflorescence was better than 2009. I knew far less about Champagne at that point in time, but this contrast of the two vintages, the mineral and the fat, has come to mark my experiences with many Champagne producers’ wines. I also recall that the Rosé, a wine that essentially doesn’t exist (because it is incredibly rare and very expensive), was fantastic, though not an ideal match with fresh berries and crème anglais. Cédric Bouchard’s Rosé, which is only made in some vintages, comes from three rows of Pinot vines in a vineyard called “Creux d’Enfer.” The grapes are foot-stomped and left to macerate, yet the wine is feather weight for a macerated Rose. It’s exceptional… and its price is commensurate with its deliciousness and its rarity.What happened? Why didn’t I write about Cédric at that time? Because the wines sold themselves and did not need my long-winded prose to help them along. Or Brooklynguy did a better and more succinct job than I would have done… or other wines cried out for my attention and I wrote about those instead. In March I went to see Cédric Bouchard in Celles-sur-Ource, and, once again, I told myself I would write about him and once again I didn’t. This time the reasons were different, however. I could not figure out the tenor of my impressions, what stance to take regarding the man and his project. Over the course of the trip, it struck me that he was different than other Champagne vignerons, and it struck me that he was extremely cocky. Does it matter if he’s cocky? Not at all! In fact, I’d argue that a certain cockiness often goes along with brilliant winemaking. Fan-fan Ganevat is a cocky vigneron if ever there was one, yet he remains a favorite. I could tell that Bouchard, on the other hand, would never become a favorite. Writing about him would be complicated; it would involve mild criticism as well as praise. A few things of note to start: Cédric Bouchard makes wines in the Côtes des Bars, the Aube, southern Champagne, a region that traditionally assisted the more prestigious Grand and 1er Cru Villages further north in the Montagne de Reims with juice for blending.  The Aube has different soil than the sub-regions of northern Champagne. The chalk is further from the surface; there’s limestone, argilo-calcaire. In Domique Moreau’s village (Moreau is the winemaker at Marie-Courtin), Polisot, just a few kilometers from Celles-sur-Ource, the soil is almost black. The historically poor reputation of the Aube’s wine, its relatively inexpensive vineyard land, its different soil type, its proximity to Burgundy, all these things have attracted a series of young, rogue winemakers, and amongst them Cédric Bouchard is one of the best-known. If the Aube has developed a reputation as being the place for “hipster” Champagne growers, Cédric Bouchard and perhaps Bertrand Gautherot of Vouette et Sorbée exemplify this. I’ll never forget my other boss, DL, complaining bitterly about Gautherot’s sartorial choices at the 2010 Dive Bouteille; I think it was cowboy boots, skinny jeans, and a purple flowery shirt! How could someone attired accordingly possibly make good wine?!? Inconceivable. Cédric Bouchard looks like the lead singer for a boy band. He has a mop of tousled dark hair beginning to streak with gray, small, pointed features, scruffy facial hair, and a few creases around lively, hazel eyes are the only sign of his age, which I reckon is late 30s. He’s very cute. We had a bit of snafu finding one another in Celles-sur-Ource, throughout which Cédric was charming in the face of my mediocre French conducted through a crackly cell phone (not much reception in the suburbs of Bar-sur-Seine). I followed him to his winery, which is also his father’s winery, where a lengthy conversation ensued. I think I must have asked him about his history, because I got a detailed account of the past several decades of his life, events streaming along with the development of an ideology. (Please be lenient regarding any factual errors if you are better acquainted with Cédric than I; they are the result of a language barrier.) Cédric Bouchard’s father, who Cédric portrayed as quite a tyrant, sent him to winemaking school when Cédric was fourteen years old. He stayed there for four years, but he was unhappy. When he finished winemaking school, he went to Paris, where he worked as a caviste for four years. As a caviste in Paris, Cedric met quite a few vignerons working without chemicals, and he was inspired as well as struck by a difference in mentality, both from what he had grown up with and from what he had learned at school. I take it that the mentality Bouchard has chosen to rebel against is one that encourages high yields, chemicals in the vineyards, heavy manipulation in the cellar, and blending over terroir expression. This is standard issue winemaking in Champagne; it preferences commercial viability over a good product. Cédric’s desire was and is to make the best wine possible. When he returned from Paris to Celles-sur-Ource, he took over Les Ursules (a small vineyard close to the cellar planted to Pinot Noir) from his father and began to practice his own kind of winemaking. It’s noteworthy when discussing the style of these wines that Cédric Bouchard doesn’t actually like to drink Champagne. He, like several of my peers, finds the bubbles distracting; he recommends decanting his Champagnes. He prefers to drink Burgundy and Rhône wine, and he’d like to make a wine of terroir in California one day. (Good luck! Perhaps this is where Cédric and I parted ways in matters of taste. I love to drink Champagne, and I find an aversion to bubbles to be like an aversion to avocados: it’s a palate-level deal breaker. I know some people have texture issues with avocados, but those people are nuts!) The philosophy Cédric adopted was one of Pure Terroir Expression: he wants as little to come between the juice and the drinker as possible. This is the Burgundian ideal: to exactly preserve the character of each vineyard. To that end, all of his wines are from a single parcel, a single vintage, and a single grape. He does his fermentations in steel, believing that wood adds something that wasn’t there before. To me he described wood as being “like makeup.” (Interestingly, he is experimenting with Coteaux Champenois, which he puts in wood.) He never adds sugar to the wines, and they are bottled with less pressure than standard Champagnes (4.5 atmospheres versus 6.) For sulfur additions, there is one at harvest and one at the very end. The sulfur addition at harvest is to keep the juice from oxidizing. All the first fermentations are done with indigenous yeast, and the secondary fermentation with neutral yeast. He leaves the bottles in the cellar for years at a time without tasting them. I believe all but “Infloresence” spend at least three years aging on the lees. There is far more detailed information about all of these things on Peter’s site: Champagneguide.net, but most of you, if you’re taking the time to read my impressions, have probably referred to Peter’s excellent Champagne Guide many times before. Half of our conversation took place in the upper part of the winery, which contained many large fermentation tanks. I’m assuming they contained wine of Cédric’s father’s as well. At a certain point, I followed him to a dark, cold cellar, the walls lined with bottles on low racks. In the middle of the room were four open, unlabeled bottles. We continued to chat, topics ranging from Cédric’s belief that no one in the village understands what he’s doing, to his trouble working peacefully alongside his father, to the space he has found, at long last, to create his own winery. Cédric does practically everything on his own with the help of his wife, though there’s a guy who comes to plow, sometimes with a horse. He resists growing grapes; if anything he’ll reduce the land he farms. I’d encountered this attitude before; he’d prefer to be a winemaker than a grower. In the background, there was a desire for simplicity, yet this desire seemed pretentious. It’s just a feeling I got, the air of the hotshot winemaker. He referred several times to having “a big head,” and I gave him some credit for self-awareness. I also thought about the prices of his wines… I couldn’t help it. Are they worth what people pay for them, or do people pay because the wines are rare and incredibly well-hyped? First we tasted 2009 Inflorescence Blanc de Noirs from the Val Vilaine vineyard in the nearby village of Polisot. The wine was very ripe, not very bubbly, and quite delicious, though, as I said at the onset, I liked 2008 better with its sharper mineral cut. So, apparently, does Cédric, who has a preference for 2008 and 2002. One of the (many) things Cédric is known for is low yields, and this wine was harvested at 50 hectoliters/hectare. Then we tasted 2009 “Les Ursules,” labeled under Cédric’s “Roses des Jeanne” label. This is Cédric’s original wine, from vines wrestled away from his father over a decade ago. The wine had pleasing sappy, ripe fruit and extract. As it turns out it’s harvested at 30/40 hectoliters, which is low, low, low… I found a mouth-watering quality to the minerality in this wine that I normally associate more with chalk soil than with argilo-calcaire, which dominates in the Aube. I love this aspect of the wines; it accentuates their absolutely perfect dryness. Peter hit the nail on the head with the following statement borrowed from his website: “Although they are all labeled as brut, the wines don’t receive any dosage, and yet it’s not even a question about whether or not they need it: Bouchard’s wines are among those rare champagnes that feel perfectly, naturally secure in their dryness, and where the thought of dosage seems even bizarre, as if adding it to a red Burgundy.” Next came 2004 Inflorescence “La Parcelle” Blanc de Noirs, from a less than one hectare vineyard in Celles-sur-Ource that Cédric bought in 2007. Prior to his purchase of the land, Cédric made wine from La Parcelle beginning in 2004. This wine was exceptional, I thought, offering beautiful savory, herbal, minty notes on the nose and very high acidity consistent with the 2004 vintage. Of the four wines we tasted, this was the one that echoed in my mind, the wine I could have drunk all afternoon had I been permitted. Finally, we tasted 2006 Roses de Jeanne “La Bolorée,” a very rare wine made from Pinot Blanc vines planted on chalk in the 1960s. Previously I had not loved this wine. At JWs, we drunk 2004, and it left me cold next to the other wines with the fruit seeming waxy and flat next to the other wines. This time, I liked it quite a bit more, the chalkiness offering a nice counterpoint to the ripe, orchard fruitiness of the grape variety. At the end of our tasting, I walked out into the crisp sunshine to drive back to Troyes full of thoughts, but it wasn’t until the journey was over that I realized how different Bouchard was from other Champagne growers, in the details of his history, in his approach, even in his looks. I’d never kick one of his wines out of bed. They are superb wines, but I find it odd that he doesn’t like bubbles, that he associates himself heavily with Burgundy, that he doesn’t drink Champagne. And I find the prices of his wines, which are higher every year, prohibitive. Maybe I’m not so unlike my boss, DL, repelled by the hip-ness of the project as he was repelled by Bertrand Gautherot’s outfit at the Dive Bouteille. I guess at the end of the day, there are wines I’d buy first, like the humble Vincent Laval’s wines, for instance, which to an extent are made in the same style, yet feel somehow less pretentious. But that’s just me.There. Done. Over a year later, I finally came to terms with my visit to Cédric Bouchard.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Sophie Problem with so many wines is the multi-tiered distribution system with multiple margins, in some cases greater than what the winemaker gets for the wine. However don't get me started on that. When one takes into account Cedric's yields and tiny production the wines are pretty reasonable. My comment on the GC White Burgundy relates to the yields that Cedric works to with the Roses de Jeanne wines in that they are as low as those permitted for GC white Burgundy

Anne There is no denying that the wines are very serious and of the highest quality within their style. People may or may not like the style that is another matter. As noted in my other postings on this topic, if one takes into account the tiny scale production and very low yields the prices are perfectly justified. Also one should be aware of the ex House prices before slotting home the blame for high prices to the winemaker and accusing them of hoodwinking consumers. I have seen offers for his wines at the wholesale level that are double the ex House ( ie a profit margin as great as the person who has to produce receives to cover his investment, labour, materials etc etc) so the retail price is going to be distorted.

Hi Ian! Thanks for posting. I spent one morning with the man and am in no way qualified to make statements about his personality. I liked him very much and had a great visit to his Domaine. I actually just finished a snack of fresh favas with the last of a bottle of "2010" Inflorescence. I also had an excellent bottle of "La Boloree" not too long ago. Perhaps it's just a bit of jealousy and resentment that the wines are priced out of the range normal humans can enjoy, except of course for Inflor., which I drink several of every year and thoroughly enjoy. Cedric should go direct with a small importer in our area so that so many salaries aren't tied up in the price of his wines. When we poor wine shop employees purchase a bottle of Bouchard, we are paying the broker and importer and probably also the various portfolio managers and sales reps involved. It hurts a bit. But this is personal.
What do you mean when you say that the Roses de Jeanne bottlings would qualify for Grand Cru white burgundy? That is intriguing. If you have a minute, please say more...
Thanks,
Sophie

I know Cedric very well and you have definitely got the wrong end of the stick as to his personality. Whilst not lacking confidence in his ability he is very humble. Price wise one needs to take into account not only the scarcity but also the exceptionally low yields, the Roses de Jeanne cuvees would qualify for Grand Cru White Burgundy and are under half what is authorised in Champagne. Not everyone will like the wines as they do challenge the "common vision"of champagne. However the is a good thing otherwise there wouldn't be enough for existing fans and the prices would be even higher.

Thank you for a very interesting, well written and honest critique of Cedric Bouchard. You've put into words what I've been trying to understand about this producer. "Are they worth what people pay for them, or do people pay because the wines are rare and incredibly well-hyped?" Cedric Bouchard has succeeded quite well in marketing his product to all the "Parisien bobos" and their equivalent in other countries. Good for him ! But I'll take a lesser-known grower champagne, of which there are so many to choose from any day !

I really enjoyed this post (and its frankness). I had a bottle of les Ursules last New Year's Eve and, being one to follow instructions, decanted it -- but my wife hated me for doing so! The bottle was expensive and felt even less worth the expense when the bubbles quickly dissipated.

item.title: Hurrication 2012!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Down the road, when I reflect on the great hurricane of 2012: hurricane Sandy, I’ll think first about my friends at Red Hook Winery, who lost vast quantities of wine as well as their facility. Then I’ll think about Dhrubo, the wine buyer at Fort Defiance, a natural wine destination in Red Hook. As though honoring the name, the guys at Fort Defiance kept their doors open until the very last minute, giving people a place to eat and drink Chinon during the storm. Dhrubo as well lost a sizable amount of inventory, the labels on his bottles of Pfifferling and Lapierre defaced, the contents compromised. These are sad stories, and many hearts go out to our wine friends down in Red Hook who bore the brunt of the storm (that is on the east side of the East River). Then I’ll recall the five days of unplanned vacation that ensued for those of us who work in TriBeCa, where the power was out from Monday afternoon until early Saturday morning. Truth be told, many of us Chambers Street Wines employees would have come to work eagerly, riding our bikes, running, or walking across the Brooklyn, Manhattan, and Williamsburg bridges, but the electronic gate was down, sealing off the store for the duration of the power outage. We were stuck in our various Brooklyn homes, unaffected by the storm, yet essentially unable to commute as long as the subways were shut down. These were some of the finest days I’ve spent in New York, at liberty to roam around Williamsburg and Greenpoint, stopping at coffee shops and books stores, sourcing ingredients for hearty, cold weather meals, popping bottles with friends, losing to the downstairs neighbors at Scattergories, giving the cat endless amounts of attention. I wasn’t bored for an instant. Accustomed to a meager two or three weeks of vacation a year, I rarely have the chance to enjoy such leisure, and, I’m not going to lie; I enjoyed the heck out of it. There were two recurring themes to 2012 Hurrication: experiments with beans, and investigations of other wine stores. The first bean experiment revolved around the European Soldier Bean, so called because its markings are thought to resemble the kit of soldiers in the British army. Whatever. They looked like skinny black-eyed peas to me. Brief perusal of the back of the bag (acquired at Whole Foods) suggested that these were mild beans that would soak up any and all flavors. I opted for a Hoppin’ John style preparation, allowing me to hearken back to a dish my mom made at least once a year. After soaking, I cooked the beans with lots of thyme stems, rosemary, and bay leaves. While the beans were simmering, I made an aromatic base of onions, garlic, peppers, herbs, and paprika, to which I added wine, chicken stock, and brown rice. Since brown rice takes some time to cook, the rice and beans were finishing up at about the same time. Once mixed together and garnished with chopped parsley and the leftover feta cheese in my fridge, this was a substantial side dish, which became a tasty main dish the next day when I added chunks of chicken sausage. I don’t have a specific wine to site with this dish, though the open bottle of La Kiuva Val d’Aosta red that the downstairs neighbors were drinking worked well. (This is a well-priced, light-bodied Nebbiolo blend from a cooperative in north western, Alpine Italy.) I discovered that my Yankee friends with whom I dined that night (Monday, as the wind roared outside and rain spattered against the apartment) didn't know the tradition of consuming Hoppin’ John on New Years Day for good luck in the upcoming year. I reckon the Hoppin’ John style preparation of the stolid European Soldier Bean protected us against the raging storm outside, because we sailed through unscathed without a moment’s loss of power. My roaming around Williamsburg the next day took me to Vine Wine on Lorimer Street close to McCarren Park. This is a sweet little wine shop that should be taken seriously given its excellent inventory; I have only positive things to say about both their collection of wines and their customer service. I was in search of bubbles and settled upon Jean François Mérieau’s “Bulles,” a Loire Valley bubbly of which I have fond memories, but rarely drink. Jon-David Headrick, a fellow North Carolinian, imports this wine, and I enjoy his selections. JF Mérieau is a third generation winemaker in Touraine, who is seeking to improve the vineyard work of his father by converting to organic viticulture and making terroir-focused wines. Bulles comprises 80% Chenin and 20% Sauvignon Blanc; it acquires its bubbles though a méthode Champenoise second fermentation and has a small dosage of 4 grams. Also, the wine rests on the lees for 18-20 months, giving it texture. The choice was between this wine and the Bretons’ sparkling “Dillètante” and I could not have been more pleased with my choice. There’s a lovely vinosity to this wine; it has decided Chenin-y richness with waxy, golden fruits, a faintly honeyed character, and ever so slightly oxidative tones. This may seem abstract, but I was in the mood for a sparkling wine that was proud of its non-Champagne-ness. Also – I wanted a sparkling wine that would work with cheese, specifically a 24 month Comte. And, guess what? Lightly oxidative, sparkling Chenin is as good with a nutty, aged Comte as any Vin Jaune, in my humble opinion.The next bean experiment was with the Green Flageolet, acquired at Bedfood Cheese. This was recommended as a bean to use in cassoulet… that is after hunting down goosenecks and strange, fatty pig parts that I was unlikely to find two days after Sandy (if at all). The very helpful woman at Bedford Cheese suggested a bean soak I had never heard of involving bringing the beans to a boil, then turning off the water and letting them steep for a few hours. This worked well as the delicate, lima-like beans maintained their structural integrity after cooking. (As an aside, has anyone wondered why bean packages tell you to soak beans “overnight?” Does it really matter if they soak during the day or at night? Is there a diurnal temperature difference that affects the bean somehow?) No goosenecks or obscure pig parts at hand, I made a soup with finely diced potatoes, fennel, beans, and Red Russian kale, a tender and purple-stemmed version of the original. For my birthday back in September, JM gave me a beautiful chef’s knife made by Joel Bukiewicz of Cut Brooklyn in Gowanus. Ever since I received this carbon steel beauty, all I’ve wanted to do is dice… and my culinary choices reflect this.For the Flageolet soup, I picked a 2010 Trousseau from Overnoy-Cinquand. This Domaine has been the subject of much discussion over the past month. A new Jura grower in the Neal Rosenthal portfolio, Overnoy-Crinquand bears only the most distant relationship to the inimitable Pierre. Based in Pupillin, this is a five hectare Domaine that has been certified organic for some time now. Because of the strange and eternally frustrating sample policy of RWM, I had to buy these wines un-tasted and my first experience with them was frankly awful. The 2010 Poulsard from Overnoy-Crinquand was hopelessly reduced and vegetal in such a way that three days open couldn’t cure it of its malaise. I won’t dwell on this, however, because I am fond of the RWM team and I’m certain that they have already been amply reproached by buyers as well as the Internet for this bio-hazard of a wine. And, in any case, the Trousseau from O-C is absolutely delicious. The wine has abundant purple fruits and flowers such as violet and lilac, and is as lively and aromatically expressive as one could want a Trousseau to be. I won’t say that is was perfect alongside the Flageolet soup, which probably demanded a high acid and filigreed white wine, but it was a joy to drink in its own right.Day four of Hurrication saw a need for fresh greens, which are surprisingly hard to find in my neck of the woods. Thus in the early afternoon an enormous and heavy bike bag of produce from a farmer’s market on the upper west side was delivered to my door. I unloaded the bag to find not just market treasures, but also two bottles of wine sourced from notable uptown competitor, Crush Wines and Spirits. The wines were Benoït Lahaye Prestige Blanc de Noirs and 2009 Ganevat Savagnin Chalasses Marnes Bleues. What a dream come true.With such an array of treasures to work with that night, it was a challenge to know where to start. I made a little appetizer of sliced winter radishes sautéed in butter with a salad of micro-greens with shaved red onion, etc… this was for the Champagne. As you know, dear reader, Benoït Lahaye is one of my favorite Champagne growers; I will not elaborate here as I have already sung his praises in a previous entry. I will say, though, that this bottle showered excellently and, if anything, had gained complexity since I last tasted it several months ago. The aromas of fresh ginger and crushed raspberry that characterize the wine for me had given way to a more burnished, golden quality with the faintest oxidative whisper and a taught, long finish of mouth-coating, chalky mineral. The wine had begun to go in the direction of 2006 Lahaye, a powerful bottle that Brooklynguy and I had marveled over last fall. The finish was so impressive that I wondered if the base wine could be 2008, a stellar vintage in Champagne. I petitioned Joe Salamone of Crush for an answer, and he replied that he is still working with 2007 base. This bodes very well for this wine, which finds very nice balance at 5 grams dosage. The centerpiece of the evening, food-wise, was another stew, this time ampler than the Flageolet soup and ultimately more flavorful, laden with farmer’s market vegetables, notably cranberry beans, skin-on fingerlings, and spicy sausage. I served the soup in deep, wide bowls, with a chunk of toasted country bread underneath. I love toast and I don’t discriminate against soggy toast, especially when it’s lining the bottom of a bowl and soaking up salty broth, dense with vegetable flavors and nutrients. For sausage and cranberry bean soup, I picked another light red, this time 2007 La Grapperie “Adonis” Pineau D’Aunis. Grapperie is a contentious Domaine between my co-workers and myself. I love the wines… and none of my co-workers share this love. (In fact, my co-worker, JR, has gone so far as to call the Domaine “La Crapperie,” a giggle-provoking epithet.) I hear all the objections; it’s a fairly dense and extracted style of Pineau D’Aunis, the inherent deep, purple fruit, funk, and pepper of the grape showing a sweet-toned and tannic edge that speak of hefty extraction. In fact, I don’t know exactly how the extraction is done, but the wine comes from older vines and is aged in barrel for a year. This is a four-hectare Domaine started in 2004 by the young Renaud Guettier, who had very little winemaking experience when he started the Domaine. I maintain that these wines are getting cleaner and more delicious as time goes on. The 2007 Adonis was tasty, elegant; its herbal and vegetal notes harmonizing well with the food. The wine prompted an indignant tirade of “I don’t care what they say; I like these wines… and I don’t care who knows it.” I’ll stick by that statement, though I’m happy to acknowledge their faults and respect their critics. I reckon Jean-Pierre Robinot also makes extracted (and expensive) Pineau D’Aunis and somehow escapes comparable criticism. Oh well. To each his or her own in matters of Pineau D’Aunis. On day five of Hurrication, I walked across the bridge to Ten Bells, where I celebrated the return of power to the Lower East Side with natural wine personality: Fifi Essome. Not much to report; I was ready to go back to work and just in time; power came on at 148 Chambers Street early the next morning. In 1996, hurricane Fran blew through North Carolina, felling a tree on my Volvo as well as preventing me from going to see George Clinton and the P-Funk All-Stars at the Walnut Creek amphitheater, where The Mothership was allegedly supposed to descend upon humankind for the first time since the 1970s. I was devastated. In 2012, Sandy blew through New York, giving me a dream-like five days of vacation that stirred deep thankfulness in my soul for wines and foods, loved ones and friends.

item.title: Raspberry, Blueberry, Blackberry, Cassis
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: It is very hard to find time to write during the month of December. Easily the busiest time of the year for a wine retailer, we work long hours, six days a week; we subjugate our needs to the holiday needs of our customers. Everybody’s stressed out, burnt out, and often sick as well. After all, there are only so many germ-encrusted bills and credit cards one can (literally) handle, before a cold comes on. This is not actually a complaint; it’s a statement of fact, and an excuse for why my already spotty attendance at my own wine blog, is even spottier than usual. I’ll be back next year… in full form. On a positive note, this month I’ve drunk a handful of amazing red wines and I want to tell you about them. I’ll skip the usual long-winded attempt at creating some sort of theme to connect these wines, also the discourse on how I drink so much more white wine than red, and just give you the bottle label and tell you why I liked the wine.A few weeks ago, my co-worker, JFR, and I cracked a 2010 Lafarge Passetoutgrains “L’Exception” at the end of an evening at the shop. It was an absolute stunner and I immediately went back for a bottle to drink at home. Now, my experiences with Lafarge’s wines have been almost universally bad, save for the Passetoutgrains. I understand that Michel Lafarge is a masterful vigneron, but virtually every bottle of Burgundy I’ve had from this Domaine has been clunky and charmless, or else potentially cooked from poor storage (not that this is the Domaine’s fault, of course.) Lafarge’s Passetoutgrains, on the other hand, resonates in my brain as being the ultimate paradigm for this style of Burgundy, a blend of Pinot Noir and Gamay. (Incidentally, there’s a story floating around in my mind in connection with the Bourgogne Passetoutgrains appellation, namely that a king or a duke or some such Burgundian nobleman annexed the lowly Gamay grape from the hallowed slopes of the Côte d’Or in the 14th Century. I’d love to know if this is correct, and all wikipedia tells me about the history of Passetoutgrains is that it gained appellation status in 1937.) At any rate, 2010 Lafarge Passetoutgrains “L’Exception” is a memorable, beautiful wine, the kind of wine that elicits swearing and absolute silence in alternation. The nose is marked by notes of raspberries and earth, the palate by raspberry seeds happily mingling with the wine’s crunchy acidity. There’s a certain desirable austerity at first that gives way to a more forward profile after half an hour open. For me the most compelling aspect of this wine is the way the palate unfolds to reveal crushed herbs and lightly bitter notes of fruit pit. There were a host of flavors on the palate that were not announced by the wine’s aromas. Over the course of a few hours, the wine proved to be so utterly gorgeous that I had to call on my downstairs neighbors to come up and keep me from single-handedly polishing off the bottle. JR (not to be confused with JFR) had been waxing on about Georges Descombes 2011 Brouilly for some time. With such a beautiful label and such a resounding endorsement, how could I resist trying one?LDM’s website tells me that Georges Descombes is the unofficial 5th member of the Gang of Four (not the post punk band, but rather the group of four Morgon vignerons responsible for the most succulent, carbonic-ly macerated, low-sulfur Beaujolais.) Interestingly, I had thought that the Gang’s fifth member was either Jean-Claude Chanudet of Domaine Chamonard, or the notoriously bad-tempered Yvon Métras in nearby Fleurie. Oh well, I will bow before the far more extensive knowledge of the folks at LDM. When I asked my boss, DL, about Georges, he replied “Georges is a real farmer; he’s got huge hands from working in the vines.” It might take knowing DL to realize what a compliment this is. Certainly, Descombes is not spoken about as reverentially as Lapierre (the father of it all) and Foillard (perhaps most praised at this point.) Yet Beaujolais geeks recognize the quality of Descombes wines, which are certainly a steel at $23 and $24 when Foillard’s are hitting the shelves at $38-$40 these days… Descombes (who, if the pictures on Bert Celce’s website, wineterroirs, are to be believed, looks like an early Martin Amis character, or an East Enders hero) farms around 15 hectares, majority in Morgon, some in Brouilly, Régnie, Chiroubles, and generic Beaujolais and Beaujolais-Villages. In fact I associate this man most with his young vines Régnie, Morgon, and Chirouble: vibrant, juicy, red-fruited Beaujolais. Brouilly is a Beaujolais Cru I often steer clear of because the vines frequently have more structure and a darker, grapier, brooding character that bodes well for the cellar but isn’t what I’m looking for. In this case, the wine was both purple-fruited, with tangy, wild blueberry and juniper notes on the nose, and incredibly lithe and slurp-able. What really got me about the wine was its texture. I can only describe it as “sleek,” yet “sleek” seems to have connotations of chocolate-y new wood, reverse osmosis, smooth tannins, etc… This wine was velvety soft in the mouth, but with bright acid, and a streak of earthiness running horizontally through from nose to finish. It’s difficult to describe, but once one has acquired a taste for this soft, flower petal texture in red wine, bolstered and balanced by lively acidity, it’s very hard to go back. Domaine Louis Magnin was, at one point, imported by Louis Dressner. Then the Domaine went missing for awhile. Within the past year, Magnin was picked up again, this time by Rosenthal Wine Merchant. In fact, I asked Kevin McKenna of LDM about Magnin recently, and he told me that they stopped working with the Domaine several years ago on the grounds that Magnin adds neutral yeast for fermentation rather than relying on native yeasts to complete the process. How much do we care about this? Well… I suppose the answer is that if the wine is good, not much! Of course, RWM boasts that all of their producers use wild yeast, which raises a whispered doubt as to their own integrity, but what do I know? There’s ample backbiting and sniping between importers; perhaps Kevin was not the best person to ask about Domaine Louis Magnin. On the RWM website, I came across this statement: “In Arbin, the Domaine Louis Magnin surfaces to the top as does the richest cream.” I found this metaphor apt because the white wine I recently tasted from Magnin: Roussette de Savoie, tastes a bit like the richest cream. It’s a dense, honeyed, layered, incredibly delicious wine, a lot of wine, a wine to share and savor, and drink on special occasions.  But this entry is about their red, Arbin Mondeuse.Mondeuse can present itself in a variety of ways; my favorite Mondeuses taste as though Syrah and Gamay took a walk through the Alps together and returned home melded into an herby, tangy, fruity, smoky unit. This one amply delivered, offering blackberry and blackberry seed notes, licorice, the faintest hint of what I suspected was wood, also delicious Alpine smokiness culminating in a very mineral finish. The fruit came out with some air and by the time the wine had been open for an hour, any tightness had loosened and the wine was joyous in the extreme. (Again, I had to call on the neighbors to save me from myself.) The grapes that go into this wine are from various parcels in Arbin; they are de-stemmed and macerate for twelve days before moving to a combination of stainless steel and old wood. Buy some and cellar it… I bet it’ll be great in a few years, but drink one now, too. It’s costly at $33, but it offers more than its less expensive brethren, at least according to my palate. I didn’t actually know how CSW came to import the wines of Domaine Pierre Gonon in Saint-Joseph until very recently, when writing this blog caused me to ask DL how such a thing came about. And, of course, the answer was quite simple: “I called him up and said I wanted to buy some wine. “ If only all ventures into the world of direct importing were so simple. This was an extremely fortunate event for Chambers Street Wines because Gonon’s wines are superb, and by circumventing the importer, we can offer them at superb prices. Les Ils Feray comes from vines within Saint-Joseph that are not included in the Domaine’s Saint-Joseph. About 120 cases are produced a year, and our lot is sought after by our customers to the extent that we have to allocate it.A couple of days before Christmas, EL opened a bottle of 2011 Les Ils Feray at work (Sometimes we do taste and even swallow wine at work. Shhh. Don’t tell anyone.), and forgot the open bottle on top of stack of boxes waiting to be delivered the following day. I was the lucky beneficiary. After a few hours open, the wine showed beautifully. The nose was all high-toned earth and almost vegetal, peppery Syrah fruit. It was like having a pencil and a prune under my nose at once. The palate was sleek and perfectly balanced with the faintest layer of mouth-coating tannins, an almost porous minerality, and a fresh draft of acidity. I love Syrah, and sometimes when I drink northern Rhône Syrah, I think about that evanescent quality of fruit fusing perfectly with place. It’s worth paying attention when a wine tells you where it’s from loudly and clearly, because even in the specialized, highly geeky wine world I inhabit, it’s not every wine that does this. Here you have it: my experiments with red wine drinking. If you can, seek out these bottles. All afford an enormous amount of pleasure. Happy New Year to all... more in 2013!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: From the Wikipedia page on Gamay: In July 1395, the Duke of Burgundy Philippe the Bold outlawed the cultivation of the grape, referring to it as the "disloyal Gaamez" that in spite of its ability to grow in abundance was full of "very great and horrible harshness",[4] due in part to the variety's occupation of land that could be used for the more "elegant" Pinot Noir. 60 years later, Philippe the Good, issued another edict against Gamay in which he stated the reasoning for the ban is that "The Dukes of Burgundy are known as the lords of the best wines in Christendom. We will maintain our reputation".[5] [4] Lichine, Alexis (1967). Alexis Lichine's Encyclopedia of Wines and Spirits. London: Cassell & Company Ltd.. pp. 158. [5] Hugh Johnson, Vintage: The Story of Wine pg 134. Simon and Schuster 1989
I want to be the third wheel in Syrah and Gamay's Alpine journey. Very poetic post. These wines sound delicious!

Ross! Thanks so much. That is what I remember learning about Gamay being annexed from Burgundy, but it's a story I've told so many times in connection with Passetoutgrains that I've forgotten the source. Did you try the wine? It got the Culang stamp of approval!!
Cheers,
Sophie

Ben - I'm sure your friendly Rosenthal Wine Merchant sales person would be happy to send you some Magnin Mondeuse... It's not exactly an easy sell, but worth ordering half a dozen bottles just to drink and sell to your most beloved eastern French wine geeks.
Cheers,
Sophie

Another fine post, Sophie.
The history of Gamay is an interesting one. The first edict against Gamay was not because of the poor quality of the wine it made, but rather it's abundance. It grew easily and in such quantity that it made wine for the common people, not just the royalty, hence the "disloyalty".

item.title: A Wine Lover Discovers Vermouth
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Every wine person I know goes through periods of waning enthusiasm for wine. It doesn't detract from one's ability to work and play in the business, nor does it lessen the charms of a great bottle. It merely means temporarily yielding to the rejuvenating properties of other alcoholic beverages. Not being much of a beer drinker, save for an occasional Budweiser by the old rustic swimming hole in North Carolina, I'm left with booze. Unfortunately I'm also not much of a booze drinker (save for the occasional ill-advised tequila shot and, really, I'm too old for shots.) Now what am I left with?I find that my drink proclivities are informed by alcohol percentage. Too little alcohol and I get bored; too much alcohol and I get drunk. I like my drinks to weigh in at the alcoholic strength of wine... and guess what what delivers in this regard? Vermouth! Vermouths: fortified wines flavored with botanicals such as roots, barks, herbs, flowers, spices, and seeds, are generally around 16% alcohol, then you add a little ice and you've got yourself a tasty beverage that delivers a welcome respite from wine. Over the past few weeks, beginning with my annual December chest cold, Vermouths (and related tipples) have become my post work drink of choice. I realize I'm way behind the times. Various friends of mine have been extolling the virtues of Vermouth for ages. Also my mom used to drink it, though she drank it dry and with a twist of lemon. Oh well. Better late to the party than never in attendance at all. My introduction to the world of Vermouth took place about a year ago in North Carolina with some Yankee ex-pats living in Durham who have a full cocktail bar set up in their apartment. We were getting ready to go to dinner and I wanted a relatively mild aperitif that would leave plenty of room in my wine slot for all the Burgundy that was to come. I'd been curious about Carpano Antica Formula for some time, but the large, 1 liter bottle is kind of a commitment. Here was an opportunity for a taste with zero commitment. Low and behold, Carpano was magically delicious and I went back for seconds. To this day (and several home bottles later) I still love the vanilla, caramel, and rum raisin complexity of Carpano, made in the Piedmontese city of Turin from a recipe that allegedly dates back to 1786. It's a rich, sweet, almost oaky Vermouth with pleasing, burnt orange, citrusy acidity and a mellow hint of bitterness on the finish. Carpano is a soothing and luxurious beverage, and it's not monochrome like a plush, oaky wine. There are layers of flavor that deliver something a little bit different with each sip. One sip you'll taste a prune, the next a vanilla bean, the next a proper British marmalade... It's surprisingly hard to find out about Carpano Antica Formula; their ancient recipe is well-guarded. On a website I discovered while researching called Eat.Drink.Think, I learned that Carpano is made by the Branca distillery. Are these the same folks who make Fernet, the wonderfully bitter digestif that has recently and mysteriously taken the world of hipster beverages by storm? It's certain that no two bitter herb inflected brews could be less similar than Fernet and Carpano. Who knows? Eat.Drink.Think's author describes himself as having been put in "a pleasure haze" by Carpano Antica, and I get the vaguely Coleridge-ian reference ; there's an almost opiate quality to the stuff and I have friends who claim they can go through a liter in a day. However, I've noticed that I only really love Carpano when I've got a sore throat and am craving its plush silky sweetness like a fortified cough drop. When I'm healthy, Carpano is ever so slightly cloying. Next time you've got a cold, try my remedy: one small glass Carpano on ice with a lemon wedge and one large mug South African Rooibos tea. This full-bodied and earthy non-caffeinated tea makes a delightful companion piece to Carpano. Then get to bed! And when you're better, move on the slightly more ballsy Vermouth.After my last home bottle of Carpano, JR, our spirits buyer at Chambers Street, ordered me to branch out. He suggested that I try Cocchi Vermouth, also from Torino, one of two recognized appellations for Vermouth. Apparently Guilio Cocchi, founder of the Cocchi business, was an enterprising Florentian who moved to Piedmont in the late 19th century to distill as well as to make the Asti Spumante. I never would have guessed it based on the flavor profile, but Cocchi's sweet, red Vermouth is based on Moscato! Brighter and less oak influenced than Carpano, Cocchi offers more cocoa and mint, darker, cooler tones than Carpano. At the same time it's lightly oxidative, giving the faintest hint of what an acquaintance of mine would call "tootsie roll." The oxidation also comes out on the finish with a note of walnut. Neither better nor worse than Carpano, it depends on what you're in the mood for.My first taste of Cynar was at Huckleberry Bar, a fantastic cocktail spot on Grand Street in Williamsburg. I am the antithesis of a cocktail geek; cocktail culture has always seemed quite pretentious to me. After all, my favorite alcoholic beverages are made by rustic French peasants with callouses and dirt under their nails, not impeccably groomed young men wearing unnecessary suspenders and gel in their mustaches. Nonetheless, I love the good people at Huck, and I try to order a cocktail or two each time I go there. The day after my 30th birthday, my best North Carolina friend, SS, and I wandered into Huckleberry Bar, atrociously hungover, in search of bitter refreshment. (I think S might literally have said something like "I need Chinato NOW, Sophie." (More on Chinato later...)) Neither of us had tried Cynar and this seemed like an opportune time.Produced by Gruppo Campari, a beverage conglomerate with 40 spirits in their portfolio, Cynar is an aperitif that is flavored with artichokes. This raises an interesting question: why is Cynar considered an aperitif rather than a Vermouth? Is Vermouth a sub category of aperitif the way Cognac is a sub category of brandy? Must Vermouth be from either Torino or from Chambéry to properly be considered Vermouth? Cynar is a dark brown, dense (but still only 16.5% alcohol), fairly intensely bitter, herb-y liquid that makes Carpano Antica taste like a Starbucks caramel macchiato. It's bracingly delicious on ice with a lemon wedge, and also makes a good cold remedy alongside a cup of Rooibos, but possessed of more "adult" flavors than Vermouth di Torino. When I first moved to New York about five years ago, I had the good fortune to be taken to dinner at Convivio, an Italian restaurant in Tudor City that, as I recall, specialized in the wines and foods of southern Italy. The sommelier was Levi Dalton, a fiery wine personality who has done much to enliven our business in various ways. At the end of the meal, which, incidentally, was lubricated by the bracing, Volcanic wines of Taurasi, Levi poured us each a flight of five Amari (Amaro=a spirit-based digestif flavored with bitter herbs). On this occasion, my palate was opened up to a brave new world of flavor. Bitterness is something we come to appreciate as we grow up; I'm almost tempted to say that our appreciation for bitterness waxes as our appreciation for sweetness wanes, but I know too many Riesling and Reese's Cup-heads to make this proclamation. I'll just say that as I've grown up, bitter and sour have taken over my brain, leaving less challenging flavors like sweet behind... This brings me to Mauro Vergano's Americano, a Grignolino-based aperitif that makes Carpano and Cocchi and Cynar seem simple. Vergano, an extremely kind and amusing man (This isn't conjecture; I've had the great pleasure of meeting him once or twice), worked as a chemist before obtaining an oenology degree and eventually beginning to make Chinati. As a chemist, he was a specialist in flavors and fragrances and it was this training that allowed him to become a master in the art of "aromatized" wine. In an interview with the lovely folks at LDM, Vergano's importer, when asked whether he views his Chinato as more "traditional" and his Americano as more "modern," he points out that his Americano draws on the traditions of the region as well, the tradition of Vermouth. Most of the time, Vermouth is based on a low quality white wine; Chinato, however, is based on Barolo, the greatest red wine of northwestern Italy. Chinato takes its name from "cinchona" or quinine, the predominant flavor. Does this make Chinato a kind of sub-category of Vermouth? A valid question.Vergano's aromatized wines are based on Moscato (Luli), Grignolino (Americano), and Nebbiolo (Chinato). In each case, the resultant Vermouth takes the category to a heightened level of fineness and complexity. Americano is beautifully ruby colored in the glass with the faintest pink gleam. The flavor of quinine is complemented by a note of sweet grapefruit, exotic cardamon, anise, and licorice. Perhaps my favorite part is the tannins on the finish. Grignolino, a wine with lots of zesty tannins from the seeds of the grape, gives a kind of fresh tannic structure to the Vermouth. Thus the wine itself seems to be more then just a base; the wine informs the profile of the aperitif. Drink Vergano's Americano on its own, with ice, with ice and citrus, with ice, citrus, and sparkling water. Any way you drink it is sheer pleasure. If every break from wine lead me to something as remarkable as Vergano's Chinati, I would take more breaks from wine.... Salut! -Sophie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I would suggest trying some American vermouths like Imbue or Vya next time. Also, in the aperitif realm, I am very partial to Pineau des Charentes from Pierre Ferrand. Northern Spy had a different variety that was okay, just not as good as Pierre Ferrand's.
Bravo! Lately I have been getting my Amaro drink fix at Reynard's. They seem able to make different versions all night long!

item.title: The Viticultrice.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Even as I begin to write this I wonder why I’m writing it and I gently chide myself for such silliness, because this piece of prose can only mean less of these remarkable wines for me to drink. I guess there are some experiences that simply cry out to be documented in spite of one’s own best interests. I began buying Marie-Noëlle Ledru’s wines from Bonhomie Wine Imports at least four years ago when I was working at Astor Wines in the east village – a resounding thanks to Charlie Woods for the introduction. At the time the wines were virtually unknown in New York. Charlie talked me into them, untasted, on the grounds of the story of a woman with very few hectares of vines and virtually no help in the winery or cellar, doing everything herself including riddling and disgorgement. Who could resist? I remember that the first bottle I drank was her Blanc de Noirs, Cuvée Goulté, but I don’t recall the vintage. I liked the wine, but I didn’t get it. I wasn’t quite ready. Let’s just say I’m ready now…Over the past few years – that is since my Astor days – the scarcity and the quality of Marie-Noëlle Ledru’s wines have become commensurate. Interestingly, the prices of her wines have remained extremely reasonable all things considered. In truth, I receive a fraction of the allocation I used to. It’s as though someone tipped off the world: “Hey! That lively little woman in Ambonnay is making insanely good Champagnes and they are a steal!” This may sound like a complaint, but it’s not, really… I cannot sufficiently reiterate that Marie-Noëlle Ledru’s wines deserve every ounce of attention and praise they garner. As her Domaine became much smaller in 2010, meaning that there’s less wine than ever before, I only wish there was more to go around. I recently returned from my third pilgrimage to Champagne and, within this trip, my second visit to Marie-Noëlle Ledru. While I was charmed at my first visit, I was truly blown away at my second. I attribute this to experience. The more Champagne I taste, the more readily I spot wines of true excellence. Let’s put it this way: there are quite a few very good Champagne growers, but Ledru’s wines are utterly distinct and in a class all their own. Amongst our little group of travelers, Marie-Noëlle became a heroine; no other grower we tasted with was so well-showered in unanimous respect and adoration. After our meeting, she was good enough to send us on our way with a couple of bottles, which meant that stressful and cold days of tasting were promptly addressed at the onset of the evening by a wine from The Viticultrice, shared between five in front of a toasty fireplace. The back story: Ledru makes wine in the southern Montagne de Reims in the Grand Cru village of Ambonnay, known for its powerful and vinous Champagnes based on Pinot Noir.  She is a second generation vigneronne, as her father settled in the region in the ‘60s and founded the Domaine. She has been the “viticultrice” since the 1980s. Once six hectares in total (one in the neighboring village of Bouzy), the Domaine is now only two, managed by Marie-Noëlle herself. The vineyards are tended without chemicals and herbicides, but she has no wish to become certified in organic viticulture. In remaining uncertified, many essentially organic estates reserve the right to use a chemical if it’s necessary to save a crop. When a livelihood depends on production, who am I to argue? In the cellar, Ledru’s base wines are raised in steel and using a neutral yeast for fermentation. I was slightly startled by these facts when I learned them, only because Ledru’s wines have such texture and power that I expected the base wines to be fermented in wood. Apparently the inherent power and electric current running through these wines, giving their family resemblance as well as their distinction from all other wines, comes from outside the cask. All wines are allowed to go through malolactic fermentation, a process I am becoming increasingly approving of for several reasons, which I’ll detail here though it’s a digression: Normally stopping malolactic fermentation requires a fairly hefty sulfur addition. Several growers I spoke to about this quoted me 60-70 milligrams to stop malo, which means that, given other sulfur additions (such as at pressing, disgorgement, etc…), the resultant wine will likely contain 100 milligrams of sulfur by the time it reaches your table. I have no wish to beat a dead sulfur horse, but I don’t like the way sulfur tastes and smells. Furthermore, the reason many Champagne growers block malo is that they like the zippy malic acidity in their wines. However, if a grower is working the soil, plowing, eschewing herbicides, etc… the wine will have more than sufficient acidity to carry it through malolactic fermentation with balance and – dare I say – aplomb. It all goes back to the vineyard. And this is not mere speculation or inference based on my feeble palate; it’s born out by PHs, but for that information you must petition Benoït Lahaye or Vincent Laval, but enough, back to Marie-Noëlle… The wines are aged between three and six years on the lees and disgorgement is done by hand… Marie-Noëlle’s hand, that is.  I have had the good fortune to watch MN disgorge twice now. She makes it looks easy, effortlessly flicking the capsule into a plastic disgorging bin with a wrench before lifting her thumb to allow the yeast to fizz out of the top of the bottle. On the occasion of my second visit to her Domaine, I was further impressed to see her roll back her sweater sleeves to apply freezing cold hose water to the disgorging chamber as well as the winery floor. Not to belabor a point, but it was about 20 degrees outside; the ground was blanketed in snow, and the five of us were looking on in our down jackets and hats whilst blowing our cupped hands and scrunching our toes further into our wool socks and boots.This brings me to my impressions of the woman. There are many types of winemaker, from the gentleman winemaker to the humble farmer to the master of his universe (see future blogging on Pascal Agrapart, who is a paradigm of this type).  Possessed of a soft spoken and jovial demeanor, Marie-Noëlle is the soul of humility, yet the soul of confidence and fortitude. When asked questions such as “have you changed the way you do things much over the past two and a half decades,” she’d reply with something to the effect of “not much, but I’ve found ways to do things with less intervention…” the answer delivered in a tone of vague amusement as though to say “the wines will speak for themselves; I’m just here to open the bottles.” She was the only grower I encountered on this trip who left lists of available bottles on the table in her tasting room so that a visitor could purchase a few if he chose. I find this practice to be quite old school, yet incredibly respectful of the visitor. She could sell everything tomorrow if she wanted to… We began our tasting with MN’s Extra Brut, a bottle that had been disgorged for two months. The cépage here is 85% Pinot and 15% Chardonnay and the wine is half and half 2006 vintage and reserve wine. The slightly older vintage and reserve wine suits the Extra Brut style, and the wine gives an impression of maturity along with its rich, shelly character and bone dry, chalky finish.Next was tasted a 2002 Ambonnay Brut Nature, a wine I had tried once before. The same cépage as the majority of MN’s wines (80/15 – Pinot/Chard), my notes read “grippy,” a quality her wines share across the board. Think of this as a comment about their finishes, which lay a lingering coating of chalk across the drinker’s tongue. I continue to question the lack of dosage in this wine, though my compatriots loved it. A faint voice crept in wondering what it would have been like with a gram or two… MN’s 2010 base Brut Reserve brought us to the question of 2010 as a vintage; MN reported that it was challenging but very good, a recurring review of 2012 as well, a vintage in which quality is high but quantity is very low. Brut Reserve and 2007 Ambonnay, which followed it, are both dosed at 6-7 grams and feel impeccably balanced. In the past, I’d have said this is high for me, but dosage is a slippery bugger and its role is to balance the wine, to enhance aromatics, to help the wine age, and well-chosen dosage will make a wine feel effortlessly balanced. I rarely assert a preference for low dosage wines these days. I will say, however, that MN’s wines seem drier than they are, which is likely due to their mouth-watering acidity and intense minerality. 2008 Cuvée Goulté Blanc de Noirs, from older, mid-slope vines offered a rush to my midpalate, highlighting the ripeness and high acidity of the vintage. The word “Goulté” is an old Champenois word for the best juice from the press. I’ve heard Goulté described as a single vineyard wine, but it’s from a selection of parcels. Delicious in every vintage, this wine is an achievement in 2008 and it’s so powerful and tightly coiled that it will assuredly age for quite some time.We moved on to Rosé. 2010 base Rosé d’assemblage was very dark in the glass with 15% red wine. Intense and hardly fruity, I liked the wine very much though it paled in comparison to the 2008 Rosé de Saignée. Macerated for 13-15 hours on the skins, this is, essentially, a red wine with a deep sense of earth and chalk mingling with cranberry and tart, wild strawberry fruit.At this juncture, I asked what happens to MN’s Rosé wines with age and had the good fortune to find out. I inquired because I believe that, though fine Champagne can generally age for quite some time, it’s often so pleasurable young that aging it is a question of taste, an instance of what I like to call “just because you can doesn’t mean you should.” Unlike Mathieu Baudry’s Chinon “Croix Boisée” or “Le Bourg” from Clos Rougeard (I am using these examples from Domaines I recently visited though there are, of course, countless examples), which are virtually undrinkable young, structured Champagne turns out to be absolutely delicious young. So why age? MN left us for moment following my query and returned with two bottles. The first, 2005 base Rosé d’assemblage, was the only wine of the tasting that wasn’t great. It has been disgorged for two years and was oddly reduced with a funky fruitiness and a marked lack of cut. We’ll blame the vintage, which was not the best. The wine was followed by a stunning 2004 Rosé de Saignée, which gave me more than an adequate sense of where these wines go with time. Savory notes and cranberries emerged from the glass along with an irony minerality and a hint of drying red berries.  MN told us that she had macerated the grapes longer than usual in 2004, a vintage that produced grapes of more color. It was a tour de force that made me wish I had more patience and a proper cellar.We finished the tasting with three very special bottles. The first was a Blanc de Blanc that MN only made in 2004. It was a toasty and laser like wine that was especially zesty as it had just been disgorged, which gives the bubbles a certain manic quality. Our penultimate wine was a freshly disgorged Ambonnay from 1986, MN’s first vintage. What a treat! This wine was astonishingly youthful, mineral, and energetic after many, long years aging on the lees, and the finish was incredibly long, yeasty and chalky. An intriguing foil to the ’86, our last bottle was a 2000 Ambonnay that had been disgorged since the mid 2000s. Having been off its lees for over half a decade, the wine was quite evolved with the mellow, nutty salinity of mature Champagne. It was a stately wine, the bubbles having receded, and it seemed to provide closure to our tasting. We sat around the tiny table in MN’s cozy tasting room taking in the aroma of grape vines smoldering on the fire.

item.title: Coplanted: A Tribute to Ancient Variety Champagnes.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My apologies in advance for the lack of pictures in this post. Many of these wines "don’t exist;" therefore no bottle images are available. It’s very cool in Champagne these days to make a wine out of the old, “forgotten” (but apparently now remembered…) Champagne grape varieties: Arbanne, Petit Meslier, Pinot Blanc, Pinot Gris. Often these grapes are coplanted with Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Pinot Meunier, and the winemaker chucks everything in the press together rather than fermenting each separately. This trend seems consistent with an overall nostalgia that is presently sweeping the brainscape of Champagne, a mild rebellion against technological winemaking. Manifestations of this trend include words such as “Autrefois” and “Antan” popping up on wine labels, vignerons choosing old barrels rather than stainless steel or enamel for fermentation, horse-plowing. Of course this is a gross oversimplification and I’m not suggesting that growers who plow with horses or use barrels are trying to be anachronistically cool. Horse-plowing promotes airy soil; barrels in the cellar give texture to the vins clairs, etc…  In general I think this backward hearkening is just fine and I’m particularly curious about the use of ancient varieties. Vignerons like to play, and these Champenois “others” provide an opportunity to do so. After tasting ancient variety wines from Agrapart, Bérèche, Laherte, Lahaye, Tarlant, and Olivier Horiot, I have some observations. When discussing their ancient variety wine, winemakers consistently refer to a law in the Champagne region according to which ancient varieties can only be planted in a vineyard that was previously planted to those varieties. I’m in desperate need of clarification regarding this law. Does it mean no new vineyards of Arbanne, Petit Meslier, etc… can be created? Why? It would seem that if these grapes are allowed by the appellation, then they’re allowed to be planted freely along with the standard three: Chardonnay, Noir, Meunier. I’ll have to contact Peter Liem, or the fabulous Marie-Pascal, who works for the CIVC (Champagne’s governing body) for more information… In researching, I went straight to Peter’s blog, where I found an interesting quote from Pascal Agrapart in Avize about his reasoning behind a coplanted vineyard: “When you harvest and press these grapes together, they cancel each other out, so you have much less varietal character, revealing more of the minerality." The entry goes on the describe the general impression of ripeness given by these coplanted wines as opposed to the clear varietal character of a Chardonnay or Pinot based wine. At a recent visit, Pascal told us that the idea behind his coplanted vineyard (planted in 2003), is to see if soil trumps variety. Called “Complantée,” his ancient variety wine comes from a 20 are parcel  (this is about a quarter of a hectare… tiny) and has only been made in the stellar 2008 vintage. Dosed at 5 grams, the wine was memorable with a lovely fine mousse; it’s as compelling an ancient variety Champagne as I’ve tasted. Essentially, like any fine Champagne from the Côte des Blancs, the wine felt like a vehicle for chalk, and the chalk sang out with clarity on the nose and the finish. It should be noted that Pascal Agrapart is a master; he makes the finest wines in Avize (aside from those of Anselme Selosse), so it comes as no surprise that his coplanted wine is a knockout. At Raphaël Bérèche’s winery in Le Craon du Ludes, we tasted a 2007 Arbanne and Petit Meslier blend from a vineyard belonging to his wife’s family. This is not a wine that is for sale; it’s an experimental cuvée. As I was nosing the wine, its strange, funky, smoky, almost vegetal aromas, Raphaël commented “this is my Aligoté,” and as I took a sip, I knew instantly what he meant. The wine’s acidity was absolutely electric. I can’t say that I liked the wine, but it was quite illustrative of what Arbanne and Petit Meslier bring to a bottle. Arbanne, for instance, brings an abundance of razor-sharp acidity. Fascinating. A few hours later in Aurélian Laherte’s tasting room, we tried quite a refined example of an ancient variety wine: Laherte’s “Les Clos,” which has now been renamed “Les 7,” for the seven varieties planted in this one hectare “clos” in Chavot: Fromonteau (Pinot Gris), Arbanne, Pinot Blanc, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, Pinot Meunier, Petit Meslier.  The vineyard was planted in 2002 with grapes first harvested in 2005.  The wine is a “perpetual cuvée,” like a solera, which means any given bottling comprises every vintage since the first: 2005. Apparently Aurélian makes both a Brut Nature and an Extra Brut version of Le 7 and I don’t know which we tasted. I’d guess Extra Brut because the wine didn’t have the insane cut of a Brut Nature without malolactic fermentation (as Aurelian’s wines normally do not undergo it), but I could easily be wrong. In any case, it’s a very pretty, lacy, white-fruited style of ancient variety wine with an underlying power and salinity that resonates on the palate. Chez Benoît Lahaye, one of my all time favorite Champagne growers who, incidentally, has added two donkeys to the entourage that plows his vines in Bouzy, we tasted an extremely unusual ancient variety wine. The vineyard that produces it is called “Jardin de la Gros Pierre” and once belonged to Benoît’s grandfather. The majority of the vines were planted in 1928. It’s a 30 are parcel (slightly larger than a quarter of a hectare) and the varietal composition of the vineyard includes Chasselas and Gros Plant. (We are not sure how the CIVC will react to this, thus we’ll trust that they don’t read my blog.) Benoît told us that his grandfather didn’t uproot his Chasselas vines in part because he especially liked to eat the grapes. Jardin de la Gros Pierre is farmed biodynamically (and plowed by donkeys). Benoît believes that it’s good for the grapes to be coplanted, but he did not expound on the reasons. In the glass, this wine was rich, honeyed, and nutty. With only 20 mgs of sulfur and no dosage, it was a very natural, earthy feeling Champagne with a long, eloquent finish. I was beginning to get the impression that ancient variety wines tend to be earthy; they tend to be rustic; they tend to show a bit like Meunier wines but without the ripe fruitiness of Meunier. Perhaps this earthiness and rusticity of style was, at some point, rejected in favor of the clean power and finesse imparted by Chardonnay and Pinot Noir? Perhaps the fashion for ancient variety wines reflects a desire for rusticity, a foil for the sleek and polished character of the vast majority of Champagne. Just a thought… I won’t dwell long on my experience with Tarlant’s ancient variety wine primarily because I don’t know much about it though I’m curious to learn more. It’s a wine called “Bam,” which is a blend of Pinot, Blanc, Arbanne, and Petit Meslier. We tasted this at a small “off” tasting of the Dive Bouteille called something along the lines of “Contient Soufre… Mais Pas Trop” (“contains sulfur, but not much”).  We didn’t spend long; our aim was to try to foster a relationship between Benoît Tarlant and a prospective importer (LDM) so that Tarlant’s excellent Champagnes will be more readily available in New York. As Benoît poured Bam into our glasses, he cautioned us: “prepare your teeth.” With white, fleshy stone fruits on the nose (a recurring theme) the wine was one of the most acidic Champagnes I’ve ever tried, the acidity so deliciously shrill it reminded me of rhubarb. It was a chiseled and precise little sip, fennel notes adding complexity to the orchard fruit notes of Pinot Blanc. Benoît told us it’s the Arbanne that adds the acidity. One man’s Aligoté is another man’s Bam... Thus far I’ve assumed that readers are generally aware of the vignerons I’m “speaking” about: Agrapart, Bérèche, Laherte, Lahaye, Tarlant, but before I detail falling in love with Olivier Horiot’s ancient variety wine, I should spend a sentence or two on Olivier. Horiot farms about seven hectares of vines in the very south of Champagne, an appellation for Rosé wine called “Rosé de Ricey.” The soil, closely akin to the soil of Chablis, is clay and limestone rather than chalk. Though Olivier struck me as totally unlike Cédric Bouchard as a person, his philosophy is similar in the sense that he’d to make single terroir wines and, in an ideal world, they would be still. In reality he does make quite a bit of single terroir, still wine, but (thankfully) he also makes Champagne. I like Horiot’s wines very much. His Rosés are deep, rich, smoky, and they have the intense, dark toned minerality of Pinot Noir from the area, which is best described as “like licking the dark crystal.” Additionally, Horiot’s wines are distinct. There’s quite a bit of excellent Champagne in the world and, at a certain point, one looks for personality. Olivier Horiot’s wines have it in droves. Horiot’s ancient variety wine is called “5 Sens” and it’s a recent wine for him. His first barrels of Pinot Blanc and Arbanne were from the 2006 vintage. In addition to Pinot Blanc and Arbanne, 5 Sens has Chardonnay, Meunier, and Pinot Noir. The grapes are fermented separately, from which I surmise that they are not from a coplanted vineyard. Like all Horiot’s wines, malolactic fermentation takes place, and the base wines are matured in barrel. We tasted 2008 5 Sense and it was absolutely magical. The nose offered white, fleshy orchard fruits but with a deep, underlying earthiness. What can we say about the appeal of this wine? It was quirkily delicious. Bottled Brut Nature and all fruit from the stellar ’08 vintage, there was much to love about this wine and I found myself returning to it over and over again throughout the evening. I’m convinced I polished off the majority of the bottle. While I can’t draw robust conclusions about ancient variety Champagnes, I can unequivocally say that, from top growers, they are delicious and well worth seeking out. For those who find Champagne to be inherently just a bit slick, a bit polished, a bit luxurious, it’s worth coming face to face with the screeching acidity of Benoit Tarlant’s “Bam,” or the deep earthiness and salinity of Laherte’s “Les 7” or Horiot’s “5 Sens.” Rusticity is good thing, and it’s often lacking in Champagne. In some cases, such as Agrapart’s “Complantée,” it’s possible to have both poise, the classic, chalky structure of Champagne, and a certain, faintly funky je ne sais quoi.

item.title: Visiting Baudry
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A few weeks ago I had dinner with my North Carolina wine family at the excellent Durham restaurant: Rue Cler. We drank 2004 Clos Rougeard wines: Clos, Poyeux, and Bourg, as well as 2004 Baudry Croix Boissée. The Baudry wines are dear to my heart. 2004 is the Baudry vintage I cut my teeth on I distinctly remember the ’04 Croix Boisée in its youth; it was very vegetal, stern, and tannic. I recoiled at its unfriendly presentation; what a novice I was! At dinner a few weeks ago, the vegetal note was still there, but the palate had fleshed out, taken on a certain restrained lushness, and the wine was just gorgeous. “Paired” with 2004 Rougeard Poyeux, a wine that is stunningly beautiful and feminine with every delectable red fruit note and an incredibly silky palate, the Baudry more than held its own, showing more funk, more herbal rusticity than the Rougeard, but in a compelling way, the chalk of the vineyard clamping down deliciously on the finish. A few friends and I recently drank a magnum of 2003 Baudry Grézeaux, also quite tasty, especially after several hours open when the wine took on a rose petal-y texture. The wine showed no “’03-itis” and was seamless and balanced, as we’d expect from this Domaine. Many people have written about Baudry and many more will; there is no need for this post, especially considering that Wine Disorder will yield superior notes on the recent wines out of barrel and bottle, courtesy of SFJoe, but I’m going to write it nonetheless as I can’t seem to help myself. I’ll jump back in time a few months. This winter I learned, among many things, that Cabernet Franc is a relief after Champagne. I had the good fortune to spend a week in Champagne; then I went to the central Loire Valley to continue the adventure. First on the Loire Valley roster was Clos Rougeard; second was Olga Raffault; third was Bernard Baudry. Each one of these visits was stunning. Rougeard, with its ancient cellar of prized juice in barrels, the walls of the underground tasting chamber iridescent with coins visitors have affixed to the moss covered walls over many years, leaves an unforgettable impression of the heights Cabernet Franc can attain. The Raffaults, with a wealth of old vintages to offer and a flawless understanding of their terroirs, is also an excellent visit.  I won’t say that I was most “impressed” at Baudry, rather that something clicked after the numerous years I’d spent drinking and selling these wines, something that gave me a fresh appreciation for the work and love of the wines – like discovering a new layer to a familiar friend – “I didn’t know you did THAT is your spare time! It all makes sense now… way cool!” There’s a sweet picture on the LDM website of Mathieu and Bernard, a picture that captures them well, their kindness and sense of humor, as well as a brief caption telling the history of the Domaine, which is a short one. Bernard started the Domaine; Mathieu took over in 2000. They have 25 hectares (though Mathieu told us 30 during our trudge through the muddy vines). They’ve been certified in organics since 2006 but Bernard never used chemicals. Believing that work in the vines is crucial, they make their own composts. The consensus seems to be that Bernard was a very good vigneron and Mathieu is perhaps an even better one. They are superior people. (See below: Mathieu and his trusty translator.) We met at Domaine Baudry on a rainy morning and proceeded to tour the vines. Beginning at Les Granges, we saw the flat, sandy soil that gives birth to this entry level wine: a juicy and easy drinking cuvée that can be somewhat Beaujolais like in character in my opinion. The “Granges” vineyard is a contiguous parcel with sandy, acidic soil. It’s not a great terroir; it yields wines to drink while your Croix Boissée bottles are coming around. At this time, Mathieu also told us about “Clos Guillot,” which is the Baudry’s most recently acquired parcel. “Guillot” is ten kilometers away (thus we did not visit it) with south and southwestern exposure, clay and yellow limestone soil. With Guillot there’s a bit of a tradeoff: the terroir is excellent, but the vines are young, having been planted in the early ‘90s. The Baudry’s Franc de Pied bottling comes from Clos Guillot. The vines are planted on sand, which (I learned) is preferable for Franc de Pied vines. From “Granges” we moved on to “Croix Boissée,” where I had my first Baudry revelation. Boissée is a very steep, windy, mid-slope plot with extremely chalky soil. The wind helps keep mildew off the vines and Mathieu described Chinon as being a bit like Burgundy in the sense that wines from mid-slope vineyards often have more finesse. Bernard and Mathieu’s white Chinon also comes from Croix Boissée as chalky soil works well for Chenin Blanc. I don’t have a decent picture from La Croix Boissée, so I’ll have to do my best with words. Croix Boissée was markedly colder than Granges had been. We buttoned up our coats; the wind tussled us, and we gazed down at the gnarled old vine trunks as Mathieu spoke. This is clearly a marginal terroir, ground where vines struggle for nutrients. I find myself thinking of vineyards like this as cosmically designed, vineyards where God had a direct hand in the formation (if I believed in God…). Abstract, I know, but there’s a feeling you get when you stand in a vineyard like this. Silence swept over the crowd and there was mutual understanding that we were in the presence of greatness. Then we returned to the cellar. All grapes are hand harvested at Baudry with stems removed. Mathieu told us that they’ve experimented with whole cluster fermentation, but it makes the wines too hard. Fermentations are with native yeast (duh) and the top wines spend quite some time in barrel. I’d say my second Baudry revelation (actually more of a Cabernet Franc revelation as it took place over the course of visits to Clos Rougeard, Baudry, and Lenoir) was that vignerons put Cabernet Franc into barrel not to add structure from wood but to remove structure from grapes. (Believe it or not I also did not know that Napa and Sonoma are north of San Francisco until a couple of months ago.) Honestly I had thought that the Baudry’s made Croix Boissée woody so that it would be more age worthy, when the fact is that, especially with Croix Boissée – as I was about to find out – without the years of softening in barrel, the wine is almost undrinkable-y structured. A quick word about the Baudry cellar: In the central Loire it seems that quite a few vignerons raise their wines in chambers hollowed out of “tuffeau,” a kind of porous, white, chalky limestone that is abundant in the area. The Baudry’s are no exception. Their cellar is clean and newly excavated. It doesn’t have the ancient vibe of Clos Rougeard; then again the Baudry’s have come to the trade more recently. It feels like a place where the Baudry’s make wine: orderly and congruous.
