We began to taste the 2012 wines starting with Rosé, a wine that is exceedingly popular in New York, but apparently virtually unknown in France. All goes to the US market. Malo was finished and the wine rested at 12.5% alcohol, but I found it hard to taste. Next came 2012 Les Granges. The malo was finished and the wine will be bottled in June. We talked about the 2012 vintage. Yields were very low – 35% lower than a classic year. Granges spends some months in concrete and is racked a couple of times to avoid reduction. There’s an impression of carbonic maceration, an ease and forward fruitiness to the wine, but I don’t actually think the wine undergoes it. In any case, 2012 had lip-smacking acidity and seemed tangier and less fruity than previous renditions. 2012 Grézeaux was a bit reduced (no racking had yet been done); the aromas were muted, I thought. It was all structure, a hard wine, yet Mathieu surprised me by telling us that 2012 Grézeaux is quite open for this stage in its life. About 90 barrels are made of this wine and tasting it in this state of extreme youth confirms the impression of its age-worthiness. 2012 Clos Guillot was very dark and opaque in the glass. With this cuvee, Mathieu told us, they rack from barrel into large tank and leave the wine for two months before bottling. The wine was crunchy, but also quite fruity. Malo was not yet complete, yet the wine was tastier out of barrel, I thought, than Grézeaux. There was an intense mineral core that made me excited to taste wines from this parcel as the vines age (you’ll recall the vines on Guillot are less than two decades old). There’s also warmth to Clos Guillot in youth that I don’t find in very young Grézeaux or Boissée, wines that may never show “warmth” exactly, but develop a certain beautiful stateliness and power with time. Needless to say 2012 Boissée was totally fruitless, though it left a marked impression of what’s to come. No malo had occurred yet (the wine will be bottled in 2014) and the wine was high-toned and mineral on the nose, pillar-like and dark fruited on the palate, with almost absurdly chalky minerality mingling with mouth-coating tannins on the finish. I’ll take a moment to remind the dear reader that I had just been traveling in Champagne and am no stranger to the flavor of chalk. “This is incredible!” I thought. “Croix Boissée is chalky like a Champagne!” No wonder I’m a sucker for it… In the Baudry tasting room, an open salon with very small yet elegant spittoons, we tried 2010 and 2011 wines in bottle. This may be a strange time to taste the 2011 wines, because virtually the only one that tasted “good” to the humble reviewer, was the 2011 “Cuvée Domaine.” I’m still unclear as to what, exactly, goes into this cuvee. Mathieu told us the wine is 80% “from the plateau” and 20% “from the valley.” Which plateau? Which valley? Allegedly sometimes the wine comprises young vine Clos Guillot… Regardless, my notes say wonderful things like “blackberry, cassis, violets…” I’ve been drinking Baudry Domaine regularly for some years now and my impression of the wine is that it is quintessentially Chinon. There’s a limestone-y underpinning to the wine and a funky, dusty, seedy black fruit character that is absolute perfection to the Chinon lover. 2011 Baudry Grezeaux was herbal and green. It was totally different than the Domaine bottling and Mathieu attributed this stark dissimilarity to the dryness of the vintage. In fact he compared 2011 to 2004, and I was happy to hear this comparison being made as a confirmed 2004 lover.  According to Mathieu and I do not doubt him, 2011 wines may arrive at a delicious place down the road. 2011 Clos Guillot, which will be bottled in September, was reduced, closed, and tannic in a way I did not enjoy. Boissée was closed but mouth-coating and structured in a way that I respected, but wouldn’t go so far as to say “enjoyed.” I was beginning to get a sense of the personalities of the vineyards: the rustic Grézeaux, the warmer and more forward fruited Guillot, and the stern, distinct, powerhouse Croix Boissée with its telltale chalky finish. The 2010 wines in bottle showed better as a group, I thought, though I was strangely less keen on the Domaine bottling than I had been on 2011 Domaine. We love the 2010 vintage, in general. It combines the power of 2009 with the finesse of a lighter year like 2008. As we tasted 2010 Grézeaux, Mathieu told us he thinks 2010 is one of the best vintages in recent Loire history, and Grézeaux certainly indicates this. The wine is very earthy with a dark, black, almost graphite-y minerality. At the same time, the fruit is surprisingly juicy. A wine for the cellar, this wine certainly still offers much to enjoy in the moment, especially if there’s a decanter on hand. 2010 Guillot was aromatically a bit closed but the palate was full of glorious, dense fruit, and porous, limey minerality. Boissée, on the other hand, had a gorgeous nose full of purple fruits and flowers, fruit seeds and herbs. The chalky clamp of the finish coated my mouth and left me salivating. After three vintages of Croix Boissée in one morning (as well as a trip to the vines), it was safe to say I’d gotten a taste of the vineyard. We drank a couple of fun bottles over lunch with the Baudrys, a jolly affair at which vegetables were served in addition to charcuterie and cheese! (Not always the case in the Loire in January.) I particularly loved 2004 Grézeaux, a decidedly herbal and non-fruity Chinon (as it should be…?) with charming rusticity. Everyone ooh-ed and ahh-ed over the 2003 Franc de Pied that Mathieu opened for us. According to one of my esteemed colleagues at the wine store, the geeks are fond of arguing over the age-worthiness of Baudry Franc de Pied. There aren’t really any old vintages as the vines are from Clos Guillot. Tasting this bottle, in addition to a 2002 Mathieu opened at a recent dinner party here in New York, suggests that the wine can happily hang out for ten years in the cellar. I’ll leave the hardcore Baudry fanatics to find out. If I’m lucky, I’ll get to taste one or two down the road. My impression is that this wine is more delicate and feminine than the other bottlings. During the aforementioned dinner at which we drank 2003 Grézeaux out of magnum, I described the Croix Boissée vineyard to my downstairs neighbor, also a wine enthusiast. The next morning, an order came through the internet from him for some bottles. All the Baudry wines are beautiful, but the Croix Boissée speaks for itself; perhaps this was the ultimate lesson I learned visiting Baudry. And to think I once found Boissée to be hard, vegetal, and austere…

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi, Sophie, good work. The "plateau" is the flat vineyard at the very top of the hill. The valley is down in the floor, close to the river.
Cheers,
Joe
Great post, Sophie. Always a pleasurable read, as well as informative. Best, John

Hi Sophie, this was a great post and a nostalgic one for me -- I spent a lot of time in the Loire valley although at that time I knew little about wine and didn't visit any vignerons. Your post makes me want to get a bottle of Clos Rougeard and see what the fuss is about, and to sit down with the various Baudry cuvees and compare them side by side -- for all the Baudry bottles I've enjoyed, I can't say I've paid much attention to how they differ from one another. One dilemma your post reminds me of is how to deal with the closed-off structure many of these wines have in their youth. The most consistently amazing "splurge" wine I've gotten at Chambers Street is the 1989 "Picasses" from Raffault. I'd love to put away several cases of Baudry for a decade or two, and end up with something comparable to that, but living in New York, how does one do that? There's no room in my apartment, and if you tally up the cost of the cellaring services around here, the total amount you've put towards a bottle when you finally pop its cork seems like it wouldn't be much less than you'd pay retail for the same vintage. Do you hear a lot of people making this same lament? Do you think there's a market for lower-cost cellaring services? I occasionally read some NYC based wine bloggers and I've never seen them discuss this issue -- it sometimes seems there's an ambient assumption that if you're not in a position to solve this problem by throwing money at it, maybe you shouldn't be cultivating an interest in wine.

Thanks, Joe! Ah yes this is helpful. I wonder what each of those terroirs brings to the blend...? Fruitiness from the valley meets acidity from the plateau?
Sophie

item.title: A Fortunate Invitation to Taste Bérèche.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I think I may have mentioned in a previous post that there are certain invitations it behooves one always to accept. I was presented with one recently when a friend and fellow impassioned Champagne drinker invited me for a tasting of all the Bérèche wines including the very rare and delicious single vineyards: Beaux Régards, Rive Gauche, and Le Cran. We very nearly had every Bérèche wine represented, though the old version of Bérèche’s Extra Brut Rosé has long since sold out on the New York market. And now there are two “new” Bérèche wines that will shortly be available: Reflet D’Antan (made in a perpetual cuvee) and Campania Remensis, an earthy and funky Rosé Champagne largely based on Pinot Noir. (The name, by the way, was taken from the Romans and means “poor soil.”) I digress. This tasting was representative of everything that’s been seen so far in New York from Bérèche save for his Brut Rosé.I’m not sure why I haven’t written about Bérèche before. His wines are manifestly great; he’s a delightful person: amusing and constantly smiling yet totally serious about his work. He took over the family Domaine in Le Craon du Ludes in the early 2000s and, if there’s one thing we learned at this recent New York tasting, it’s that he has made serious improvements at the Domaine since then. I’ve been to visit Raphaël twice now and once had the privilege of sampling two awesome boudins (one blanc and one noir) that his family made whist watching future beer burbling in a caldron in his backyard (this was thinks to a very fortunate invitation from Peter Liem. Thank you again, Peter.) Additionally (and this was such a treat) Raphaël hosted me for a fascinating blind tasting of the same wine with four different dosages. I highly recommend this to anyone who is truly interested in Champagne as it serves as a reminder that one, in fact, knows nothing about the way a gram or two or three or four impacts the aromas and flavors of a bottle of Champagne.The Bérèche Domaine is nine hectares in total with vines in and around the winery (Ludes, Craon du Ludes), in Ormes, and in Mareuil-le-Port in the Vallée de la Marne. The vines are roughly equally divided between the Noir, Meunier, and Chardonnay and, while the Domaine is not certified in either organics or biodynamics, the vines are essentially farmed organically with some parcels in conversion to biodynamics. The wines drink like wines that are made in the vineyard with very vivid terroir elegantly shepherded into the bottle. In the Bérèche winery, there are quite a few barrels. Raphaël prefers Burgundy barrels and sources many from Pierre-Yves Collin-Morey. Some barrel influence can be detected in most of the wines, not “oakiness” but rather the subtle presence of oxidative rather than reductive processes. Additionally Bérèche is firmly convinced of the superiority of tirer à liège, where the second fermentation occurs under cork rather than capsule. This is costly, time consuming, and risker than capsule use, but does allow ever so slightly more oxygen to reach the wine during the second fermentation. Bérèche believes tirer à liège greatly influences the wines’ texture, giving finer bubbles and the overall seamlessness of texture we associate with the finest Champagnes. Malolactic fermentation is generally avoided at Bérèche, meaning there’s a certain firm, bright, snappiness to the way the wines finish that is certainly appealing to the acid hound in all of us. Overall, these wines give me an impression of luxuriousness and quality. This is not to say that Raphaël is a sleek, suited, Champenois businessman; he didn’t strike me as such at all, rather that there’s an obsession with quality in every aspect of the process at this Domaine. Every bottle of Bérèche I’ve encountered has been impeccably wrought, from the “basic” Brut Reserve, a blend of equal parts Noir, Meunier, and Chardonnay, with a portion of reserve wine and some dosage (usually 9-10 grams) up through the powerful, single vineyard and vintage “Le Cran” and the seductive and singular “Reflet D’Antan.” These wines “deliver” (an expression I loathe; please forgive this use of it…) across the board, which is noteworthy as the world of Champagne is full of growers who make fine wines at the high end and mediocre ones at the low end. We began the New York tasting with two Bérèche Brut Reserves: 2009 base and 2010 base out of magnum. 2009 base Brut Reserve is a wine many of my customers fell in love with. In the grand scheme of the Bérèche lineup, it’s pretty opulent and friendly. From a ripe year and with dosage, there’s a sense of apply sweetness and accessibility to this wine that is perfect for the non-geek. Don’t get me wrong, it’s a lovely wine that is in a great place right now, a year and a half or so after disgorgement. However my preference was for the 2010 base Brut Reserve out of magnum, which felt higher in acid, more taught, and darker toned than the 2009 base. Recently disgorged (January 2013), the magnum was perhaps still somewhat shocked by disgorgement and will, I suspect, show better down the road. My ultimate conclusion was that 2010 is a better wine, but 2009 is in a better place right now. We followed with Bérèche’s Extra Brut Reserve, the wine that sold me on this Domaine in the first place when our friendly sales rep from Sussex Wine Merchants brought it by Chambers Street for us to sample. The story of my discovery of Bérèche is that the former export manager from Champagne Salon, a worldly and clever South African with whom I became acquainted thanks to Brooklynguy (wine is truly a business of connections), told me in no uncertain terms at dinner one night: “You know who’s making the best wine in Champagne right now?!? Raphaël Bérèche.” The rest is history… Bérèche’s Extra Brut Reserve is essentially the same wine as his Brut Reserve, but held on the lees an additional year and with two-ish grams of dosage (rather than eight-ish for the Brut Reserve). Based on 2008, this wine is super chiseled with green, toasty aromas and a fine, creamy texture. It’s a wine that, to me, feels perfectly, appropriately dry and with the power and resonance of the 2008 vintage singing loud and clear on the finish.A quick word about our company on this delicious evening: this is a group of extremely worldly folks who care very much about food and wine and spend a goodly amount of their leisure time cooking and pairing. We tasted these wines alongside plates of charcuterie and cheese ranging from excellent prosciutto to Brillat-Savarin to firmer, Alpine cheeses. Especially later in the tasting, our assessments of the wines took into consideration how well they held their own against the various meats and cheeses in front of us. I should add that these are unapologetic lovers of very dry, mineral Champagne. It came as no surprise that the general preference at the table was for Extra Brut Reserve over Brut Reserve.We moved on to Bérèche’s single vineyard wines beginning with 2008 Beaux Regards. This is a wine that received expletives in last year’s tasting notes from my visit to Bérèche. (My friends in Montréal would’ve said “Ça c’est fucking bon” and they would have been right.) The majority of the base wine here comes from the Beaux Regards vineyard in Ludes with some fruit from Mareuil-le-Port. The wine is a Blanc de Blancs comprising selection massale Chardonnay vines planted by Raphaël’s great grandfather in 1902. This wine is all minerals, fresh, green zestiness, and tangy, yellow fruits on the nose with unbelievable power on the mid-palate and finish. While it’s not as overtly chalky as Blanc de Blancs from the Côte des Blancs further south, there’s lots of raciness and minerality accentuated by the absence of dosage and steadied, one might say, by a fullness of texture coming (in part) from aging under cork in the cellar. Everyone really liked it. Between Beaux Regards and Rive Gauche, one attendee asked me why we move from less complex to more complex wines over the course of a tasting. She was finding herself less able to get a read on the wines as she began to feel the effects of alcohol. In a professional tasting (read: spitting), this is essentially a non-issue, though the longer the day of tasting the less one apprehends as palate fatigue sets in. The answer I gave is that typically the intro wines taste very simple after the heavy hitters, yet they’re fresh and appealing when staged at the onset of a tasting. Certainly when we came back to the magnum of Bérèche 2010 base Brut Reserve at the end of the evening, we found this to be the case. There’s also something a little bit more abstract that takes place as one tastes across a range of wines from a given producer that allows the taster to get a sense of the “house style;” in this case acid driven yet with a definite suavity. In truth, I was very glad not to be spitting…Rive Gauche – in this case 2008 vintage but not vintage dated – comes from wines in the Marne planted in 1969. Again the vin clair is matured in barrel and the wine rests under cork during the second fermentation. Rive Gauche showed the same power of the vintage that Beaux Regards showed but with darker, spicier fruit, the ripe, generous, gingery qualities of Pinot Meunier. The effect of the two wines back to back was to show the excellence of the vintage and the stamp of Raphaël’s winemaking while highlighting the difference between Meunier and Chardonnay when vinified on their own. This wine was also beloved by the group.  I heard an exclamation of “I thought the last one was the best… until I tasted this one!” My personally preference is for Beaux Regards, but I love them both… The big surprise and delight of the night was 2005 Bérèche Le Cran. This wine is from the Ludes, based on equal parts Chardonnay and Pinot from two different mid-slope, chalky vineyards. Every time I have tasted Le Cran, it has called to mind white wines from the Jura. I don’t know why. There is something ever so slightly oxidative and secondary about the aromas that, when coupled with the wines high acidity, makes it feel Jurassic. The wine absolutely sang at this tasting. Stately, mellow, and opulent, especially after the 2008s, it had remarkable depth and concentration and was easily the most vinous of the Champagnes on the table. One member of our group pointed out quite correctly that Le Cran stood up best to the food we were eating, especially the charcuterie, a definite selling point in this particular crowd. There was much “wow”ing at the table. We closed the tasting with 2004 Vieilles Vignes, a wine made when Raphaël’s father was still at the helm of the Domaine. This can be quite a nice wine, but it was virtually impossible to taste after the powerhouses that are Raphaël’s single vineyard wines. A blend of 40/40 Chardonnay/Pinot with 20% Meunier, the wine is raised in tank rather than barrel and sees six grams dosage; it’s a standard Champagne: rich yet elegant with a toasty, praline quality to the nose, and not much finish to speak of. It’s an easygoing wine that merely lacked complexity after what we’d just tasted. It’s not a wine that feels “made in the vineyard,” and perhaps that’s what separated it from the other offerings on the table. What can we say about this beyond that the older generation makes way for the new one to do great work? Fashions have changed in Champagne and for the better: the trends of rigorous vineyard work, separating parcels, fermenting base wines in wood, caring for the wine as wine, etc…  are all excellent trends. We slipped off into the night relishing the memory of very many beautiful bottles… Many thanks to the hosts!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It was a very enjoyable night. Thank you, Sophie, for allowing us to relive it!
Nicely written report. Raphael is a star with a obsession to maximize the potential of his terroirs. Would love him to have some great GC plots.

item.title: Montréal: They’re Doing it Better than We Are!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Last weekend I went to Montréal for the second time. The first time I flew; this time I drove in a silver Mustang convertible, a delightful though unasked for upgrade, up and up interstate 87 into Québec “je me souviens.” The drive to Québec from New York is about six or seven hours, and it takes the driver through the Hudson Valley and the Catskills, then through the Adirondacks, the Champlain Valley, and into Canada. The road opens up as you drive north to reveal the beautiful and unsullied Adirondack Mountains, and in the far reaches of upstate New York, Québecois stations become as frequent as American ones as you spin the radio dial, and “sortie” is printed below “exit” on the road signs. My love affair with Montréal is about two years old and dates back to the day Martin Labelle walked into the wine store. Martin is a natural wine importer by night and an engineer by day. His company is called “Glou” (after the popular French expression for quaffable natural wines: “glou glou”), and he works with many producers that are familiar to us here in New York: Frank Cornelissen, Philippe Bornard, Angelino Maule, Eric Pfifferling, Thierry Allemand, Bruno Duchene, Jérôme Lenoir, to name just a few. Once I had met Martin, I quickly began to meet others: Cyril (also an importer) Jack (Martin’s partner and owner of Le Comptoir), Xavier (co-owner of Les Trois Petites Bouchons), their respective girlfriends and friends, all great tasters and excellent people. I began to notice that many wine enthusiasts and industry types from Montréal pop into Chambers Street to pick out a pair of bottles to bring home. Canadian customs allows two bottles per person to cross the border, after which tax (generally 100% of the price of the wine) is applied. Conversations with Québecois wine people at Chambers Street typically turn to lamenting Canada’s strange booze laws, also the inability to create any kind of a market between Montréal and New York. All alcohol sales are state monitored in Québec. In fact my friends who “import” wine there aren’t actually importers, they are representatives. Technically the state is the importer and these intermediaries represent wine growers to the state. Bottles of wine as well as spirits must be purchased through the SAQ, whose outposts are ubiquitous, rarely with anything really good, though there will likely be at least one or two potable bottles on the shelf at the SAQ. Private sales are allowed for clients who have particular tastes, meaning that a customer can buy “direct” from an importer, but the sale must pass through the SAQ for tax purposes… and the client must pick up at their neighborhood SAQ. In spite of what appear to be clear setbacks to the wine industry courtesy of the government, Montréal has a thriving food and wine scene and, after this recent visit, a notion began to grow within me that, for the way I like to eat and drink, they’re doing it better than we are in New York. It’s my sense that New York (Manhattan is clearly the chief offender) has an obsession with the high end side of dining and wine. Fine dining is a big deal here and you’ve only to scratch the surface of the New York wine business on social media to discover that sommeliers, buyers, bloggers, industry movers and shakers love to tweet and photograph and status update any rare or expensive bottle that comes their way. I’ve done it myself! Around the time of La Paulée of New York, I was on the verge of launching a personal tirade against this event and the pervasiveness of what I call “wine ballin,’” but I decided such a gesture would be an unnecessary act of “hateration” (to quote  Missy Elliot). I’m not complaining; I’m expressing a personal preference. I would like there to be more casual restaurants with really good lists that I can wander in to without a reservation to enjoy food and wine in a non-pretentious fashion with friends. I’d like there to be more than one natural wine bar in New York. Regardless of one's feelings about “Natural Wines,” Bar à Vin culture, which originated in Paris and now thrives elsewhere, blurs the distinction between bar and restaurant in a way that is supremely lively and vibrant. Of course New York dwellers tend to think of New York as the center of the universe and the ultimate east coast hub for interesting dining, which perhaps explains why so many Montréalers come to New York, and so few New Yorkers travel to Montréal. I’d like to expose this as an unfair exchange of wine luminaries. If you live in New York and you work in wine, especially euro-centric, “Natural” or natural-ish wine, get your ass up to Montréal and check out what these folks are doing! It’s more than just Joe Beef and Au Pied de Cochon!For those who haven’t been to Montréal, a quick word about the way the city feels: Montréal fosters a vibe that is at once European and North American. Many people are bilingual and the French spoken in Montréal is often peppered with English. One’s credit card malfunctioning at the super market can, for instance, be “fucké” or, even better “christé” (“christed”).  As I mentioned in my last post, a really special bottle of wine can be “fucking bon.” This melding of languages is apparent in every aspect of the city as one wanders down the Rue Sherbrooke past McGill University, looking at advertisements in French, listening to both languages, spoken with ease and fluency. The architecture of the city is, of course, not as old as that of a European city, and there’s a very North American penchant for exercise in Montéal. At the center of the city is a big park that holds the Mont Royal at its center. This park is ideal for jogging, cycling, etc… At the top, one commands a spectacular view of the city. On an unseasonably warm and windy Friday afternoon, I strolled up the Mont Royal and then spent the afternoon window shopping in the neighborhood called “Le Plateau.” Sadly I do not think Montréal is as advanced as we are in terms of specialty coffee and I had a sad Macchiato in a chess café before reporting to Le Comptoir for wine and food.Le Comptoir is a wine bar and restaurant outfitted in blond wood with its food menu displayed on a chalkboard above one large service station that is at once bar and kitchen. As its name suggests, the restaurant specializes in house made charcuterie, all of which is prepared in the basement of the restaurant. I arrived in advance of my friends, took a seat at the bar, and was at once handed a wine list by the kind and understated Jack Jacob. I pondered the list and Jack poured something in my glass, a rich, vibrant, and smoky Rosato of Primitivo from Guttarolo. It’s a natural feeling yet clean Puglian Rosato that, to my knowledge, has not been sold in New York before. I sipped my wine and bantered with Jack periodically gazing at the list and marveling that there was so much that I wanted to drink: verticals of Jean-Yves Péron both Champ Levat and Cote Pelée. I saw thoughtfully chosen natural wines from France, but also quite a few from the Italy, Spain, and the US. There were multiple cuvées from Clos Saron, for example. I finished my Rosato and Jack poured a taste of 2010 Clemens Busch Vom Roten Schiefer into my glass, as well-balanced and resonant a Riesling as I’ve tried, the red slate presenting itself in a mellow, burnished, and golden tone, buoyed up by a laser-like spine of acid. My friends began to arrive. I can’t possibly recall everything we drank and ate, but there were some highlights, beginning with Laherte 2008 Autrefois, from old vine Pinot Meunier. This wine is incredibly crisp, crunchy, and long, highlighting the power of the vintage. With it we had a charcuterie platter, the specialité de la maison.There were beautiful salads, one of beets, one of crab. We drank an Australian Riesling served blind. Cyril and I convinced ourselves that it was a white wine from Santorini. As always, blind tasting is humbling. There was a Frantz Saumon “Minèral” Chenin Blanc that was quite lovely in its creamy, herbal, apply way. We had very good lobster and an intriguing dish (in the rear ground of the picture below) featuring ravioli and ceviche on the same plate and the same time. Honestly the wines were very good, the food excellent, but the company was truly superior and I found myself enjoying easy and amusing conversation most of all.We moved on to red wines, amongst them L’Anglore Pierre Chaude Grenache, which was so pure and spicy and succulent, it reminded me why I’d gone to great lengths to make the acquaintance of this shy and inspired vigneron, Eric Pfifferling, from Tavel in the southern Rhône. Martin recounted a story of wooing his girlfriend with Pfifferling on their first date. A wise choice! These wines have such delicate beauty for southern wines and so much overall distinctiveness that the best bottles are truly swoon-worthy. I’d be taken in by a man who opened L’Anglore on a first date and so would several other women I know!Of course our conscientious wine steward made sure to sample all bottles before pouring them for us. We spent a stint with an earthy, savory magnum of 2002 Calabretta Etna Rosso, a wine that smells and tastes of brushy Sicilian terrain, Nerello Mascallese, and old cellars. Since our evening was largely dominated by natural wines: juicy, aromatic, carbonic maceration stuff, this bottle showed a welcome, stately maturity, especially with perfectly prepared pork with baby root vegetables. The evening wore on and the clouds that had been threatening to open up all afternoon finally did, spilling forth their contents onto the street outside Le Comptoir. I found myself in a long conversation with Cyril about the possibility of setting up an exchange program between New York and Montréal wine folks -- something along the lines of a small van that would ferry people back and forth between the two cities. What a fabulous idea! I was not, however, sober at the time and in the light of day this plan seemed slightly more difficult to execute than it had during the evening's festivities. A bottle of Duroux Patience materialized. This is a producer who is dear to us at Chambers Street Wines. From what I've heard, Ducroux is a shy and humble grower in Régnie who has been passionate about biodynamic vine growing and wine making for many years now. Initially I rebelled against the green and herbal flavors of these wines, but as an older drinker, I have come to love this quality as it's charmingly born out on the palate in a kind of ethereal, green, slightly seedy, dark fruit note. Patience sees more élèvage than the other Ducroux wines and is deeper in color and more serious in structure than the other bottlings. It absolutely sang at Le Comptoir and came to symbolize the exquisite taste of my hosts there. I did learn in Montréal that a brisk walk up a mountain in the snow with a friend and a very happy dog can do much to relieve the sluggishness brought on by a late night of wine drinking. Unlike New York, where one must go to great lengths to find countryside, in Montréal the country is about half an hour outside the city, and it's deep, satisfying countryside, not New Jersey. The south shore of Montréal is home to quite a few wonderful produits réginaux, ranging from goat cheese to venison pie to Maple Syrup to apple ciders. This was a favorite of mine; the two apple varieties in blend are listed at the bottom of the bottle. The apples have red flesh, which gives color to this sparkling Rosé, which was very lightly sweet along the lines of a Pet-Nat (but undoubtedly containing quite a bit more sulfur). I adore this city, and so will you! I'm standing by to offer recommendations...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hello Sophie,
First, let me say how much I am a fan of CSW. Every time I go to NYC, I glad to visit the shop and buy a few gems (Vatan, B. Mascarello, the Cotats, A. Clouet...) that are very difficult to find in Montreal, even through the private import channel.
Thank you for your wonderfull post about Montreal. It's true we have a healthy and exciting restaurant scene, which is more accessible (financialy speeking) than New York's.
I wanted to bring a different point of view concerning the diversity of wines available in regular SAQ shops around Québec. It is true a lot of good wines from small producers are only available through the private import channel, but there is still nearly 10 000 different wines available as we speak in SAQ stores.
Just today, if I wanted, I could buy 10 different cuvees from Dönnhoff, 4 from FX Pichler, 3 from Alzinger, 4 from Domaine de Bellivière. I could buy Groleau by Clau de Nell. I could buy a Baudry Chinon, a Vouvray by Philippe Foreau or a Larmandier-Bernier or Egly-Ouriet Champagne! A Pinot Meunier by Françoise Bedel? Sure!
Of course, all of these products are not available in every outpost, but usually concentrated in a few special ones. You have to know where to shop.
Hope to see you in one of my next trip to NYC! Cheers!

Hi Sophie,
I just read your excellent Montreal post. The restaurant and wine scene in this city has improved a great deal in the past 5 years, and much of the credit goes to importers like your friends at Glou. What we really need now is a better selection at the state-run SAQ wine stores. If we could get a fraction of the wines you have at Chambers Street, I would be a happy man.
And I second Myriade... best coffee in the city!
As for Joe Beef, Au Pied du Cochon, and that ilk, you're right to pass them over. They do great business with the tourists, but they are not very interesting restaurants, serving a version of traditional Québécois fare, heavy, greasy, and overpriced.

Hi Maysaam - Thanks for your comment! And good for you for going to Montreal to eat and drink! Do you come to Chambers Street Wines when you're in NYC? If so, please introduce yourself! And thanks for the notes on cafés in Montreal of interest. Hopefully it won't take me another year to get back to that great city.
All the best,
Sophie

Great post! For someone who's lived in New York and goes there often to eat, I have to admit that we have an amazing food scene up here in Montreal. Next time you're in town, please check out my map of independent cafés in Montreal, we do have some great ones and there's no reason not to have a good cup of joe while you're up here! :) http://willtravelforfood.com/2012/09/13/montreal-best-cafes/

I didn't mean to say we in Montreal are totally devoid of interesting wines from the state monopoly. There are numerous good bottles to be had, as Francis points out, scattered throughout the system (the SAQ's website is a big help). But the vast majority of the 10,000 wines are, *ahem*, plonk. Using Champagne as an example, it is only recently that Larmandier-Bernier, Egly-Ouriet, Bedel, and Billiot have been available on the SAQ shelves (as of last week we can add Cédric Bouchard to the list). Starting some 30 years ago when I first shopped at the SAQ, until about 5 years ago, it was an endless monotony of Cordon Rouge, Brut Impérial, White Foil, etc. However, I should temper my complaint, in France too most wine shops carry almost exclusively the big Champagne brands. The public gets what the public wants. But the situation improves every year, and much of the credit goes to the importers and restaurants you write about. But I'm an impatient bastard, I want a Chambers Street or a Mi-Fugue Mi-Raisin (a wonderfully weird half wine, half music shop) in Montreal now!

Hi Sébastien - Thanks so much for your comment and for your list of cafés! I wanted to go to Myriad (my boyfriend works in specialty coffee in New York and he recommended Myriad), but I was in Le Plateau and in and around McGill, which made a jaunt to Myriad on foot kind of an endeavor. The next time I will seek out great coffee while I'm there as well. Thanks also for your language tips. I thought perhaps crissé was the spelling. Is that word related to "Christ the Savoir?" Right now I am really curious to hear Acadians speak as I hear they mingle French and English even more than the Québecois! Okay -- hope to hear from you again...
Sophie

Hello! Great post about the Montreal wine scene and pretty accurate about Montreal in general... I have to say I have never ever heard "christé" in my entire 31 years of life in Québec. The closest would be "crissé", but not used as an alternative to "fucké". More like in "Ma carte de crédit marchait pas, je l'ai crissé aux vidanges".
Here's a few cafés suggestions that should help you change your mind about the exploding coffee scene here: Pikolo Flocons St-Henri St-Henri Quartier-Latin Le Couteau Myriade Odessa In Gamba Neve ...and look for local roasters such as Kittel and St-Henri in various other bistros, pastry shops, etc.

item.title: Garden State
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My aunt and uncle live in the borough of Stockton, New Jersey. Located in Hunterdon Country, this is a nice place and its landscape of woods and green, rolling hills is a far cry from the vista of factories and suburban sprawl that give the Garden State a bad rap. Stockton lies on the Delaware River, on the other side of which is Pennsylvania. Many of the houses are old and stone (though there are a goodly number of modern eyesores of the kind my dad used to call “starter castles”) and every front yard seems to boast at least one red maple. The closest restaurant to my aunt and uncle’s house is in Pennsylvania. I was surprised and delighted to learn - when I read her memoire Blood, Bones & Butter - that Gabrielle Hamilton of Prune restaurant grew up in the vicinity but on the Pennsylvania side of the river. The Canal House, a restaurant that inspired the publication of a wonderful set of eponymously named cookbooks is also in the area… Canal House Cooking is the project of Gabrielle Hamilton’s sister, Melissa. It’s safe to say there’s a very attractive architectural and culinary aesthetic to this place, as well as a local food scene! The vibe is sort of self-consciously rustic colonial, which is lovely… especially coming from the metropolis. A few weeks ago my friend, SS, and I went to Stockton to visit my aunt and uncle for Thursday and Friday. SS, who recently moved to Gotham from North Carolina, mentioned that she hadn’t realized it was spring until we were halfway through New Jersey and she began to see green leaves on budding trees out of the train windows. Not to belabor the point, but ones misses flora and fauna when one lives in New York in a way that no amount of Ramen with pork belly at Ippudo can truly mollify. We selected some wines from Chambers Street to take to my aunt and uncle’s for a simple repast of local foie gras, duck prosciutto, salad, cheese, and very good bread from a bakery in Doylestown (PA). “This doesn’t sound like a simple repast!” You might think. My uncle is on a mission to support a local restaurant called The Rosemount Café that prepares foie and charcuterie in house, meaning we sampled quite of few Rosemount Café specialties over the course of the weekend. Check them out if you’re ever in Hunterdon County; they’re doing a fine job. While I had anticipated a lovely two days in the country with excellent company and a tasty dinner, I had not anticipated such an exciting wine night. My aunt and uncle like wine and my uncle often surprises me (as he did this time – more later…) with a nice bottle of Burgundy or two from his personal collection. (Incidentally, this time he had a bottle of 2005 Edi Kante Vitovska that he purchased from me during my Astor days on the counter. He wanted to know what he should have to eat with this 500ml gem and I had no idea… suggestions are welcome.) We began the evening with a bottle of 2012 Dauny Sancerre Rosé accompanied by fresh ricotta on thin sliced bread, drizzled with olive oil and seasoned with salt and pepper. Anyone who has enjoyed appetizers at Locanda Verde knows what a treat this simple presentation of ricotta can be. I was excited to see Dauny Rosé come into stock. This is a relatively new producer for me and I’ve liked all I’ve tasted. Dauny’s “regular” Sancerre “Clos du Roy” is quite complex with more rich, mouth-filling mineral character than banal, gooseberry, Sauvignon Blanc varietal character. Since the arrival of Dauny a year or so ago, I have essentially stopped recommending the standard Girard Sancerre, which is quite frankly boring in comparison to the more complex Dauny. The Dauny winery has been organic since the '60s and I’ve learned from their very old school website that they have ample respect for living soils as the basis of good wine production.Dauny’s Rosé “Pinoz” comes from the Domaine’ s younger Pinot vines; their older Pinot vines are used for their Sancerre Rouge “Pinoz,” which I also had a good though fleeting impression of at a trade show not too long ago. Dauny Rosé is shimmery, fresh, and limestone-y with a delicacy that Crochet Rosé has not had in the past few vintages. Don’t get me wrong; I like Crochet Rosé, but it’s powerful and typically shows best a year or so after the release date, meaning that 2011 Crochet is drinking well right now (and it is… I found one at Chelsea Wine Vault a few months ago). Dauny Rosé has the citrusy, zesty quality of a white Sancerre but with the tangy, wild strawberry and tart cherry notes of cool climate Pinot Noir. As it turns out this is a tasty combination in a bottle of Rosé. My aunt (like my late mother, actually) is not typically a Rosé enthusiast. My mother historically accused dry Rosés of being “sweet” because they were fruity. This type of conflation drives wine people up the wall, as it did me during the year’s worth of wine conversations we had before she died. Anyway, I have learned since my mother’s passing that many a person who objects to Rosé on the grounds of fruitiness can be wooed with an extra crisp and zesty Sancerre Rosé. Needless to say my aunt enjoyed the Dauny. When my uncle arrived home from the salt mines (Rutgers University Chemistry Department), we opened a bottle of bubbles: 2009 Belluard Mont Blanc Brut Nature. It’s probably safe to say that this is as obscure a bottle of sparkling wine as graces the shelves at Chambers Street. It’s made from a grape called Gringet in the Ayse vineyards of the Savoie. When I first encountered Belluard, the Domaine was described to me as being “the Plageoles of the Savoie.” Robert Plageoles of Gaillac in southwestern France is credited with maintaining and in some cases replanting old, indigenous, practically extinct local grapes. Belluard, as the preeminent producer of Gringet, certainly does bear some tiny resemblance to Plageoles.The best sources I’ve found on Belluard and the Ayse vineyards are eastern French wine luminary Wink Lorch: http://winetravelmedia.com/tag/domaine-belluard/ and Bellu’s importer, Selection Massale. As we learn from Wink, before the phylloxera, Gringet was fairly widely planted, and since the infamous louse, Gringet plantings have dwindled to a mere 25 hectares, 50% of which are owned by Belluard, the only “serious” producer of Gringet. The Ayse vineyards are extremely steep and the soils are red clay, limestone, and yellow marl. Dominique is the current winemaker at Belluard and responsible for converting the Domaine to organic and then biodynamic viticulture. Selection Massale tells us that Dominique believes biodynamics interferes the least with the 700+ year history of this grape variety. Fermentations are now done in concrete egg since both wood and stainless steel were rejected as not quite right for this grape. The grapes that go into Bellu’s sparkles are grown on limestone scree. The base wine is aged for several years on the lees before disgorgement and is bottled Brut Nature (no sugar added); all this is to say it’s given the same treatment as some of my very favorite Champagnes! I’ve had two sparkling wines from Belluard and I’ve loved them both. The “basic” Ayse sparkling wine we stocked at the end of last year was beyond complex for a sub $20/retail sparkling wine. It alternately offered earthy, oxidative notes of walnut skin and apple-y fruit and sort of burnished, golden Christmas spice notes. Always more earthy than fruity, this was an arresting bottle that never failed to draw comment. 2009 Ayse Brut Nature shows a lighter and more herbal, waxy, yellow-fruited side of this grape. There are hints of unripe mango flesh and papaya, marigold and green herbs. I joked that this wine was like taking a walk in a field in springtime with all the fresh foliage and wildflowers such as crocuses, and buttercups. It’s a fanciful way to describe a wine and perhaps I’m succumbing to the power of suggestion of its Alpine origin, but I’ll stick to my guns. This wine is distinct. The palate is mellow and ripe, certainly more so than Brut Nature Champagnes are, and speaks of a warm ripening climate, the south facing slopes of the Ayse vineyards. (Though Selection Massale’s website tells us that sparkling wine perhaps best translates the freshness and minerality that Gringet brings, I’d argue that the still wines from Belluard: Les Aples and Le Feu – Bellu’s top site – are well worth drinking, especially for lovers of other Savoie favorites Altesse and Roussanne.) With dinner, we adjourned to a Burgundy. Typically my uncle will offer a couple to chose from and I’ll select the one I’m most curious about. In this case it was ’97 François Legros Nuits-Saint-Georges 1er Cru Les Perrières. What intrigued me most about this bottle was that it bore a Louis/Dressner back label and yet it’s a producer I’d never heard of. I’ve been following and drinking from the LDM book pretty consistently since 2005, which makes something like this a rare find. When I asked my boss, DL, about this producer, he replied that Dressner had many relationships in the earlier days that did not pan out for various reasons mostly having to do with the grower’s regimen in the vineyards not being up to snuff. Since LDM is a company devoted to selling wines that are organically farmed, fermented with native yeast, etc… deviations didn’t really last within the portfolio. I tried asking Jules Dressner, who seemed to remember Legros but nothing specific about the Domaine. If anyone has thoughts about this estate, I’d love to hear them… It turns out that my aunt had given this bottle to my uncle years ago for some sort of birthday or holiday present. Whether or not she knew it at the time, she had excellent instincts to single out the bottle with an LDM back label! In researching the Domaine, it does seem that they practice lutte raisonée rather than strictly organic or biodynamic viticulture. I came across much evidence in Legros’ favor: hand-harvesting, less than 40% new barrels in the cellar, etc… Not to sound conceited, but I assume if they were doing good work, I’d at least know the name. But perhaps not. It’s sad to say, but in some ways I’ve given up on Burgundy devotion because there are so many cats playing the Burgundy game and paying the Burgundy prices and it’s a bummer. I feel as though Burgundy drinking comes with bragging rights and I don’t enjoy that. I suppose the same could be said for Champagne, but since I’ve opted to specialize in growers to the exclusion of négociants, Champagne has become a much smaller category. I guess for the past few years, my stance on Burgundy has been that if someone wants to open a great bottle to share with me, I’ll be happy to enjoy it, but that’s the most I’m up for. In my research on Legros, I did find one tasting note on 2006 Legros NSG Perrières that jived with my experience of the wine at my aunt and uncle’s. Bill Nanson of Burgundy Report “Big Red Diary” humorously recalls tasting the wine at a restaurant in Beaune, corking the remainder, stowing it in the back of his car for a day’s travel in December, leaving the bottle in the fridge overnight, then finally tasting it the next to find the wine still quite good! He describes the wine as being velvet-y textured with dark fruits overlying sort of a snappy, soaring midpalate. Our bottle was certainly resolved and silky like a flower petal in texture yet far from being over the hill. I couldn’t imagine this ’97 in a better place. More dark fruited than red, the wine remained quite delicate and had taken on a Burgundian soil-iness on the nose that added nuance to its silken texture. Then there was that lively burst on the palate that did wonders for our duck prosciutto, etc… It was a really good bottle of wine! I’m not going to chalk it up with the best Burgundies I’ve tried, but it was seriously delicious and in a very good spot right now. Riding the high of our Legros experience and with some nibbles still on the table, we opened another bottle of wine: 2005 Lenoir Chinon "Les Roches," a wine that I absolutely loved at the Domaine a few months ago (having interrupted regularly scheduled programing to go rogue with my Québecois friends... and visit Lenoir). My uncle loves Chinon and I brought this bottle with him in mind. Used to the impeccable Chinons of Baudry and the sleek and now somewhat modern wines of Joguet, I thought he would like the pretty rusticity of Lenoir. Here's a picture from the Lenoir Domaine featuring sandwich wrappers, very old limestone walls, lots of cigarette butts, and many half empty bottles of wonderful Chinon. I feel as though I've recounted the story of Lenoir quite a few times now, so I'll keep this brief. It's an old and very small estate with superior terroir, lots of massale selected vines, and a motley assortment of ancient barrels of different sizes used to mature Cabernet Franc and a tiny quantity of Chenin. Lenoir's Chinons rest in barrel and bottle as long as it takes to soften up their structure and get them to a point of drink-ability. As I mentioned in my Baudry post, Cabernet Franc takes a long time to come around, and maturation in ancient foudre is a good way to go as long as the winemaking is kept clean, which in Lenoir's case it generally is. The first word in my notes from our tasting at the Domaine was "bangin'", a word that for me connotes a certain rompy quaffability, openness, sexiness. I was told this word was not appropriate for the Chambers Street website, so I'll use it here. Historically significant wines that have garnered this "adjective" include 2006 Foillard Côte du Py, the first Foillard I ever tasted... catch my drift? I distinctly remember how the 2005 Lenoir tasted at the Domaine: pretty with dark, tangy black fruits, juicy from the ripeness of the vintage, cool in the glass, a touch of VA heightening the wine's aromatics, less structured and hard than a Baudry wine with a delicious playfulness. It was good in New Jersey as well, but slightly funkier, especially on the palate. Perhaps it's a pity that wines can't be teleported from France to New Jersey so that they avoid the malaise of travel, which is especially hard on wines made without sulfur (and I believe Lenoir is one...). But I supposed one can be philosophical and say that if wines were as good stateside, trips to origin would lose some of their luster. There you have it: good wines in the Garden State.

item.title: Two Great Champagnes (in two very different styles…)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I am a lucky gal. I work in an industry I love, full of interesting, smart people, many of whom are erstwhile musicians, artists, or academics, the majority of whom love to cook and eat great food; these are people who care immensely about the cultures and landscapes that produce wine, etc… This is only the tip of the iceberg. I get to use my voice and the reach of the shop I work for to support small farmers in France, Italy, Germany, etc… I get to tell their stories and share their craft with (for the most part) sympathetic and curious enthusiasts in the US. And as if this weren’t enough, I really only curate sections of the wine shop that excite me. I can avoid the entire categories of Argentine Malbec and California Chardonnay if I want to. This is not to say that there are not good examples of these wines floating around, bottles I’d be happy to spend an evening with, but let’s face it: the wines I love are high acid, usually low alcohol, often either white, pink, or low-tannin red wines. Yep. I’ve got it made. I consider one of the greatest perks of my work life to be that I taste a lot Champagne. This past week two excellent Champagnes crossed my path and they were so different from one another that I began freshly to ponder what constitutes a good bottle of this finest of bubbly wines. I have a confession to make, namely that I’m a bit of a Champagne hipster. I don’t drink from the big houses, although I’m gearing up to drink a bottle of 2004 Roederer Crystal that came my way recently. And I’m ready to be open minded about this bottle of wine as many reliable Champagne lovers, amongst them Peter Liem of Champagneguide.net, have told me that Roederer is a superior Champagne house. Also, I’ve never tasted Crystal! I might don my leather booty shorts for the occasion. (Clearly, I’ll let you know what I think… about the wine, that it.) For the most part, I drink wines from small grower producers, the smaller the better, the more organic the better, the lower the dosage the better. I’m not particularly enamored with wines from the Côtes des Bars and I don’t have a preference for Pinot Meunier, but in essentially all other respects, I’m a Champagne hipster. The first great bottle that recently came my way was 2004 Franck Pascal Blanc des Noirs "Harmonie," one of the few remaining bottles on the shelf at Chambers Street. This was recommended by my very good friend, AR, whom I have had several occasions to mention. AR is not a Champagne (or any other kind of) hipster, but as open-minded a drinker as you’ll find working in the business. She may have more of a penchant for Meunier than I do, but I can’t swear it. I hadn’t had Harmonie in some time and AR reported that it was drinking very well right now. Time to find out...A couple of years ago I visited Franck Pascal and though he made quite an impression on me, his wines made less of an impression. Franck is intensely passionate about organic and biodynamic viticulture. He was an industrial engineer until he decided to return to his own village of Baslieux-sur-Châtillon to make wine. Franck did a brief stint in the army, where he learned to hate chemicals. He says that learning the effects of chemicals on the human body made him detest the use of them in the vines. This hatred of chemicals has been born out in the kind of viticulture he practices; he stopped using pesticides in ’98 and beginning to convert to organics in 2000. Pascal has also experimented with biodynamics, which he says changes the texture of the grape and the resultant wine as well, giving more structure, minerality, and a longer finish to the wine. For him biodynamics gives life back to the soil.  Pascal’s Domaine is north of the Marne River in the western part of Champagne. The soil is mostly clay with “calcaire dur” (hard limestone). This is Pinot Meunier country and 60% of Pascal’s Domaine is planted to Meunier.In the cellar, Pascal does not use wood, preferring the cut imparted to base wines fermented in stainless steel. If you think about it, this makes sense. Pinot Meunier grown on clay soil has a much riper, heavier presence inherently than, for example, Chardonnay grown on chalk. While someone like Pascal Agrapart in Avize might like the roundness wood gives to his Chardonnay, the same treatment applied to Meunier could result in a ponderous wine lacking liveliness, which is essential in Champagne. However Pascal’s base wines do go through malolactic fermentation, which could be due to a desire to minimize sulfur use, but this is speculation. It’s hard to put my finger on what I didn’t love about Pascal’s wines at the time of our visit. Certainly then I had not consumed remotely as much Champagne as I now have, but I think the terroir is, frankly, not my favorite. While I like Champagne grown on clay, sand, sandstone, and limestone, I prefer Champagne grown on chalk. It’s a bit difficult to put into words what chalk gives to Champagne – an intensely powdery and shelly note to the nose, a porous and mouth-coating quality to the finish. It’s addictive; I swear. Anyway, wines from the Marne are less chalky and rounder as a general rule, as are wines from north of Reims such as the wines of Chartogne-Taillet and Francis Boulard. These are all commendable Champagnes, but they don’t quite send me the way my favorites from chalkier soils do. I find Pascal’s wines to be subtle, though distinct, attaining their depth and resonance from good vineyard work. I approve of this entirely, but at the time of the visit, the wines didn’t thrill me. I’ve had good, though not transcendental (until now) experiences with the wines since then. Last summer we had a Meunier tasting at the wine store and I showed Pascal’s Sagesse, which is in fact only 57% Meunier. It was such a rustic, manly Champagne, offering ample earth and funk and dark-toned, burnished fruit (though not much of it…) It had some commonalities with the wines of Tarlant, another Marne Valley grower making unapologetically dry, terroir-driven Champagnes. Who knows what I wanted… more elegance and more chalk? What a silly thought – like wanting red wines from the Jura to taste like Burgundies. At any rate, 2004 Harmonie was my first transcendental Pascal wine. How to describe it? The wine is 50/50 Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier and it shows qualities of both grapes, the deeply earthy and almost Sake like notes of Meunier and the pretty, spicy, gingery notes of Noir. The wine clung to its Pascal-ness, the funk of Meunier, the length and minerality of wine grown on living soils. Furthermore just a little bit of age had sweetened the fruit, balancing the wine’s intense acidity. In youth I have found Pascal’s wines to be a trifle austere, but this bottle seemed to have fleshed out and become stately and elegant in a big-boned sort of way. It’s always a question with Extra Brut Champagnes how long they’ll age as dosage helps the aging process. Perhaps the answer is that one needs to catch them about a decade after the vintage date… Thanks to this experience, I’ll turn fresh eyes to Franck Pascal’s roster of wines. A couple of days later, with Harmonie still on the brain, I opened a bottle of Diebolt-Vallois Cuvée Prestige. Let me back up and say that every once in awhile, and I can count the number of times this has happened to me on the fingers of one hand, a customer gives me a bottle of wine. Though I have carried Diebolt CP at Chambers before, I haven’t carried it in some time, and this particular bottle was a gift from a client in Pennsylvania who is, himself, a wine retailer. He and I have exchanged thoughts about Champagne many times; he’s bought Ledru and Laval from me and was recently blown away by 2008 "Autrefois" from Laherte. (Who could blame him? It’s a great bottle…) He may have been thanking me for letting him snap up quite a bit of my 2008 Ledru Goutle, but I think it’s most likely that he’s just a super nice, generous guy.I have not had the privilege of visiting Diebolt-Vallois though I fully intend to do so. I’ll have to content myself with Peter’s recounting of the history and methods at this Domaine. The estate is based in Cramant and its present incarnation is the result of the marriage between Jacques Diebolt and Nadia Vallois, both with roots in the northern Côte des Blancs. This is an estate with deep family history in one of the most well-known parts of Champagne. I say this to highlight the difference between where Franck Pascal makes wine, a small outlying village in the Vallée de la Marne, and where Jacques Diebolt makes wine, one of the most famous Grand Crus in the Côte des Blancs. There is also, of course, a difference of terroir. Cramant is chalky soil; Baslieux-sur-Châtillon is predominantly clay. I had my first Diebolt-Vallois wine at Convivio, when Levi Dalton was working as the wine director there. It was delicious in the kind of sleek, polished, and extremely satisfying way that classically made, high quality Champagnes can be. I’ve had the wines on numerous occasions since and I stock the “regular” Blanc des Blancs in half bottles at Chambers Street. I might stock more wines from Diebolt, but it’s not an organic Domaine, rather a traditional Champagne estate that has, in fact, recently become registered as a négociant-manipulant in order to buy grapes from a family member in Cuis to use in the blends. As Peter mentions this on his site, he refers to “RM snobs.” I don’t know that I’m “an RM snob;” as long as the wine is good and the operation small and family run, which Diebolt-Vallois is, I could care less whether there’s a tiny “R” or a tiny “N” on the label. Because of the party line I’m obliged to tow at CSW, I try to stock organic and biodynamic Champagnes. I also believe vines farmed without chemicals produce better wines, but this wine was fantastic, so who am I to judge? As I read about this edition of Diebolt CP on Champagneguide.net (before actually drinking the bottle, incidentally), there was one thing that confused me. Peter lists this wine as “base 2009” then tells us that it’s 56% 2008. 30% is 2009 juice that would have gone into the Fleur de Passion bottling, which was not made in 2009, and 14% is 2007. I guess I would think that this blend would make it a 2008 base… further research needed. The 2008 and 2007 juice in the blend is foudre-raised and the 2009 is, I assume, tank-raised as is the practice with the various three vintages in CP. As soon as I discovered that this “base 2009” was actually mostly 2008 fruit, I got very excited.  There’s just something about 2008 that transforms otherwise good wines into true things of beauty. Never before have I known a vintage to leave such a clearly perceptible mark (with the exception of 2004 red Burgundy, but in this case the mark is generally thought to be bad rather than good). Upon first opening, the wine was creamy textured, lemony and almost lemon curd-y in a way I found quite pleasant. The dosage was higher than I’m used to at this point, but it worked given the high acidity and density of 2008 juice. (As an aside, when I mentioned to Brooklynguy that I had thoroughly enjoyed this bottle, his first comment was “isn’t that a bit high dosage for you?” I know why he said this. We have drunk and discussed quite a bit of Champagne together and my tastes seem to run dogmatically drier than his. In defense of my preference for drier-styled Champagnes, I’d say that dosage often masks flaws in not very interesting Champagne. Well-done dosage is a wonderful thing, clearly, but dosage as a form of makeup is not so great. There’s my two cents.) It wasn’t until the bottle had been open for several hours that it began to sing. The dosage receded to the background and the wine’s chalkiness, which I found more on the palate than on the nose shone through like a beacon of light illuminating and enlivening the wine. By the time there was just a glass or two left in the bottle, the wine had become so magnificent that it was virtually impossible to think about anything else. I suppose I paid it the ultimate compliment: the next morning on the way to work, I emailed the person who sells us Diebolt and requested all the rest of their stock. It’s coming Monday, if you want some. There you have it: two extremely different Champagnes, the mature (ish) and the young, the avant garde and the classic, the Blanc des Noirs and the Blanc des Blancs, the clay and the chalk, the tank and the foudre, the very dry and the not-quite-so-dry. Thank God there are so many styles of Champagne to enjoy, and thank God my chosen path allows me to try so many…

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Diebolt-Vallois Prestige is one of Champagnes most consistent, best value cuvees. You should seek out some of the "tete de Cuvee" Fleur de Passion to try. Read Peter Liem's review ( also a vertical tasting report in his articles section). The current 2005 is very good but maybe hang on till the 2006 comes out next year.

Ian - I tasted the 2006 Cramant this past week and it was excellent. One thing I really appreciate about Diebolt-Vallois is that, in addition to being great values, the wines are more classic than a lot of the geeky stuff I put on the shelf at Chambers. It's nice to find Champagnes in more classic style that I can get behind. I've never had the Fleur de Passion bottling, but I'm looking forward to trying it one of these days. Another of my Champagne customers called it "oaky in youth..." but he also objects to Lassaigne's Colline Inspirée on those grounds... and that's a wine I absolutely adore.
Thanks!
Sophie

2008 in Champagne continues to show so electric and nervy. So glad you've been kind enough to put so many lovely bottles in my hands. It's always a pleasure reading your notes as you are a more astute taster than I. I tend to get swept away very easily and give way to enthusiasm. Of course, if one can't fall in love with beautiful wines what's the point? Best, John

Hi Sophie If you like the 2006 Cramant then you will be knocked out by the 2006 Fleur de Passion. You customer must be super sensitive to oak in champagne , Jacques Diebolt only uses older barrels so the wood notes are very light. Cheers Ian

item.title: German Riesling Renaissance
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Though if asked, I generally say “I’m not a German Riesling person,” German Riesling is creeping back into my lime light. This probably sounds ridiculous. What serious wine lover is not a German Riesling person? Clearly Riesling – along with Chenin Blanc and Chardonnay (and probably some Italians I don’t know about) – is an incredibly terroir expressive and age-worthy white wine variety. While there are excellent examples from Alsace and Austria, also satisfactory examples from Australia and even northern Italy, the apotheosis of Riesling is Germany, the Mosel-Saar-Ruwer, the Nahe, and sometimes the Rhein and the Pfalz. While I have the utmost respect for Riesling, I don’t drink it often. When it comes to my home refrigerator, bottles of Riesling frequently go unfinished. My proclivity for dry wine is to blame. Especially with food, which is usually my context for wine drinking, I prefer dry wine. I feel as though Riesling exists to be beautiful, to sip in bed with your lover, not to pair with dinner. What about spicy food? I like a crisp wine with spicy food. If the dish is truly spicy, it’ll drown out the sweet song of the wine. Who wants to use a delicate, nectarine-y fresh Mosel wine to put out a fire? In fact I think that ultra-rich foie gras, though I never eat it, is a better pairing with lightly sweet Riesling than spicy food. I’ve only mentioned Riesling once on this blog and it was to name check a bottle of Von Schubert Kabinett that I drank at dinner with JBT (accompanied by foie gras and peaches). Over the course of my career in the wine business, my enthusiasm for Riesling has waxed and waned. Presently I’m at the point of feeling ambivalent about most… and absolutely smitten by a select few. How did this happen?In the summer of 2007, I was working at a wine store in North Carolina when the Terry Theise portfolio transitioned from one local distributor to another. (This typically means a period during which both the wholesale and retail buyer benefit, when wines are massively discounted as they move from one book to the other.) For me at the time, this meant lots of 2001 Dönnhoff and Willi Schaefer for somewhere around $15-$20/bottle. Those were glorious days. One of my favorite activities that summer was to retire to the pool at my apartment complex in the evening with a bottle of Willi Schaefer and a book. I remember being awe-struck at dinner one night by a bottle of ’01 Dönnhoff Niederhäuser Hermannshöhle Spätlese. My boyfriend at the time’s mother was trying to hold a conversation with me and I too transfixed by the wine to respond. These are the Rieslings I cut my teeth on and I consider myself lucky because these are superior producers in a classic, sweet style (working within the Prädikat system) and the 2001 German vintage was unparalleled in its decade.Then I moved to New York and pretty much stopped drinking Riesling. The selection at Astor, where I worked, was uninspiring at the low end. All the bottles I coveted were expensive and I wasn’t exactly flush. (To this day, I think one should be able buy a delicious bottle of Riesling for $20 or less.) I received the Chambers Street Wines offers from the intrepid and loquacious Lyle Fass, but I never actually made it in to the shop to pick up that bottle of Schäfer-Fröhlich or Von Kesselstatt from the newsletter. The 2005 and 2006 vintages were on the market and neither was to my liking, 2005’s tasted ripe and powerful but without the acid to make them light on their feet, and 2006 was marked by rain, rot, and associated issues that overshadowed the delicate filigree of slate, acid, and fruit that gives German Riesling its incredible succulence. I had practically forgotten about German Riesling when I met Dan Melia – formerly of Mosel Wine Merchant – at a trade show. He asked to come see the buyers at Astor with some Clemens Busch wine and we acquiesced. I started to like Riesling again. Clemens’ wines felt more “natural” (for lack of a better word) than the Rieslings I was used to. They tasted effortlessly dry as opposed to forcedly dry like many of the “trocken” wines made since “dry” became so much more fashionable in Germany than “sweet”. To my palate, forcedly dry German Riesling tastes aggressively steely and unbalanced and lacks the magic a small quantity of residual sugar can bring, especially to the aromas of the wine. On the other hand, Riesling from well-tended vineyards, fermented dry using native yeast and not absolutely loaded down with sulfur, tastes sort of earthy and authentic – this was what I tasted in Clemens’ wines that first day with Dan Melia. I learned about “sponty” (pronounced “sh-ponty” with a silly German accent), spontaneous yeast fermentation, which is somewhat rare in Germany. Mosel Wine Merchant focused on Rieslings from the Mosel, made in this way. Thus I tasted the wines of Knebel, Lauer, Stein, and Steinmetz… and later Immich-Batterieberg and Weiser-Künstler. Mosel Wine Merchant no longer exists, though I still have the pleasure of speaking to Dan every few months, and Dan’s former partner, Lars Carlberg, presently lives in Trier in the Mosel and writes a fantastically informative website about German wine: www.larscarlberg.com. After the disintegration of MWM, the growers scattered to the winds and, as luck would have it, three wound up in the Louis/Dressner/McKenna portfolio: Clemens Busch, Matthias Knebel, and Gernot Kollmann of Immich-Batterieberg.  This was a fortunate turn of events for the growers (because LDM is a fantastic portfolio with an unparalleled reputation) and also good news for me personally because I was privileged to travel with Clemens, Gernot, and Matthias in the Loire Valley this past winter as part of the Dressner’s annual trip. Having gotten to know many of Dressner’s French growers over the years, I was delighted by the Germans’ contribution to the group. Ironically, some of the best wines I tasted in the Loire this winter were actually from the Mosel. So I’m starting to crawl back on board with German Riesling, with a particular affinity for drier German wines made outside the Prädikat system – wines that are an expression of the vineyard without the ripeness of the grapes at harvest documented on the label. (As Gernot Kollman explains, with low yields and old vines, ripeness isn’t an issue and most of their dry wines are harvested at Spätlese and Auslese levels.) Of course the other thing that happened when MWM closed up shop and its growers were absorbed by other portfolios is that we got great deals on Riesling. Apparently there are a handful of collectors who care very much about Riesling, but the general public doesn’t actually consume that much of it. I can only imagine that this proved incredibly challenging for Dan, Lars, and Mosel Wine Merchant, considering that MWM only sold German wine.  I would assume that the un-sell-ability of German wine was also responsible for the movement of Terry Theise’s portfolio in North Carolina back in 2007. Whatever the case, once again in my wine career, I found myself benefitting from a German portfolio changing hands. (As an aside, I had a long conversation in the Loire with Matthias and Clemens about their wines being offered at “close-out” prices. Matthias especially was unsettled by this, not wanting to be thought of as a producer of “cheap wine.” I understand and respect this. The work these producers do in the vineyards is superior and their sites are exceptional. The wines should command prices that reflect this. On the other hand, we have to trust that our customers recognize a close-out price when they see one and realize that 1) it’s temporary and 2) they should seize the day! Furthermore we hope that a brief period of reduced prices will serve to encourage new folks to try these wines – the way I was originally introduced to German Riesling during The Great North Carolina Terry Theise close-out.) I’m going to speak about one wine from each of these three special growers – barely a nick on the surface as each works with such complex and various terroir. These are the three wines that made the most impact on me, personally, serving to re-enthuse me about Riesling.The first highlight of my recent foray into Riesling drinking was 2011 Röttgen from Knebel (my apologies that the picture shows 2010...), tasted at L’Herbe Rouge in the Loire Valley. This wine comes from blue slate, perhaps the most well-known of the numerous colors of slate that exist in the Mosel. Lars Carlberg’s website (which costs less than $40/year for a subscription and is a wonderful resource) offers a beautiful picture of Röttgen in the lower Mosel. The terraces are as steep as those of the Côte-Rôtie, amongst the steepest in the region. Knebel uses native yeast and long, slow élèvage on the lees, mostly in stainless steel. Though the wines are often dry, some show a hint or more of residual sugar, but judicious amounts that balance the wine. This particular example has 15 grams of sugar, which feels just about perfect. In some ways the wine tastes classic with its peachy and exotic pineapple-y aromas and flavors resonating in the mouth with acid and flavors of cool, blue slate. There’s a subtlety to Matthias’ wines that makes a delightful contrast to the power of Immich-Batterieberg and the unique, natural and sometimes oxidative nature of Clemens Busch’s wines. As much as one reads on the internet to supplement knowledge, there’s no substitute for talking to the winemaker. While tasting this wine with Matthias, he told me about the death of his father in 2004 and his struggles taking over the Domaine. (I thought I was young to have deceased parents!) Matthias must have been barely out of school if that when his dad died. With much assistance from Gernot Kollman, who made the wines during the mid-2000s, he was able to take the reigns at the Domaine rather expertly.Next came a bottle of 2011 Steffensberg from Immich-Batterieberg. The bottle was left over after our Super Bowl party in the hostel in Anger. I shoved it in my bag to take home to the states along with some Lahaye Violaine, and a bottle of Chinon Blanc from Olga Raffault. From soft soil with copper colored slate, Steffensberg may not be the top site for Immich (the vines are a mere 60 years old, minimum, and ungrafted versus the 80 year old vines of some of the other Crus), but it holds a special place in my heart because the bottle I brought back from France was so delicious. The nose offers red and yellow fruits, an exciting twist in a glass of Riesling, and upon first opening it, I thought it smelled quite a bit like sweet, yellow cherries. The palate was dry but warm and ripe (this site faces south and is the warmest of the Immich Crus) with a creaminess that I loved. As usual with an awesome bottle of Riesling, there were layers of flavor culminating in a grippy, slate-y finish. And the bottle kept getting better over three days open, another advantage to Riesling, which often improves considerably over several days open as the sulfur in the bottle dissipates. Possessed of a constantly smiling face, Gernot is a knowledgeable and inquisitive person. He is well worth seeking out at a tasting if you have the chance… Finally, I took home a bottle of 2010 Clemens Busch Vom Roten Scheifer last week. It was one of the few remaining from what has been a size-able haul at close-out time. The bottle was so damn good. On the third day open, the wine was singing alongside some obscure book I was reading, and I knew I had to write this post. I’d been pondering it for awhile: how to write about German Riesling when I often eschew it, when so much has already been written and is being written, and at such a high level. In Quaker School, they used to tell us that when the spirit moves you to speak, you should suppress it twice, and if it rises up inside you a third time, it’s proved itself insuppressible, and you should give it voice. Maybe that’s what happened over the course of my three days with this wonderful bottle.In some ways, Clemens is the original. He’s certainly the first German grower I met and spoke to at length. We’ve drunk beer together at Eleven Madison Park; we’ve chatted at 2am in Le Cercle Rouge in Anger. I am always happy to see the inspirational Clemens Busch. I’ll let you hop on Lars’ site if you’d like to read more about the Domaine. The important things to note about Clemens are that his use of organic and biodynamic methods in the vineyard is rare, as is his low-intervention regime in the cellar. Other people do not make wine like Clemens. His wines undergo very long fermentations with native yeast. (The first time I met Clemens, he had a wine still in barrel that had been fermenting for years.) His avoidance of sulfur means that malolactic fermentation occurs regularly, and the winemaking is more oxidative than reductive. In addition to their singularity, Clemens’ wines are extremely transparent to vintage, I’ve found, and are often more delicious in cooler years, such as 2010. Vom Roten Scheifer comes from red slate in Rothenpfad and Nonnengarten. Clemens has some very old vines in these vineyards and I’d say Vom Roten has the depth and resonance of old vines. On opening, the wine was crunchy and zesty with citrusy red fruits such as sumac and red currant. It was very lively and energetic for a Clemens Busch wine, which I attributed partly to the vintage.
