It was wound up on day one and not as harmonious as on days two and three, when red, sour cherry notes started to emerge. By the end of its life in my fridge, it had taken on a mellow, burnished, and pastry or crème brulee-like character, which melded very nicely with its sour cherry notes. This was only the beginning and the middle, before the wine gave way to its mouth-coating and slate-y finish. Each glass, each sip, even, of this wine was a little revelation. I should drink more Riesling… and so should you. In addition to these beautiful bottlings from Matthias, Gernot, and Clemens, I have also had super experiences recently with wines from Weiser-Künstler, Falkenstein, and Lauer… Go forth and seek out some German Riesling!

item.title: Unusual Pairings: Champagne and BLTs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My coworker and friend JBT has been around the food and wine block many times and he always seems to have a wealth of pairings up his sleeve; many of them are unusual, unorthodox harmonies, even… A few weeks ago it was Poulsard and Pad Thai; the other day it was Champagne and BLTs. While I haven’t gotten around to testing the Poulsard/Pad Thai combination, Champagne and BLTs sounded intriguing and I thought I’d give it a go.Tomatoes are in season right now. As a southerner, I have a particular fondness for tomatoes. I grew up eating them in abundance all summer long, and when I was a teenager I worked at a produce market in rural North Carolina that sold 25 cases of German Johnsons a day during the height of the season. This rivals CSW’s Pierre Gonon sales when a new vintage is released.  The raw tomato tends to show best when the least is done to it, hence the caprese salad, the tomato sandwich (sliced tomatoes, mayonnaise, white bread, salt, pepper), and the queen of sandwiches: the bacon, lettuce, and tomato. There is absolutely no point in preparing any of these dishes unless you have a great tomato, meaning that they grace my table at only one time of year, and the heart grows fonder and hungrier over the course of the long, bleak, tomato-less winter. The perfect summer tomato is a challenge for wine. Provençal Rosé sometimes works as does Loire Valley Sauvignon Blanc, but in general the sweet yet tangy and vegetal flavors of the tomato clash with most wines. The tomato is a fruit, and possessed of its own residual sugar and acidity that cry out to be mirrored in a wine for successful pairing, and where do we find this? One place we find it is in Champagne, and not the bone-dry, hipster Champagnes I’m generally touting, but broad, traditional, dosed Champagnes. It was this logic (and the fact that I had an open sample of one such Champagne) that prompted me to test JBT’s pairing.You’ll likely need no instruction to make a BLT. Slowly fry bacon, slice tomatoes, layer with lettuce between slices of good quality white bread slathered with mayonnaise, season with salt and pepper.  It’s traditional in my homeland to use iceberg lettuce and wonder bread, and the argument has been made by one of my dear North Carolinian friends that Miracle Whip is preferable to mayo when summer tomatoes are involved. (Incidentally he’s also a fan of fruit and fish liaisons. No comment.) Personally, I don’t feel the need to sacrifice to a tradition of low quality ingredients. I doctored my BLT up a bit by adding basil and arugula, dressed very lightly with olive oil and sherry vinegar. (Papa’s turning in the grave at this spoofilation of the BLT.) It’s crucial to use enough mayonnaise. JBT suggests homemade mayo or pesto mayo. Those seem fine to me, but please do use mayo – not reduced fat mayo – and use enough of it. Mayonnaise is a product that gets a bad rap and many people claim not to like it… but it’s absolutely essential to this sandwich. I went back for more, having not applied enough the first time around.To drink I had Cuvée des Grands Vintages from Éric Rodez, a grower with six hectares of vines in the famous Grand Cru of Ambonnay. Rodez is a producer I was tipped off to by RSG, the former Champagne buyer at Chambers Street, and I thank her very much for the tip. Though I have never been to visit Rodez, I hope to one day. He intrigues me, and I’m intrigued by his Champagnes, which are broad and burnished, powerful examples of Grand Cru Ambonnay. We learn from Peter Liem’s Champagneguide.net that Rodez is an 8th generation winemaker who spent time both working in Burgundy and at Krug, where he learned to use wood in the cellar. His wines have a distinct wood influence, though one would never call them “oaky.” We also learn that Rodez farms biodynamically and has great respect for the environment. He does not believe that organic viticulture is a sustainable answer for the future because it relies on the use of copper in the vines, which is poisonous to the soils though approved by organic viticulture. For Rodez, biodynamics, which takes the whole ecosystem into consideration, is the only answer for sustainably healthy soil. He takes steps to reduce his carbon footprint that Eric Texier might applaud.What most seems to set Rodez apart from other growers is his craftsman-like blending. In fact most small growers do not hold very much reserve wine because it’s costly to do so. Rodez may make up to 60 different wines each vintage, meticulously separating juice not just by plot, but by vine age as well. His finished wines generally combine some wood and some tank raised juice, some that has undergone malolactic fermentation and some that has not, as well as numerous vintages. While the size of Rodez’s operation is typical of a grower (and the attention to vineyard work typical of an excellent grower), the material he has to work with for his finished wines – the sheer variety of shades on the palette in which to dip the brush – may be more typical of a négociant. This is a fine tension and one that yields delicious results, at least judging by the small handful of Rodez wines I’ve had the pleasure to taste. It’s proven a bit difficult to find out exactly what was going on in the bottle of Cuvee des Grands Vintages that I enjoyed with my BLT. Unfortunately there is no information such as base year, dosage, and disgorgement date on the back label, though it does helpfully tell us that the wine is 60% Pinot and 40% Chardonnay (also that it “shows the pure essence of soil and fruit character…”). The gentleman who sold me the wine seemed to think the “Grands Vintages” contained in the bottle were 2002, 2004, 2005, and 2006. Had I not consulted Peter’s site, I likely would have believed him. However perusal of Champagneguide.net leads me to think that the juice in the bottle is quite a bit older. I believe the wine I enjoyed with my BLT was either base 2002 or base 2004. Base 2002 suits the varietal breakdown listed on the back (base ’04 was 70/30 Pinot/Chard) but base 2004 is apparently the current release. In either case, the base year vintage is the youngest wine in the bottle comprising 30-40% of the blend; the rest is juice from the ‘90s and early 2000s. (How cool is that?!?) The base wine is fermented in wood, without malolactic fermentation, and as to dosage? Who knows… ? It tasted to me like 6-8 grams, which is also consistent with the wine being base ‘02 (’04 was dosed lower at 4 grams).  It’s an interesting question: do we want mystery or do we want certainty? Sometimes it can be almost impossible to have certainty with multi-vintage Champagne, so I’ll have to settle for delectable mystery. I liked the wine very much. It was nutty, evolved, luxurious, and stately, no longer bursting at its seams with lively bubbles. The style is not my favorite because I do prefer a racier, more chiseled and soily, acid-driven Champagne. I’d likely have taken a bottle of Prevost or Laval in its stead had I had the chance… but as it took me out of my comfort zone and melded with my evening and my meal, I thoroughly enjoyed it. I’d say there were two symbioses that made the pairing with BLTs a good one. First, the acid and sweetness of the Champagne played nicely with the acid and sweetness of the wine, both showing high levels of one and an appropriate touch of the other. Second (and this surprised me) the savory, toasty and caramel-y notes of mature(ish) barrel fermented, Pinot heavy Champagne inter-played perfectly, practically mimicking the flavors of bacon, which is at once salty, sweet, and savory. Was it the best pairing of my life? Probably not… Was it an indulgent, satisfying, and edifying way to spend a Tuesday night home alone? Absolutely…

item.title: Drinking 2004 Roederer Cristal...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I probably should have waited another decade or two to taste this bottle of wine, but my curiosity was bound to get the better of me before the bottle was ready, so I figured best to drink the wine in good company, company that would want to discuss as well as drink the wine. (No I did not wear my booty shorts and, in fact, all references to Cristal and its connection to the hip-hop community were avoided. Interestingly, Cristal night did herald in an era of Jay-Z listening, but the events are unrelated…) As I may have mentioned in a previous post, I traded my friend who is the wine director at Restaurant Daniel a magnum of Agrapart for a bottle of 2004 Cristal, an exchange of which I was, surely, the greater beneficiary (at least in terms of dollars). We traveled together in Champagne in January, and numerous conversations on the road revealed that I’ve been insulated from the world of négociant Champagne… also that I’d never tasted Cristal. After I acquired the bottle, I bragged to a number of cronies about it, and roughly have of them replied “Cristal is fantastic wine. You’re in for a treat,” while the other half replied “It’s a good Champagne, but I bet you’ll be underwhelmed.” Of course after these divergent responses there was no way I was going to be able to keep my hands off the bottle.So I took it to dinner at Brooklynguy’s house when I knew Peter Liem would be in attendance, along with a long time Portland client who has been collecting wine since I was middle or even elementary school age. These are fans of Cristal and I knew they’d be pleased to drink the wine with me, also to offer their own insights. Clearly I wanted to hear what Peter had to say about the wine, especially, as our greatest expert on the region. (Additionally, BK has a set of superior Champagne flutes of the Riedel Vintage Sommelier variety, and, while I’m not a huge subscriber to the theory that glassware makes or breaks a wine, I did drink some Ledru out of these flutes once, and it tasted great.) My bottle kept unusual company on the table that night. There were two vintages of Overnoy Arbois Blanc open: 2000 (Savagnin) and 2010 (Chardonnay). And we drank the Cristal as a sort of palate cleanser between courses. This may have been the first dinner party in the history of the species at which Cristal was served as a palate cleanser after Overnoy and before Lopez de Heredia. The thought tickled me: a famous Champagne that has become emblematic of luxury, quality, and opulence, rinsing away the mouth-coating and deliciously oxidative flavors of 2000 Overnoy.A few quick words about what Cristal is (for the full history, including the story of Roederer’s bottling of Cristal in a clear vessel for Tsar Alexander II, please consult Peter’s site: www.champagneguide.net): Cristal is Roederer’s Prestige Cuvée. It’s a vintage dated blend, generally of 60% Pinot Noir and 40% Chardonnay. The Chardonnay is sourced from Le Mesnil, Avize, and Cramant, while the Pinot comes from Verzenay, Verzy, Beaumont-sur-Vesle, Aÿ, and Mareuil-sur-Aÿ. It’s important to note that Cristal is entirely estate fruit; some will argue and probably correctly, that Cristal is a “grower” Champagne. Folks tend to raise this point when they are arguing that it’s arbitrary to prefer grower Champagne for the sake of its “RM”-ness. I understand the point; it’s what’s in the glass that counts and Cristal is the result of well-tended, estate owned vineyards in excellent Crus in Champagne. Along with fabulous cellar-work, this is a recipe for top notch Champagne. The base wine is fermented 15-25% in wood and the house systematically avoids malolactic fermentation. The wine is known to be incredibly age-worthy. I learned while drinking 2004 Cristal that 2002 was a power house of a vintage for the wine and that it was hard for 2004 to follow on its heels. (Cristal was not made in 2003.) Knowing the vintages, this doesn’t surprise me as 2002 is a powerful year and 2004 more subtle though also a great vintage. Apparently Roederer releases Cristal more often than some other houses release a Prestige Cuvée because they believe in showing the character of all but the most problematic vintages. 2004 suffered in repute purely in virtue of having followed 2002. What a shame! All this idle chitchat and you’re clearly on the edge of your seat, dear reader, wondering if I liked the wine, and the answer is: I loved the wine. My reviews to my colleagues after the fact sounded something like this: “Cristal had all the qualities I look for in a great Champagne: stunning texture, length, intense, powerful chalkiness on the finish, burnished, golden aromas that were, I reckon, somewhat infantile (meaning the wine is clearly tightly coiled, structured, and going somewhere), perfect balance, etc…” I’ve been disappointed by many of the other prestigious Champagnes I’ve tried: Dom Perignon, Krug (my experiences with Krug have been mixed and I generally blame my palate and not the wine), etc… but I was not disappointed by Cristal and I’m extremely glad I drank it. Clearly this was a delicious experience, and it made me want to bring all my evaluations of Champagne back to the glass. So often my assessments of Champagne are theoretical, cerebral, and it was refreshing to remember that I can rely on my sense of smell and taste alone to analyze a bottle of wine so far outside my realm of experience. (PS: The next day I had a headache; must have been the sulfur!) The following morning I received an email from another regular Portland client. The exchange was as follows and I've decided to attach it as a coda. PC: "wow...i'm surprised you like Cristal ;) what did you think of the dosage?  i find it distinctive...almost too obvious in some vintages...and compared to the other Champagne I drink... i usually find the wine hedonistic, balanced, well made...but not cerebral..." S: "Well it was so flat out delicious that it was hard not to enjoy drinking it. As to the dosage, there was so much power and minerality that the dosage didn't bother me. Would have been like criticizing an ice cream cake for being too sweet. That's just the wine, right? I didn't find it to be particularly cerebral. What was thought provoking for me was finding all the elements of a great Champagne together in an unaccustomed package. But yes rather obvious, for sure." In fact I considered commenting on Cristal's dosage and decided against it because the wine's overall integration was such that all I could really have said was "I apprehend that this wine has more dosage than the Champagnes I usually drink" with no value judgement connected to the statement because I couldn't possibly have imagined or wanted the wine to be any other way. Injudiciously dosed Champagne leaves the drinker thinking "Gee; I wish this wine were drier/sweeter..." while judiciously dosed Champagne tastes like itself, like it's supposed to taste.

item.title: Lunch with Oliver Jullien
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: And another enjoyable wine experience of late was lunch with Olivier Jullien of Mas Jullien in Jonquières (Coteaux du Languedoc – or the newer and more terroir specific appellation – Terraces du Larzac). In a relationship with Rosenthal Wine Merchant of over two decades, Oliver had never visited New York. This was several weeks ago, now, but the wines and food were memorable and well worth documenting. The ever amusing, knowledgeable, tireless, and loquacious Neal Rosenthal was our host, and lunch took place at The Modern, which I mistakenly and embarrassingly thought was somewhere in the nether regions of Manhattan when in fact it’s … well … you know: uptown. The result of this rookie New Yorker gaff was that I was late, but Neal quickly allayed my embarrassment and my impatient foot-tapping on the uptown train was forgotten as soon as there was 2011 Mas Jullien Blanc in my glass.Mas Jullien is a superb Domaine in a part of France where there are only a few of such caliber. I’d say that while Olivier’s work is innovative (as I’ll discuss shortly), his wines are classical stylistically. These days we tend to forget about the Great Domaines of the Languedoc, where it seems that every year a new hipster producer who wanted to make carbonic Gamay but couldn’t afford land in the Beaujolais pops up, generally applying organic/natural vineyard and cellar practices to Grenache and Carignan with mixed results. (You’ll have to excuse my prose this time around; I’ve been reading David Foster Wallace short stories and I’m sure quite a few of us know how the tone of such a distinct writer can affect one’s voice when it comes to putting words on the page.) And so more staid and traditional producers who are doing great work fall by the wayside a bit, at least amongst my age group of drinkers. Of course many wine savvy people know that MJ is the real deal, that the wines are age-worthy, powerful, yet graceful expressions of the schist and limestone that mark this terroir. In truth, I’ve had the utmost respect – and have been drinking these wines – for years, and even I need to be reminded sometimes that they are sensational. After much deliberation as to whether to intersperse what I learned about Mas Jullien over the course of the meal with notes on the wines we drank, which is perhaps the more organic way of documenting a wine lunch, I’ve decided to put revelations about the Domaine below, followed by tasting notes. Olivier Jullien is profoundly innovative in the best possible sense. While he’s not concerned with wine fashion, he’s constantly changing what he does, constantly seeking, with the objective of making better wine. He looks for new terroirs in and around Jonquières and Saint Félix that are higher altitude in order to bring more acidity and better balance to his wines. For the white, he’s changing the blend to incorporate more Carignan Blanc grown on high elevation parcels. For the reds he used to rely heavily on Grenache and Syrah grown on schist soil. Now he’s moved to higher percentages of Mourvèdre and Carignan and he prefers limestone soil. Perhaps most intriguingly (and there was lots of discussion about this at lunch with no real answers though I don’t fault the Rosenthal crew for trying…), he used to make site specific wines such as “Cailloutis” and “Vignes Oubliées” and he now makes three general wines: Mas Jullien Blanc, Mas Jullien Rouge, and the more accessible red called “Les États D’Âme” (“the states of the soul”). It seems that now he’s creating a house style from various parcels, which are constantly in flux as he strives to craft the best wine possible. I approve. The skill and passion of the vigneron are clear in the wines and I can categorically state that never have I tasted so much excellent wine from the Langeudoc as I did as lunch at The Modern.We began the afternoon with 2011 Mas Jullien Blanc. For those of you who are not familiar with MJ Blanc and who only know the red wines, it’s time to discover the white, which is unparalleled in its category in terms of both beauty and age-worthiness. The closest competitor is Mas de Daumas Gassac Blanc, which is also a stunner, and were the two to duke it out at a debutante ball, it’s unclear who would emerge the victor. For myself, I generally have a slight preference for Mas Jullien, which is often the drier of the two. The cepage is Grenache Blanc, Chenin Blanc, Carignan Blanc, Viognier, Clairette, and Roussanne. The wine is aged for two years before release and (I believe) it’s vinified in tank and aged in used barrel. Unlike the white wine of Daumus Gassac, it’s a blend rather than a co-harvest, co-ferment situation. The young white wine of Mas Jullien loudly pronounces its Chenin Blanc with a honeyed, herbal, and lemony quality that is almost creamy like lemon curd. The 2011 had the faintest hint of tropical fruit, which was balanced by acidity and clear structure to age. These are succulent, pleasing young wines that are manifestly intense and complex. If I owned a cellar full, they’d be hard not to touch prematurely (then again if the wine tastes great and brings joy, can we really say it was drunk prematurely?). Fortunately at lunch there was the opportunity to taste MJ Blanc with some age. With the first course of Hamachi Tartare with Trout Caviar and Crème Fraîche we had 1996 “Les Vignes Oubliées” Blanc (out of magnum). Not identical in cepage to the recent vintages of MJ Blanc, this wine comprised two thirds Carignan Blanc and one third Chenin Blanc. Folks are sometimes taken aback when white wines from the Languedoc feature Chenin Blanc. Apparently, however, there has been Chenin in the Languedoc since the dawn of time – especially in the Aveyron – and it’s favored because it drives up acidity. The '96 Vignes Oubliées showed, if anything, more Chenin Blanc character than the young wine with rich, golden color, straw and dried apply, waxy, nutty notes on the nose. It was remarkably fresh, almost herbal, stony, and really quite lovely with the Hamachi, though I found myself glad to have clung to a sip for my cheese at the end of the meal. As aforementioned, Olivier does not make the same wines as he made in the ‘90s.Next we turned our attention to a pairing that would ordinarily have been totally cringe-worthy: fish and red Languedoc wine. In this case the wine was 1995 Coteaux du Languedoc Rouge “Les Cailloutis” (out of magnum) and the dish was Chorizo-Crusted Cod with White Coco Bean Puree and Harissa Oil. The wine had matured in an olive-y way, which of course did wonders for the red, spice accents of harissa. From the end of the Grenache era at Mas Jullien, the wine was also a touch raisin-y with a velvety and resolved texture and weight that was almost Burgundian (what an overused word to denote a lithe and seamless wine, but it gets the point across). It was a deeply spicy, savory wine and, again, the vast majority of Langeudoc wines don’t taste like this... We moved on to 1990 “Cailloutis” (out of magnum) with Rack of Lamb, Niora Peppers, Summer Vegetables, and Peanut Potatoes. My notes on the ’90 Cailloutis are less detailed as I didn’t like it as much as the ’95, which I found to be so expressive and perfectly chosen to complement the food. ’90 Cailloutis was more evolved, but also less gamy and compelling. The lamb, however, was the best lamb I have ever eaten and I pushed through burgeoning fullness to devour the whole piece.For “dessert” we had cheese: Brebirousse D’Argental, which Neal hilariously prefaced by a rant against cheese plates that feature miniscule wedges of a variety of carefully curated cheeses. Apparently Neal prefers a more focused selection. We drank 1989 “Cailloutis” (out of magnum), which offered a return to the savory qualities of the ’95, but with added bottle age, more tertiary aromas, and an elegant, stately presence that reminded me of a mature Barolo or Bordeaux. There was the faintest, rose petal-y note that took me to Piedmont, and also the dusty, spice-boxy warmth of an aging Bordeaux. We learned that ’90 was a warm vintage and that at the time there was no temperature control at the winery. The combination drove up the wine’s volatile acidity, which in turn gave the wine its deeply “animale” qualities. I didn’t smell or taste excessive VA; then again I drink lots of natural wine… As to its ability to pair with the cheese? I pretended I was in France, where bold red wine and cheese are often served at the end of a meal. It worked, but my last sip of ’96 Vignes Oubliées might have been better with the Brebirousse. What can I say? Try as I might, at the end of the day I’m still an American who prefers the symbiosis of rich white wine and cheese. This was the kind of lunch I enjoy at most once a year. The food and wine were unsurpassed; I learned many things about Olivier Jullien for whom my admiration has only deepened, and I was delightfully sandwiched at the table between two archrivals in the wine trade. Thanks for the invitation, Neal!

item.title: Blanca: A Tasting Menu, North Brooklyn Style
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I’m vowing to complete this post without using the ubiquitous seven-letter word beginning with “h” and ending with “r” that springs – seemingly without hesitation – to the tip of the tongue when Williamsburg, Green Point, and Bushwick arise in conversation. Briefly, I’ve spent the duration of my time in New York living in North Brooklyn; I don’t have tattoos; while I’ve been known to enjoy the occasional beer/shot special at one of a few local watering holes and I now ride a vintage steel bike, I consider myself to be a normal human. I find north Brooklyn to be a congenial place to live and I prefer it adamantly to the chi-chi, stroller-strewn environs of south Brooklyn (meaning essentially everything south of Fort Greene.) Perhaps no restaurant gathers more stereotypically arrayed and adorned north Brooklyners than Roberta’s in Bushwick. I lived off the Morgan stop on the L line when Roberta’s opened. It was a motley collection of long tables in a big open room with a pizza oven. There was no liquor license, but the pizza was tasty. Now, about five years later, Roberta’s is a vast compound that features multiple dining areas and bars as well as its own radio station and urban greenhouse garden on the roof. I visit Roberta’s once, maybe twice a year, each time marveling at its sheer growth and development since my last visit. Until my recent experience dining at Blanca, the most intricate meal I’d had at Roberta’s was an Easter multi-course tasting menu a few years ago featuring lamb that had been slaughtered and fabricated by the Roberta’s staff, paired with wines based on the Sagrantino grape variety. It was memorable. I suppose because I’ve watched it develop, garner national acclaim, and grow to epic proportions, I have a sort of fondness in my heart for Roberta’s. It’s an interesting and fundamentally good place; the folks behind it are creative as well as entrepreneurial; the food is generally excellent. With these thoughts in mind, I happily accepted an invitation to dine at Blanca, a high-end, reservation only, sub restaurant of Roberta’s that is tucked away behind the main dining and drinking saloons. Blanca is an airy, open space in which diners eat in a semi-circle overlooking the kitchen. The space reminded me of the teaching facility in Astor Center above Astor Wines and Spirits, all gleaming and white and professional, quite the contrast to the rest of Roberta’s. In spite of the fact that one watches everything as it’s happening in the kitchen, it isn’t an interactive experience, save that the excellent sommelier, Shanti, comes by and gives a sentence or two summation of the beverage pairing (if you go that route; there’s also a more traditional wine list). The tasting menu is roughly 25 courses, and the accompanying tipples range from wine to beer to sake to tea. Unlike other tasting menus, there is no actual, physical document telling you what you’ll be eating, and since phones and cameras are disallowed at Blanca, it was a challenge to remember exactly what was what. Personally I loved the décor as well as the laid back vibe of the place, enhanced by a record player in the corner treating us to The Rolling Stones as well as Metallica while we ate. There’s something inherently and self-consciously “cool” about the place, yet there’s nothing sloppy or slapdash about the food, which is thoughtfully conceived and executed. I won’t be able to remember everything we ate and drank at Blanca, and chef Carlo has asked me to leave my experience somewhat shrouded in mystery, but there were some highlights, which I’ll happily share. Our first couple of courses were served with 2002 Christian Etienne Champagne (Savio Soares Selections) from the Côtes des Bars. I’ve been tasting this producer’s basic wine for several years now and have liked it. This was my first experience with a vintage bottling, and from the superb 2002 vintage. Pinot Noir based, rich, ripe, and fruity, it’s not a wine that would have normally moved me, but it was an apt pick for the starting courses, which were fruits! The first was an intensely sweet and creamy white melon accented with anise. The second was nectarine swimming in house made almond milk. When one drinks bone dry Champagnes, one forgets that Champagne and sweet things can be a good match, but when the Champagne is dosed with 12 grams of sugar, it’s a different story, and there's more harmony to be found between wine and fruit. Following these amuses bouches, we had Copa, then fried veal sweet breads, which complemented another aspect of the wine, its savory, nutty, maturing Champagne notes. The wine transitioned seamlessly between these quite different sets of flavors.Paonnerie Simplement Gamay (Zev Rovine Selections) surprised me on a pairing level, even more than the Champagne had... Paonnerie is a 20 hectare Domaine in the western Loire Valley that has been organic since the early '9os. This bottling is made entirely without sulfur. Paonnerie’s wines tend to offer zippy, generous red fruit, pepper, and bright acid. The first course with Paonnerie was shredded wagyu beef in beef tartar format with radishes and a kohlrabi broth poured over the top. I probably would have looked for a wine with more umami – or even a sherry – for this dish. But the wine gave the dish a welcome treble note belted out amidst a chorus of base-y, earth tones. Next came sun gold tomatoes in a sweet corn broth, which I thought for sure would clash with the wine, but where the beef and kohlrabi offered a foil for the bright, tangy wine, the sun golds and corn broth mimicked it. As so often happens with food and wine pairings, I sat down at the table and unlearned what I thought I knew. Following Paonnerie, we drank this wine (De Maison Selections): I adore this "grower sherry" (meaning Florido operates outside the cooperative; the grapes that go into the wine are estate-grown). This summer I've drunk more sherry than ever before (for no particular reason) with the result that I've learned quite a bit about what I like. Finos with heavy flor character such as Valdespino's Innocente tend to be too much for me. I respect Innocente, but I don't love to drink it. This could be said as well for most of my experiences with Equipo Navazos, the present day starlets of Jerez. I find the wines to be too intense to be fun to drink after one small glass. On the other hand the finos I used to enjoy of old such as La Cigarerra Manzanilla just don't deliver enough complexity. My favorites this summer have been 1) Gutierrez Colosia's Elcano, which absolutely blew me away last fall at El Quinto Pino for its ability to deliver fine, delicate fruit character as well as flor, alcohol, and umami, 2) Valdespino's Manzanilla En Rama "Delicioso," an unfiltered Manzanilla that has abundant flavor, and 3) the salty yet soft, silky textured Chipiona from César Florido. This is not my order of preference, merely my order of discovery. My apologies for the digression. More meaningful than any verbal praise is the fact that Chipiona was on the shelf at Chambers Street Wines within three days of my dinner at Blanca. We drank this sherry with Little Neck Clams and it was great.2007 Jasnières "Charmes" from odd-ball winemaker Jean-Pierre Robinot sang alongside tofu and pea purée followed by sea perch and egg yolk topped with black lime. My revelation during these courses was that, though in general Robinot's white wines are too oxidative for me, this bottle did well with the foods. This is no surprise as oxidative white wines often have an ability to stand up to and meld with strongly flavored foods that reductively made, crisp white wines do not. The wine might have slightly over-powered the tofu and pea, but was perfect with the perch. At this point I should mention that if you dine at Blanca and order pairings, the pairings you'll receive will be tailored to you. A few days after our meal, I called Shanti to ask for more details, and she told me that she essentially reads people during the early courses and then determines how adventurous they are for pairings down the road. She likes oxidative wines and keeps a healthy roster of Jura selections, but you will need to prove yourself before she'll pour them for you.I tasted the best beer I have ever had: Ron the Red Ryan from Evil Twin Brewing Company. This is a saison-style beer aged in red wine barrels at about 7% alcohol. With beer, I can't even fake it, I have no idea what made this brew so damn good. Suffice it to say that the beer was spicy and aromatic and substantial but in no way sweet, cloying, or heavy. It was ruddy in color and smelled much like a natural wine made from Pineau D'Aunis, and as all of us who drink natural wine know, sometimes "natural wine" aromas work far better in beer than they do in wine. Sadly this Red Ryan beer is exclusive to Roberta's. Shanti was nice enough to give us one in our doggy bag, which we'll savor at some point down the road. It was paired with two pastas: andouille ravioli, which made me feel as though I'd ordered nachos at the ball game (in the best possible way), and grapefruit orecchiette, which was the only dish we ate out of 25-ish that was not, in my opinion, a success.  I'll end my notes with 201o Ghostwriter Chardonnay from the Santa Cruz Mountains (Regal Wine), which was paired with several dishes; the most notable to my palate was Japanese eggplant, daikon, and yogurt. My friend NV (or Vulgar Little Monkey as many wine folks know him) in North Carolina was raving about these wines when I was home over the winter. This is the first one I've ever tried. The wines are made by a guy named Kenny Likitprakong, who graduated from UC Davis and has made wine under several brands including Hobo, Banyan Wines, and Folk Machine. The Ghostwriter wines come in both Pinot and Chardonnay from small plots of less than five hectares in the Santa Cruz Mountains. This is the extent of my knowledge... and I'm trying to find out more, but the Ghostwriter wordpress site just gives me an impressionistic paragraph quasi-explaining the name "Ghostwriter." (And this blurb features the cringeworthy word "cherish" so I've had to turn away.) American wine is virtually unchartered territory for me. I never taste minerality in American wine, that mouth-coating, porous layer that great old world wine leaves behind once you've swallowed (or spit, if at a professional tasting). But I'm beginning to think there is minerality in American wine; I just don't know how to taste it because I'm so accustomed to Jurassic limestone. Before I digress a second time, the Ghostwriter wine was sensational with eggplant and daikon with yoghurt. Balanced, crunchy, lightly oaky, and full but not "hot" from high alcohol, it's creaminess played alongside the yoghurt and its earth tones were a pleasant match for the eggplant and daikon. There is much more that could be written about our meal at Blanca. This is merely a portion of what we ate and drank. At the end of dinner, we chatted with Shanti, sipped some bourbon and met chef Carlo, who we'd been watching all evening as he directed the show. As we strolled out of the restaurant, weaving through the picnic tables of kids drinking beer, I commented that I felt neither stuffed nor drunk, but rather inspired by the meal we'd had. Blanca is not cheap. It costs as much as dining at Daniel, where I have had the good fortune to dine twice. The cost is unfortunate in a way, not because it's not worth it, rather because adventurous food and wine geeks seem to be the target audience and we typically are not rich by any means. Since dining at Blanca, I've spoken to a number of my friends who say that they'd love to go to Blanca, but the price is prohibitive, and I understand. However the experience is awesome, and in many ways more creative and interesting than a tasting menu at Daniel, which offers a more posh, classical, luxurious experience. If the occasion arises to treat yourself to something really special, and you're curious about this kind of avant-garde tasting experience, I'd encourage you to go to Blanca.

item.title: Shit Happens: Drinking Right When Things Go Wrong.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Before I kick off this post, I’d like to mention that a few nights ago I was sifting through the comments (mostly spam) that I receive on my various postings on Sophie’s Glass. A gentleman had taken the time to go onto my site not once but twice to tell me how self-absorbed, long-winded, and generally unreadable he found my writing. I didn’t approve his comments because they didn’t have much content save for his dislike of my penmanship, but it got me thinking. Long-winded, I am! Blogging, however, is inherently self-absorbed. What is blogging if not an individual’s experiences and opinions out there in the world for other humans to read… or not? Without further ado, I cordially invite anyone who doesn’t enjoy my writing not to read my blog. Click the little x in the corner of the window, sir, and find something you like reading more. I promise I will not be offended. If you’re still reading, I warn you in advance that this post is self-absorbed, and is likely not my finest effort. I recently broke the 5th metatarsal bone in my left foot whilst running in North Carolina. My foot is ensconced in a large, ugly, black orthopedic boot, and I’m using crutches to get around, which is no picnic in New York City. (It’s difficult to imagine the frustration of crutches until you’ve used them. They’re quick to slide off any slick surface; they make you much wider than you’d normally be, and don’t be surprised to note the development of pectoral muscles you never knew you had.) They tell me the bone will heal... in about four months. It’s no fun; however I’m tired of complaining about it… and I’m tired of feeling sorry for myself. The truth is – and I know it sounds cheesy – that since it happened I’ve felt lucky for what I have. (I’ve also noted that New Yorkers are much nicer now that I’m on crutches. I haven’t wanted for a seat on the train; folks stop to open heavy doors… Faith is rekindled in this hard, fast, inclement city.) This metatarsal fracture has prevented me from indulging in one of my loves, namely running, but thankfully I can still drink wine. I drank some delicious things in North Carolina, chosen and sent by friends who rallied around during… if not a time of need… certainly a time of want. 2008 base Tarlant Brut Rosé Zero cut through the muggy haze that hangs over North Carolina in the summer.The more Tarlant I drink, the more I love the estate. Benoît is the current winemaker as of 1999, but it’s an old Marne Valley Domaine dating back to the 17th Century. As with other favorites in the eastern Marne such as Laherte, Tarlant farms many different parcels of vines, each unique in terroir, etc… The wines are dominated by Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier, and to me they show a green, almost vegetal character that I associate with Meunier as well as low dosage. I find Tarlant’s wines to be marked by cellar work. The majority of the base wines are made in wood; malolactic fermentation is avoided, and dosages are low to nonexistent. The “house” style is rich and broad, yet rigorously dry. Tarlant’s work in the vines is also excellent. Pesticides and fertilizers are not used, and Tarlant works with cover crops depending on the plot. If anything, Tarlant listens to each plot in each vintage, letting circumstance dictate vineyard work. There is incredible attention to detail at Tarlant and the wines have a finely wrought lustre. Perusing Peter Liem’s review of Tarlant yields lots of detail regarding Tarlant’s higher end bottlings, which are superb, yet I remain blown away by the quality of the “basic” Brut Zero and Brut Rosé Zero, which deliver lots complexity for the price. As I’m sure I’ve mentioned more than once, it’s the ultimate testimony to the skill of a Champagne grower that he or she make complex wine at the introductory level. I learned from Peter Liem’s site that the 2008 base Tarlant Rosé Zero is the first rendition of this wine to be made with Pinot Noir in the blend (vinified white that is…), which comprises about 20%; the rest is Chardonnay, with 13% still red wine made from Pinot Noir and Meunier completing the assemblage. (I’m sure I’ve also mentioned this before, but Peter Liem’s website: www.champagneguide.net is quite possibly the most informative and scholarly wine website to date. It costs about $90/year to subscribe, which, if you’re shelling out for bottles of Champagne, is a drop in the bucket.) As is the case with many Champagnes based on the 2008 vintage, the wine’s 2008-ness screams out loud and clear in the form of a laser-like explosion of acid, concentration, and minerality on the finish. It’s clear that Peter found it to be a bit austere at his last tasting of it late in 2012; I think it’s mellowed, almost a year later. Still its pronounced notes of cranberry and pink grapefruit remain, along with the earthy, vegetal hint I frequently discern in Tarlant’s wines. The bubbles are creamy, tight, and maintained their structure and verve as we depleted the bottle. With its total lack of dosage, it may not be for everyone, but it was great for a sultry night in North Carolina. Later that evening, an unusual pairing surprised and delighted the humble blogger. The hosts prepared pizzas, which were allegedly to be cooked in the outdoor pizza oven they’d constructed earlier in the day. (I have a soft spot for homemade pizza ovens, as I’m fairly certain my mother yearned for one until her dying day.) As it turned out, the exterior oven needed a few test runs before it could surpass the kitchen oven’s ability to produce pizza. We moved indoors, where the host assembled a pizza topped with olive oil, marinated jalapenos, really ripe figs from their own tree, and feta cheese. One can only imagine what kind of sweet, spicy, salty combination met the palate. What wine could possibly rise to the occasion? What wine could step up to the pairing plate with such loud, almost garish flavors at work? Three cheers for 2011 Cros Marcillac Lo Sang del Pais.Marcillac is an off-the-grid appellation in the western part of the Auvergne, in the massif central. The grape used is a peppery little number know locally as "Fer Servadou,” though it also masquerades as “Mansois” in other parts of the southwest. Though Marcillac is a very old winemaking region, many growers left after the phylloxera and now Marcillac is virtually unknown. Domaine du Cros, at 22 hectares, is one of the only available Marcillacs this side of the Atlantic. Lo Sang del Pais, made from the Domaine’s younger vines grown on red, iron-rich soil and in matured chestnut barrels (some of which are several centuries old) is always redolent of Jalapeno peppers on the nose, which, I’m convinced contributed to its harmony with the pizza. After I returned to New York, I tasted 2012 Le Sang; 2011 must have been a ripe vintage for the wine because the wine was fruitier than I’d known it to be in previous years. This fruitiness contributed to its ability to match the sweetness of the figs. The 2012 was more austere, higher in acid, firmer in structure, and likely more suitable for sausages, which I normally would have preferred, but alongside this wonderful thin crust pizza, 2011 was definitely the preferable vintage. (Did I mention that this wine retails for about $15? It’s a steal.) As a dedicated Champagne drinker, I am amazed by the few sparkling wines from the Canary Islands. How does a good sparkling wine come to be in a place where high acidity isn’t possible? Yet Bermejos sparkling Malvasia alongside ever-so-slightly under-ripe, creamy figs (yes figs are a recurring theme in North Carolina in August with fresh chèvre was absolutely outstanding.It turns out to be not so easy to learn about Bermejos. Their website seems to rely most on pictures of the incredibly striking, black, mountainous desert of Lanzarote, where the grape vines rest, coiled like little buns in a snood to protect them from wind (as on Santorini). I have heard that Bermejos is one of the more “mainstream” Canary Islands producers, and extreme Canaries wine fans tend to write them off as a bit glossy. Certainly it’s the first Canaries producer I ever encountered, and it continues to be a favorite. The more obscure Canaries producers seem to make wines that are a trifle extreme for me. Also, while I’ve always been attracted to the smoky, brooding minerality of Canaries wines, the lack of acidity often bothers me. This Espumoso Brut Nature is made using Méthode Champenoise, and is aged on the lees for nine months. Brut Nature sparkling wines from warm terroirs are quite a bit more accessible than their brethren from further north. With this wine, there’s a voluptuous, honeyed, almost dried fruit character to the midpalate and finish that creates an interesting impression as it marries with the bubbles, which are fine and buoyant. The aromas are totally unlike the sharp, green, tangy, chalky ones I’m used to finding in Champagne. Bermejos Brut Nature smells like garrigue, wild thyme, and brushy desert. It’s very restrained for the Malvasia variety, yet very aromatic nonetheless. There’s an earthiness that I often find in Cava, but more refined and less sharp and rustic. This wine was fascinating; I purchased and drank it again upon my return to New York and liked it just as much as the first time… Regardless of injury, I spent a fulfilling few days in North Carolina. My chief complaint about my hometown is that there is no good coffee for those who can't make their own. I do not understand how an area so rich in food and wine can be totally devoid of high quality specialty coffee, especially considering that Durham is home to Counter Culture, a major player in the specialty coffee game. A friend who now imports wine, making regular trips to far flung North Carolina towns such as Asheville and Charlotte, keeps this combination on hand to fuel the journey (you should be ashamed, Counter Culture, that local coffee geeks have to rely on Stumptown for their juice:Thanks for taking care of me friends. You made it possible for me to drink well in spite of everything.

item.title: Dosage Panel: Some Like it Sweet!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Thanks to the generous folks at Michael Skurnik wines, I was recently invited to participate in a tasting and panel discussion of Champagne and dosage. My crutches and I escorted one another to this fine affair, where a room full of New York wine luminaries assembled to taste and learn. Our host, Kevin Pike of Skurnik wines, was joined at the speaker’s table by writers Peter Liem, Josh Raynolds, and John Bonné. The tasting was divided into two parts. The first part centered around seven renditions of exactly the same wine, finished differently, all served blind. Our objective was to try to taste the differences between wines dosed with cane or beet sugar, the substance traditionally used to add sweetness to Champagne, and wines dosed with MCR (moût concentré rectifié), concentrated grape must. Whence and what is MCR? MCR is a super-sweet grape concentrate comprising fructose and glucose. It’s primarily made in the Languedoc to use up an over supply of ripe grapes. (It’s worth noting that the sugar in traditional dosages is sucrose.) Please read this article from Peter Liem’s former blog: http://www.peterliem.com/2008/07/dosage-liqueur-vs-mcr.html in order to understand the gist of the sugar vs. MCR argument. As a point of introduction to this topic, Kevin pointed out that while buyers are quick to ask “how much dosage?” they almost never ask “MCR or cane/beet sugar?” The tendency is to request an array of data, and then to over-simplify it. “Dosage” translates to “sugar added,” when an answer to the question “how much sugar?” barely scratches the surface of what goes on. Growers look to the “liqueur d’expédition” to finish the wine; many specially select wine with which to blend the sugar or MCR – an oak aged wine, a reserve wine, perhaps, to add another layer to the final product. In the same way that we can’t come up with an English translation for “terroir” that captures the essence of the word, our distillation of “dosage” to “sugar added” somehow doesn’t do it justice. It seems to be enough to say: “this wine has six grams dosage.” As it turns out MCR and cane sugar are qualitatively different. We know from the effects of high fructose corn syrup on foods we eat, that fructose is sweeter than sucrose. 6.5 grams of MCR turns out to be the equivalent of 8 grams of sugar. Moving on. Some Champagne growers use MCR; Champagne houses/négociants do not use it. Part of the underlying idea seems to be that it’s intuitively more “natural” or authentic to use a grape based product to sweeten, rather than a cane or beet based one. (I remember Peter’s surprise upon learning at our visit to “natural” Champagne grower André Beaufort, that Beaufort uses cane sugar.) On the other hand, surely there’s no terroir imparted by hyper-concentrated must from the Languedoc. Pascal Agrapart in Avize has experimented with using his own must for the dosage. He makes a wine called “Expérience” that is sweetened with his own must. I have tasted this wine a few times; I prefer his wines dosed with cane sugar. There’s also a regional divide: growers in the Côte des Blancs, who use predominantly Chardonnay, prefer cane sugar, which promotes quicker oxidation. MCR is favored in red grape areas of Champagne for its tendency to slow down the oxidative process. MCR also takes longer to integrate than cane sugar, and it’s thought to affect texture most of all, adding a creamy viscosity to the wine. Time to reveal the results of our blind tasting. My least favorite of the seven wines was #7, dosed with 8 grams MCR; there was a strange plasticity to the nose and the sweetness felt heavy and ponderous. 6th place went to the wine dosed with 8 grams of cane sugar (wine #3 in the lineup), which had candied aromas. 5th place went to the wine dosed with 5 grams MCR (wine #1), which was balanced though sweet for my taste. The acid was crisp and bracing. 4th place went to #4, which merited a “pretty good” meaning nothing offended me, but the wine wasn’t expressive; this one was dosed with 3 grams MCR. 3rd place went to wine #2, which showed apple and pear aromas, was balanced, crisp, pure and pretty; this was dosed with 3 grams of cane sugar. Second place went to wine #6, which was also popular with the group. This wine was quite harmonious, I thought. The nose offered fresh, almost Riesling-like sweetness, appealing texture on the palate, and a long finish. This wine was dosed with 5 grams of cane sugar. I recognize my 1st place choice as a matter of personal preference. Wine #5 stood out for me at the onset. I loved the nose, which was steely crisp. The palate instantly felt lighter and drier, though with some naturally occurring fruitiness on the palate. It was Non-Dosé. Draw from this what you will… I drew from it a natural inclination on my part toward dry Champagne. Interestingly, though, my second favorite wine was not the second driest. I recognize that there’s such a thing as objective balance, and what I noted in wine #6 was an objectively well-balanced wine in which the dosage worked. Proud of myself for an instant, I pondered the fact that personal preference comes as naturally as breathing, but that the ability to objectively assess is an aspect of professionalism. Before I move on to part 2, I’d like to point out something that Josh Raynolds said to me during the panel, namely that my customers (namely Chambers Street Wines’ customers) care about whether dosages are done with cane sugar or MCR. It has not been my experience that they do… but perhaps, geeky as they are, our customers should be asking this question. Perhaps I should be bringing it to the conversation. I just don’t know. I’m an ideologue, on some level, but I don’t feel ideologically bound to one side of this argument or the other. The quest is for good-tasting, age-worthy Champagne… The second part of the panel addressed the present fashion for low-dosage Champagne. There’s lots to be said here. The causes of this trend are thought to be some combination of global warming, which has lessened the need for high dosage to balance the wine as grapes get riper, and the Parisian natural wine movement, which calls for less to no additives in wine. (Peter speculated that the Parisian natural wine movement was partially responsible. It’s an interesting point. I tend to think of Champagne as being largely outside the natural wine movement, but perhaps those Parisian hipsters had an influence after all…) Interesting comments were made about the market. Apparently the biggest market for super-dry Champagne is in Scandinavia; is there a culinary reason for this? It was generally agreed – and this jives with what I’ve heard from growers in Champagne – that while many pay lip service to the fashion, sales numbers don’t back it up. In other words, customers say they favor Extra Brut and Brut Nature Champagne, but their purchases don’t confirm this. Aurélian Laherte was the first grower to point this out to me. He essentially said: ‘We make what our importers buy. They say they want Extra Brut, but they don’t reorder it.’ The second part of the tasting was also conducted blind; it consisted of pairs of identical wines “finished” differently. 2005 Pierre Gimmonet Fleuron, dosed with 6 grams of cane sugar, was ripe and balanced, seamless and harmonious. 2005 Gimmonet Oenophile, left for an additional year on the lees, dosed with 1 gram of sugar had an incredibly savory nose and was a touch austere on the palate after Fleuron. The Oenophile was fascinating, but the Fleuron was delicious. (It’s worth noting here that additional lees aging helps balance drier style Champagnes.) Next there were two Renée Geoffroy wines; I don’t have good notes on these as I was catching up. The first was base 2010 Expression, dosed with 5 grams MCR. The second was a bottling called “Purité,” which was non-dosé. While my notes fail here, I did taste Expression shortly after at the Skurnik trade show and it was fantastic. Geofffroy makes wine in the warm village of Cumières in the eastern Vallée de la Marne; this is prime terroir for red grapes, and also for MCR dosages. The third pair, I recognized instantly as being from the grower Margaine in Villers-Marmery. Margaine’s wines have distinct aromatics and the first bottle, 2008 Extra Brut (bottled as non-vintage), had a very expressive toasty nose and a crisp, crunchy finish. I don’t normally like Margaine’s wines, but this one was so distinct with its nori-like nose that I was drawn to it. The second wine from Margaine was 2008 Special Club. The nose was far more muted, the palate rich, textured and apply from 9 grams dosage with cane sugar and partial barrel fermentation for the base wine. The majority of our group preferred the Special Club. The last pair of wines was eye-opening and polarizing. They were from grower Jean Milan in Oger. The first was his Cuvée Speciale, dosed at 6 grams (of – I’m assuming – cane sugar but don’t have it noted) and the second was his Sec bottling, dosed at 20 grams. When asked to raise their hands in preference for one or the other, the vast majority of the group preferred the Sec bottling. I imagined the newspaper headlines: “Wine Luminaries Proven to Prefer Sweet to Dry Champagne!” We fleshed this out; one wise panelist said that while she tasted the sweetness and probably wouldn’t want a whole bottle of it, she found better balance in the Sec. Many agreed, which I took to be criticism of the Speciale more than anything. I found Speciale to be muted, with a nice earthy note and some minty-fresh herbal qualities, and I found the Sec to be honeyed and totally undrinkable. I didn’t get it, but I’m glad others did. I’m also glad to have the fashion of super-dry Champagnes exposed as what one panelist described as a case of “Emperor’s New Clothes.” I would have liked to hear more about how dosage influences aromas. We talked some about the influence on mouth-feel, but for me one of the biggest draws to Extra Brut and Brut Nature Champagnes is that the aromas are greener, leafier, grassier, earthier; higher dosage seems to mean more honeyed notes, more fruity notes; a few of the sweeter Champagnes we tried smelled liked Riesling to me. I like Riesling, but I don’t especially want my Champagnes to smell like it. Does that make sense? Who knows? This event confirmed my suspicion that I’m a total Champagne hipster. Is it contradictory to say that I’m glad to see the fashion for super-dry Champagne exposed, whilst being a huge lover of super-dry Champagne? Probably… Even as we state that there are loads of people out there who say they like it dry, but don’t actually; we should probably allow for those who say they like it dry and do, in fact, like it dry. Many thanks to the Skurniks, Kevin, Peter, Josh, and John, Gabe and all those who organized and poured. And my humble apologies for so many words without any pictures.

item.title: L’Anglorious.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In April I was eating and drinking in the wonderful restaurant/bar à vins: Le Comptoir, in Montréal’s Le Plateau neighborhood, when my friend Martin Labelle’s beautiful girlfriend Elisabeth told me that on their first date he wooed her with L’Anglore. Excluding Champagne, the most striking and memorable bottles I’ve drunk over the past few months have been from Domaine de L’Anglore, and I’m swooning afresh over this producer. (My apologies if there are too many romantic tropes in this post; for me these wines drag this language to the fingertips as I type.) If I wrote a(nother) newsletter about L’Anglore for Chambers Street, I’d probably be tempted to call it something like “L’Anglore: The Overnoy of the South.” Why this comparison? Both are tiny Domaines that are well regarded in the natural wine world for the purity, singularity, and downright deliciousness of their (no sulfur added) wines.  But to my mind the real comparison comes in the increasing challenge of obtaining them. While I can’t recall a time when Overnoy was easy to come by in New York, I do recall a time when L’Anglore was readily available in the cool room at Astor. No one knew what it was. The purple-labeled Tavel, ostensibly a Rosé but darker than Poulsard, redolent of cinnamon, garrigue and ripe, mixed red and black plums, bing cherries, beside it rested L’Anglore’s intriguing red wines from Tavel: Traverses, Pierre Chaude, and Comèyre (of course bearing a “Vin de Table” designation because the Tavel appellation only allows Rosé wine…). As with Overnoy, production has shrunk and demand has risen as folks begin to discover how special these wines are. I’d even argue (so crucify me… ) that unlike Overnoy, L’Anglore’s wines have gotten better as demand has increased, and this isn’t a critique of Overnoy; it’s a comment about how damn good L’Anglore’s wines are right now. The fact smote me this fall as I drank L’Anglore’s “Chemin de la Brune” and “Sels d’Argent;” these are stunning, sensual, magical wines. No wonder Martin and Elisabeth’s relationship got off to successful start; it’s a smart man who let’s a Pfifferling bottle be the third on a first date. Last summer I milked every connection I had in a concerted effort to visit Pfifferling with AR as we traveled the southeast of France. I thought for sure I could reach him for an appointment through Martin (who represents Pfiff in Quebec) or through Ten Bells, or through Jenny and François, the New York importer. No dice. I finally tracked him down much farther north at Les Pénitents, a trade show in the ancient castle at Anger. For me this was the least exciting of the trade shows; the rooms of the castle were jam packed with the cognoscenti of the natural wine world, gossiping and boozing, winemakers unavailable, impenetrable hoards with empty glasses crowding the tables hoping for a drop. It was worth the claustrophobia, however, finally to meet Pfiff. He was shy and kind as I tasted the wines (“J’adore votre vin; J’ai essayé de vous visiter l’été dernier…”); we didn’t talk much, but I liked putting a face with the name and of course his wines were delicious. Eric Pfifferling was a bee-keeper and honey-maker before he became a vigneron. By good fortune he has very old vines planted on gallet-strewn soil in Tavel. Gallets are the flat stones that famously typify the terroir of Châteauneuf-du-Pape, across the river. Pfiff started making his own wine in the early 2000s, farming his seven hectares by hand and organically, eschewing all chemicals and winery shortcuts. Many people do this; few make wines that are as resonant as Pfifferling’s. Why are these wines so good? I don’t have the answers. I was hoping to obtain them in the south of France last year; I’ll probably try again one day. The summer of Pfifferling began with this bottle…… consumed in early summer alongside tiny wild strawberries. The season for these follows closely on the heels of ramp season and is almost as short. This is Pfifferling’s Tavel Reserve, which sees an additional year of aging in barrel. Last fall when the wine arrived it showed its oak with deep, almost cordial-sweet red fruit aromas and a density and spice on the palate that was intriguing but a little off–putting. Since, any oak the wine showed at first has disappeared allowing the wine to deliver all its gorgeous fruit – signed, sealed, delivered… This would not have been the first wine to spring to mind for strawberries, but it was a memorable pairing that lingered long after the fact. When the fall allocation of Pfifferling arrived, I took home three right off the bat: 2012 Chemin de la Brune, 2011 Sels d’Argent, and Tavel; I’ll only go into detail about the first two. I always like Pfiff’s Tavel as a total departure from the industry standard fat, pink, alcoholic mess, but I believe the pale “Blanc de Noirs” Rosé Chemin de la Brune (Grenache & Cinsault) and the rich yet balanced white Sels d’Argent (Grenache Blanc) are utterly profound wines, and they fly under the radar of Pfiff’s achievements. Coincidentally the first L’Anglore that stole my heart last month was consumed with my friend Brooklynguy on the same evening as a bottle of 2005 Overnoy Poulsard, and it withstood the test of being drunk on the same evening as a great bottle of Overnoy without being totally eclipsed.Before I opened the bottle, I asked Brooklynguy how he felt about L’Anglore. He said he hadn’t loved the ones he’d tasted, which had – as I recall – all been red. He said he felt as though they tasted more like winemaking than like terroir, and I knew what he meant. Pfiff’s red wines are dense with the sweet, ripe fruit of the southern Rhone, and they taste as though they are at least semi-carbonic. Grenache-iness tends to dominate; they are a bit of a challenge for those used to lighter, higher acid reds. I think they are dead sexy, but one has to be in mood for such ebullient, lush fruit. Of course BK was happy to indulge me in drinking L’Anglore and approached our Chemin de la Brune with an open mind (and he liked the wine).This wine is made with a very short maceration, which gives it barely a hint of color, best to think of it as a white wine. It’s a sheer, shimmering beauty that shows subtle apricot and nectarine fruit on the nose and sweet, aromatic orange flower water (imagine a desert that featured this flavoring … ) and distinct pine nuttiness on the palate. This pine nuttiness, for me, marks it as a Mediterranean wine. These notes are found throughout Provençal white wine and in some Italian whites from the Mediterranean coast.  While the aromas are lovely, it’s the palate that takes the drinker above and beyond: silken texture and a broadening and lengthening of the flavors – enlivened by acidity – continuing on and on as the wine glides or floats through the mouth and beyond, finishing with a velvety coating of minerality at the end. The wine is 13.5% alcohol (higher than presently fashionable), and it augments the texture of the wine without feeling disjointed or “hot.” First and foremost, Pfifferling’s wines are unique. The last time I wrote about them for Chambers, I found myself in a diatribe about this word “unique,” its overuse and the tendency to insert senseless modifiers in front of it. Go back to the meaning of this word “one of a kind;” these wines embody a sense of one-of-a-kindness. Secondly, L’Anglore’s wines do not show natural wine flaws, at least in my experience. By natural wine flaws I mean volatile acidity, bacterial aromas, dirtiness (to be distinguished from earthiness) on the palate, and the dreaded “gout de souris” or mousiness, a sensation that attacks the finish, leaving the drinker feeling as though she has sucked on a mouthful of peanut shells. We’ve not yet gotten to the bottom of mousiness, but the prevailing theory is that it’s residual lees or yeast in the wine. Natural winemakers, not wanting to add sulfur to protect against oxidation, are sometimes fearful of racking from one vessel to another, a process that normally banishes residual lees. Depending on your tolerance, mouse may not bother you; personally I cannot drink mousy wines. Like cork taint, mousiness emerges as the bottle is open, becoming more pronounced. I left a fraction of the bottle of Chemin de la Brune in the fridge for two days. It was even better on the third day open than it had been on the first and there was nary a mouse to be found. I cannot begin to express how unusual it is to find wine made without sulfur that offers the drinker such pure, crystalline aromas and flavors. Several days later, overwhelmed by curiosity, I cracked 2011 Sels d’Argent with my friend Susannah. I hadn’t seen it in the states before and a quick taste at Les Pénitants was not enough to give me an idea of what was going on. At 14% alcohol, it's best not to drink this wine either too cold or too warm as the alcohol can feel disjointed and mask the wine's beauty and complexity. At the right temperature, it's expressive, lush, and sexy in a buxom, full-figured way. For me this wine's aromas drew forth Proustian associations with child and young adulthood. When I was living in North Carolina, the slightly odd and off-kilter cantaloupe was my favorite summer fruit. This wine smells exactly like utra-ripe dead of summer cantaloupe, from the earthy, green flesh touching the rind to the intensely sweet, perfume-y, pale orange, juicy interior. After half an hour open, the wine starts to show geranium and dried apples. Not quite as impeccably balanced as Chemin de la Brune, it's a lot of wine. However, like Chemin, the palate is silky and layered, and the finish tastes like peaches and cream. I loved this bottle; it challenged me. I had to change my drinking habits to accommodate the wine, pouring it into large, round Burgundy glasses, sipping daintily, savoring every mouthful. In a way it's not fair to wax on about wines that aren't readily available. Fortunately there's a short time in the early fall of each year, when, with a bit of effort, you can still find L'Anglore. It's indubitably worth the effort.

item.title: Authenticity and the Myth of the Shepherd-Vigneron
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A couple of weeks ago my downstairs neighbor, Zach, and I were enjoying a low-key Friday evening over some (for the most part horrible) Greek wine samples. Zach writes for a number of publications including Tasting Table. In addition to being savvy and knowledgeable about wine, he is an excellent writer. You may find his work here: www.zacharysussmanwine.com. We were consuming a meal I typically make just for myself and don’t foist on other humans: swiss chard, squash and onions, chunks of sausage held together by eggs and baked in the oven. Unable to tolerate another glass of Agiorgitiko, Zach cracked a 2000 Lopez de Heredia Rosado, which was closed and a touch musty at first but blossomed as it warmed up to deliver all of the lactic, caramel, and orange rind, dill, and tobacco-y notes we like to smell and taste in Lopez Rosado. The fruit played a very faint second fiddle to savory and earthy tones and it suited the food and mood quite well. We found ourselves in conversation about the concept of “authenticity” in wine. Prior to our Friday evening Lopez, I hadn’t thought much about authenticity in wine, probably because the word doesn’t crop up in my daily work in the business, but I’ve thought about it quite a bit since that night. “Authenticity” is a writer-ly word that pops into texts to make fashionable points but is, when it comes to wine (as Zach pointed out), semantically ill equipped to say much. Dictonary.com defines it as the quality of being authentic (duh), which in turn is defined as: 1) of undisputed origin or authorship; genuine; real 2) accurate in representation of facts; trustworthy; reliable. To begin with we must make a leap from “facts” to “soils,” “grapes,” “terroirs:” an authentic wine is a wine that accurately represents soils, grapes, landscapes. Assuming there’s a ledge to stand on once this leap is made, problems continue to arise. In our circles of wine folk, it’s a popular myth that the best wines are the ones that have the least “done” to them. In turn these are supposed to be the wines that are most transparent to grape and terroir, and thus the most authentic. An authentic wine is a wine that gives the drinker a genuine or real account of soil and fruit, without the hand of man showing itself in the form of banana yeast, new barrels, preservatives, etc… Yet this image of the vigneron as a kind of shepherd herding or ushering grapes into bottles is totally inaccurate. Wine is a made thing. Even in the lowest intervention scenarios, the winemaker is doing a heck of a lot. We tout the humble shepherd-vigneron because it suits our desire to think of what we’re drinking as “natural” or “simple” or “from the earth,” not because it’s an accurate reflection of the reality of winemaking. As we all know in our heart of hearts, if man picks grapes and does nothing, man gets rotten grapes and vinegar. Furthermore, some of the modern-day techniques that yield “authentic” wine are in fact totally unnatural; the best example of this is, of course, carbonic maceration. Often (especially in warm climates) carbonic maceration just happens. There’s lag time between picking and crushing, and berries begin to ferment whole. But in carbonic maceration the winemaking technique popularized by the Gang of Four Beaujolais growers several decades ago whole grape clusters are left to ferment in sealed off tanks with a layer of carbon dioxide on top to protect them from oxidation. Difficult to imagine the humble shepherd-vigneron having access to such technology… This is not a rant against carbonic maceration. I like and drink very many wines that are made this way, though I do feel that “carbo” marks its victims. I’m merely trying to illustrate, as Zach pointed out, that it’s a type of “fabrication,” just like new oak barrels as popularized by Robert Parker in the ‘80s. “Fabrication” is Zach’s word and I think it’s an apt one. What we’re saying – at least on some level – as we proclaim the virtues of one wine over another is “I like the way this thing is fabricated.” Now – as to whether there are superior and inferior fabrication styles? Well… it’s a matter of region and grape, as well as of fashion and taste. At this point in the conversation with Zach, I found myself thinking of one thing: Champagne. (I know; I think about Champagne a lot.) Because of the complex process of secondary fermentation, riddling, disgorgement, dosage, etc… Champagne seems hyper-fabricated. And I love this about Champagne! Rarely in Champagne discourse do you encounter the myth of the shepherd-vigneron (save perhaps these days in the Aube…). I think that for related reasons, even my favorite small, organic Champagne growers have largely existed outside the natural wine movement, as though it doesn’t make sense to talk about ultra-low intervention winemaking when such a glaring intervention is involved by definition. (It’s worth saying here that while I’m willing to take a relatively inclusive view of fabrication styles, I believe adamantly that there are superior and inferior modes of vineyard management. I believe that vines tended organically produce better grapes, which in turn produces better wine.) At a certain point in our dialogue, Zach and I agreed that the problem is semantic, that the word “authentic” doesn’t have a place in our wine lexicon. And moreover that (and this point has been made many times over with respect to the word “natural”) that it sets up an erroneous dichotomy between authentic and inauthentic wines. This felt very Wittgenstein-ian to me. Why make a mountain of a mole hill? It’s just a word mistakenly appropriated by wine writers to make whatever point they want to make. It wouldn’t be the first time a mere language error masqueraded as a larger philosophical problem. The next morning I said to my coworker JFR: “you know the concept of authenticity in wine is utter bull shit” and proceeded to outline the previous evening’s discussion. “But I don’t agree with that,” he said. “I think you can have authenticity in wine… ” His point was that (of course) we can and do say that some wines speak more authentically of place than others, also that we try to get to the bottom of the fabrication styles that promote authenticity.  It might even be our job to do this. And there I was, having debunked the concept, ready to let it back into my life again. I don’t have any real answers here, but since Zach and I talked about authenticity, I’ve thought about it a lot. I thought about it when I drank this wine:To me, Ariana Occhipinti’s wines taste very process-driven; they also taste very good. (I still remember my first bottle of her Frappato; it was unbelievable.) Probably I don’t know what I’m talking about, but I find more cool-temperature maceration and fruit (they go hand-in-hand) in the bottle than I find terroir. Again, this is a delicious Nero D’Avola. It has pretty, floral dark fruit on the nose, a pleasing sense of ripe, sweetness on the palate, and lots of juicy acidity (actually an astonishing amount given the scalding temperature of Vittoria). When I drank this wine, though, it struck me as unnatural that such ripe, hot climate aromatics should be coupled with such high acidity. I cannot help but imagine such a coupling is only possible because of modern winemaking technology that allows cool temperature cellar work in a very hot place. Enough said. I certainly don’t think winemakers in hot climates should be doomed to high-alcohol, low acid, ponderous wines, but I do think fabrication is at play, and that it’s worthwhile to say so. I thought about authenticity and fabrication again when I drank this wine, which I found to be more authentic than Occipinti’s, and also less delicious:I imagine that Cyril Fhal, who makes these wines, is more of a shepherd-vigneron than Ariana, who has by this point attained wine rock star status and for good reason. Cyril makes wine in the Roussillon, a rough, mountainous, desert-like terroir in the south of France that is covered in craggy brush. He does foot pigeage for this Grenache, then vinification in old wooden vats and aging in stainless steel before bottling. Straight out of the bottle, this wine gave an impression of place. Subsumed by structure, the fruit was dusty with wild strawberry and the sweet cherry of Grenache coming out eventually. At 13% alcohol, the wine was tannic and hard, animal, spicy, gamy; it cried out for a spit-roasted lamb or some such caveman food. I respected it; it made me think, but I’m not a masochistic drinker … and I’d be hard pressed to say I enjoyed it. Ultimately I came away from the experience of heavily pondering authenticity in wine wishing folks would abandon this word. There’s so much fashion and fad involved that it doesn’t behoove anyone to get on their high horse about authenticity when they’re likely merely trying to justify a preference for one fabrication style over another. At the same time, I think we should abandon the myth of the shepherd-vigneron because it’s inaccurate. These wines we love don’t make themselves and there is much thought and effort that goes into their creation; the hand of man is apparent no matter what. As I said previously, I’ll go to the grave defending organic vineyard work, but when it comes to winemaking styles, it’s probably a good thing that there is creativity and variety in fabrication as it gives us infinite fodder for consumption and conversation.
